('55', 0, 13, 17, 749) 3. LETTER TO VANAMALA N. PARIKH
('55', 0, 14, 18, 781) February 10, 1932
('55', 0, 15, 19, 799) VANAMALA, You get five marks for your handwriting.
('55', 0, 15, 20, 850) You will get eight if you leave space between the words and use a good pen.
('55', 0, 15, 21, 926) Why does man have no root?
('55', 0, 15, 22, 953) A man carries his root wherever he goes.
('55', 0, 15, 23, 994) A tree has its root under the ground because it comes out of the ground.
('55', 0, 15, 24, 1067) Man is born from his mother’s body, and his root also comes out with him at the time of his birth.
('55', 0, 15, 25, 1166) One may say that the navel is his root.

('55', 1, 5, 5, 1492) 4. LETTER TO NARAYAN M. KHARE
('55', 1, 6, 6, 1522) February 10, 1932
('55', 1, 7, 7, 1540) PANDITJI, I got Barve’s book.
('55', 1, 7, 8, 1570) I will dip into it when I get time.
('55', 1, 8, 9, 1606) Your explanation about the first doubt is quite correct.
('55', 1, 8, 10, 1663) I have felt that that is the implication of Chapter XVII.
('55', 1, 8, 11, 1721) Ultimately one has to rely on faith.
('55', 1, 8, 12, 1758) We see again and again that what seems to be the truth to one does not often appear so to others.
('55', 1, 8, 13, 1856) However, to follow truth as one sees it is like walking on the razor’s edge.
('55', 1, 8, 14, 1933) Anyone who tries to do so ought to remain wide awake and rigidly follow all the rules and restrictions.
('55', 1, 8, 15, 2037) The lazy, the licentious, and the hypocrites can claim no right to act according to their view of truth.
('55', 1, 8, 16, 2142) That privilege belongs only to the sadhak, the seeker after truth.
('55', 1, 8, 17, 2209) As for the second doubt, I think that the sadhak will not trouble himself with deciding what is and what is not for general good.
('55', 1, 8, 18, 2339) He would say that he was not interested in the question, and that universal good lay in truth since truth was the supreme Being.
('55', 1, 8, 19, 2468) While all other names of God suggested only one aspect of His, truth signified His perfect essence, so that a person who opposed truth could never accomplish anybody’s good.
('55', 1, 8, 20, 2642) Truth necessitates harmony of thought, speech and act.
('55', 1, 8, 21, 2697) That is, one must follow truth as one sees it and always be faithful to it in thought, speech and action.
('55', 1, 8, 22, 2803) But a false notion is widely prevalent among us.
('55', 1, 8, 23, 2852) We are not always bound to answer a question asked by anyone.
('55', 1, 8, 24, 2914) There is no violation of truth in refraining from giving an answer.
('55', 1, 8, 25, 2982) To keep silent when it is one’s duty to reply to a question amounts to telling a lie.
('55', 1, 8, 26, 3068) For example, if my father asked me whether I had stolen a piece of gold, I would be bound to answer the question.
('55', 1, 8, 27, 3182) However, if even my father asked me whether somebody had stolen a thing, I would not be bound to answer.
('55', 1, 8, 28, 3287) If, therefore, I did not reply, I would not be telling a lie.
('55', 1, 8, 29, 3349) I remember the chapter in
('55', 2, 0, 1, 3375) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 3
('55', 2, 1, 2, 3419) Gitarahasya 1. I did not agree with the suggestion in it.
('55', 2, 1, 3, 3477) If you tell a lie under force of circumstances, you are certainly not telling the truth.
('55', 2, 1, 4, 3566) There never can be an occasion when one must tell a lie.
('55', 2, 1, 5, 3623) If there can be such an occasion, then it would follow that the principle of following truth in speech and action wasimperfect.
('55', 2, 1, 6, 3751) There can be no exception to a principle, and hence there can be no atonement for untruth spoken knowingly.
('55', 2, 1, 7, 3859) Or the only possible atonement would be never to do so again.
('55', 2, 1, 8, 3921) Atonement is possible only when some error is committed in ignorance.
('55', 2, 1, 9, 3991) I think that this answers your second question too.
('55', 2, 1, 10, 4043) Ask again if anything is still left out.
('55', 2, 1, 11, 4084) I have not revised this letter.
('55', 2, 2, 12, 4116) Blessings from
('55', 2, 4, 13, 4131) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 222. Courtesy: Lakshmibehn N. Khare
('55', 2, 5, 14, 4206) 5. LETTER TO SHARDA C. SHAH
('55', 2, 6, 15, 4234) February 10, 1932
('55', 2, 7, 16, 4252) SHARDA, What you have written is as good as saying that you like pakodas but not chapatis.
('55', 2, 7, 17, 4343) But a person whose body acquires such a tendency should be considered diseased.
('55', 2, 7, 18, 4423) A healthy person will never be able to satisfy his hunger by eating pakodas.
('55', 2, 7, 19, 4500) He would ask only for bread.
('55', 2, 7, 20, 4529) The same is true about the Gita.
('55', 2, 7, 21, 4562) Once your mind has awakened, you are bound to like the Gita.
('55', 2, 7, 22, 4623) You must think that there is something still lacking so long as you cannot like the Gita.
('55', 2, 7, 23, 4713) But I, who prepare such recipes, should also be blamed.
('55', 2, 7, 24, 4769) My prescription of the Gita for you is defective and that is the reason why you are not able to absorb it.
('55', 2, 7, 25, 4876) What is the remedy?
('55', 2, 8, 26, 4896) Blessings from
('55', 2, 10, 27, 4911) From the Gujarati original: C.W. 9944. Courtesy: Shardabehn G. Chokhawala

('55', 3, 1, 2, 5067) 6. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('55', 3, 2, 3, 5089) February 11, 1932
('55', 3, 3, 4, 5107) MIRA, I have your letter which consoles me.
('55', 3, 3, 5, 5151) Those who believe in God’s guidance just do the best they can and never worry.
('55', 3, 3, 6, 5230) The sun has never been known to have suffered from overstrain and yet who slaves with such unexampled regularity as he!
('55', 3, 3, 7, 5350) And why should we think that the sun is inanimate?
('55', 3, 3, 8, 5401) The difference between him and us may bethat he has no choice, we have a margin no matter how precarious it may be.
('55', 3, 3, 9, 5517) But no more speculation of this sort.
('55', 3, 3, 10, 5555) Suffice it for us that we have his brilliant example in the matter of tireless energy.
('55', 3, 3, 11, 5642) If we completely surrender ourselves to His will and really become ciphers, we too voluntarily give up the right of choice and then we need no wear and tear.
('55', 3, 3, 12, 5800) I have just commenced almond paste instead of milk.
('55', 3, 3, 13, 5852) I was daily decreasing the quantity of milk because it was not suiting me.
('55', 3, 3, 14, 5927) It may be that while I am resting, I do not need animal proteid.
('55', 3, 3, 15, 5992) I am simply trying.
('55', 3, 3, 16, 6012) Therefore, if you have more almond paste we had in London, please bring the bottles with you.
('55', 3, 3, 17, 6106) Just now I am flourishing on dates, tomatoes and almond paste, of course with lemon and honey water twice during 24 hours.
('55', 3, 3, 18, 6229) It is too early yet to say how I shall fare without milk.
('55', 3, 3, 19, 6287) I shall not do anything consciously to injure my health, much as I would love to give up milk altogether.
('55', 3, 3, 20, 6393) There may be no time for you to tell me when you come, therefore let me know by letter how you washed the woollen blankets.
('55', 3, 3, 21, 6517) Did you soak them in cold water or warm and how long?
('55', 3, 3, 22, 6571) How much Lux did you use, in how much water?
('55', 3, 3, 23, 6616) I propose to use powdered Apana soap.
('55', 3, 3, 24, 6654) I am in no hurry.
('55', 3, 3, 25, 6672) I take it that you share my letters with the Ashram and that you get from the Ashram what may be worth knowing.
('55', 3, 3, 26, 6784) I had a letter directly from the Privats.
('55', 3, 3, 27, 6826) They seem to have thoroughly enjoyed their stay and I am glad.
('55', 3, 3, 28, 6889) Do you ever meet Manilal our host and his wife?
('55', 3, 3, 29, 6937) If you meet Pyare Ali tell him or send him word not to send any more dates.
('55', 3, 3, 30, 7013) I have about 20 lb.
('55', 3, 3, 31, 7033) from Jerajani.
('55', 3, 3, 32, 7048) Moreover what Pyare Ali gets are old dates and, therefore, they are weevily.
('55', 4, 0, 1, 7125) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 5
('55', 4, 1, 2, 7169) My love to Damodardas and his people.
('55', 4, 1, 3, 7207) Love from us both.
('55', 4, 2, 4, 7226) BAPU [PS.] The accompanying for Nargis.
('55', 4, 2, 5, 7266) I have heard from Agatha Harrison.
('55', 4, 2, 6, 7301) She says that Percy Bartlett and Hyam and a university girl are coming.
('55', 4, 2, 7, 7373) 1 I forget the names.
('55', 4, 2, 8, 7395) But perhaps you have heard from her too.

('55', 6, 7, 10, 10648) February 11, 1932
('55', 6, 8, 11, 10666) RAMBHAU ALIAS RAMACHANDRA KHARE, Bravo!
('55', 6, 8, 12, 10706) You have found a good argument.
('55', 6, 8, 13, 10738) Since all others write, why need you?
('55', 6, 8, 14, 10776) If everybody argued in that way, I would get no letters.
('55', 6, 8, 15, 10833) Can’t I also argue similarly?
('55', 6, 8, 16, 10863) The correct reasoning, however, is this.
('55', 6, 8, 17, 10904) If we do our duty, others also will do theirs some day.
('55', 6, 8, 18, 10960) We have a saying to the effect: “If we ourselves are good, the whole world will be good.” Have you now completely overcome the habit of fibbing?

('55', 10, 5, 15, 16480) 19. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('55', 10, 6, 16, 16507) February 13, 1932
('55', 10, 7, 17, 16525) DEAR SISTERS,
('55', 10, 8, 18, 16539) Your nest is now almost empty.
('55', 10, 8, 19, 16570) However, I write down in these letters, as I remember them from time to time, the things that I thought worth noting.
('55', 10, 8, 20, 16688) As these letters are preserved, they may be of some use perhaps when you reassemble in future.
('55', 10, 8, 21, 16783) You have heard the name of M. Rolland.
('55', 10, 8, 22, 16822) He is a great European writer and a saintly man.
('55', 10, 8, 23, 16871) I went to see him.
('55', 10, 8, 24, 16890) He has a sister who also may now be regarded aged, like him.
('55', 10, 8, 25, 16951) She has remained unmarried with the sole purpose of helping her brother.
('55', 10, 8, 26, 17024) The language of the two, the brother and the sister, is French.
('55', 10, 8, 27, 17088) Rolland does not know English, but the sister does.
('55', 10, 8, 28, 17140) One may say that the sister has merged her identity in her brother’s.
('55', 10, 8, 29, 17210) She looks after Rolland’s needs in every respect.
('55', 10, 8, 30, 17260) She works as his secretary and also as interpreter when Englishmen come to see him.
('55', 10, 8, 31, 17344) Rolland has delicate health, and the sister guards it too.
('55', 10, 8, 32, 17403) Though such examples of renunciation are rare in this world, we do come across them in the West.
('55', 10, 8, 33, 17500) If there are any in our country, I do not know about them.
('55', 10, 8, 34, 17559) By linking up celibacy with moksha we have made it rare, and it has also, therefore, become difficult to observe.
('55', 10, 8, 35, 17673) On the other hand, in the West women observe it of their own free will for the
('55', 11, 0, 1, 17752) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 11, 1, 2, 17793) sake of service to parents or a brother or some other cause, and they find it easy to observe.
('55', 11, 1, 3, 17888) I wish to draw two lessons from this.
('55', 11, 1, 4, 17926) One, the observance of brahmacharya for any selfless purpose is good, and two, its observance is perfectly easy for anybody who has, like Rolland’s sister, a concrete reason, for his self imposed task leaves such a person no time at all.
('55', 11, 1, 5, 18164) Besides these two, there is of course the particular lesson that women have to learn from this example.
('55', 11, 2, 6, 18268) Blessings from
('55', 11, 4, 7, 18283) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II.

('55', 11, 5, 9, 18370) 20. A LETTER
('55', 11, 6, 10, 18383) February 13, 1932
('55', 11, 7, 11, 18401) CHI., This is what I mean when I say that I think of God every moment.
('55', 11, 7, 12, 18472) During waking hours there is no time when I am not aware that God dwells within and observes everything.
('55', 11, 7, 13, 18577) This awareness is intellectual and has been achieved through long practice.
('55', 11, 7, 14, 18653) I do not say that my heart has such awareness, since I do not think that I am free from all fear.
('55', 11, 7, 15, 18751) I do feel afraid of snakes, etc.
('55', 11, 7, 16, 18784) Even though I look upon death as a friend, I also see deep seated within me the desire to live.
('55', 11, 7, 17, 18880) It seems that I love life and also that I would be ready to die.
('55', 11, 7, 18, 18945) These two feelings together are strange, and because of this weakness I do not think I can say that my awareness of God is a matter of the heart also.
('55', 11, 7, 19, 19096) That the intellect accepts that He dwells in the heart is another matter.
('55', 11, 7, 20, 19170) One who actually feels the presence of God in his heart would be wholly free from blind attachment to the body.
('55', 11, 7, 21, 19282) I can see that I have not reached that stage, and yet so complete and firm is the intellectual acceptance of this idea that I also feel it is slowly sinking into the heart.
('55', 11, 7, 22, 19455) I cannot go further than this.
('55', 11, 8, 23, 19486) I trust you are no more rigid about food.
('55', 11, 8, 24, 19528) It is necessary to take fruit along with milk, and preferably fresh fruit.
('55', 11, 8, 25, 19603) A small quantity of uncooked leafy vegetables also should be included.
('55', 11, 8, 26, 19674) Tomato and lettuce are considered good.
('55', 11, 8, 27, 19714) There is a science of diet too, and it should not be disregarded.
('55', 11, 8, 28, 19780) We know that our food ought to be sattvik,
('55', 11, 9, 29, 19823) 1 Omission as in the source
('55', 12, 0, 1, 19851) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 13
('55', 12, 1, 2, 19896) but we have to learn from experience which food can be considered sattvik.
('55', 12, 1, 3, 19971) It is not necessary that one’s food should have all the characteristics of sattvik food mentioned in the Gita.
('55', 12, 1, 4, 20082) 1 Experience shows that we need fire very little.
('55', 12, 1, 5, 20132) Personally, I am certain in my mind that it is sufficient that our food is ripened by the sun.
('55', 12, 1, 6, 20227) All that I wish to say is that we should give the body what it requires from among the things which are acceptable to us.
('55', 12, 2, 7, 20349) Blessings from

('55', 13, 1, 10, 21990) Which statement of mine did you interpret to mean that, according to me, the Ashram had nothing to do with education?
('55', 13, 1, 11, 22108) My view is this: literary education—formal education—is given a secondary place in the Ashram.
('55', 13, 1, 12, 22203) That is why the Ashram could not be made a Vidyapith.
('55', 13, 1, 13, 22257) But such education is certainly useful and necessary, and that is why the Vidyapith was established.
('55', 13, 1, 14, 22358) The Ashram and the Vidyapith supplement each other.
('55', 13, 1, 15, 22410) Because of this limitation of its sphere of activities, the collection of books in the Ashram should be restricted.
('55', 13, 1, 16, 22526) 1 The Vidyapith can have no such restriction.
('55', 13, 1, 17, 22572) The restrictions on it relate to its internal experiments.
('55', 13, 1, 18, 22631) The Ashram has a big name and certain extravagant notions have come to be formed about it, so that it receives books on all kinds of subjects and in many languages.
('55', 13, 1, 19, 22796) The Vidyapith is the right place where they can be preserved.
('55', 13, 1, 20, 22858) The Ashram, on the other hand, should have only such books as relate to the subjects which we study.
('55', 13, 1, 21, 22959) What books fall in this class, you and others can easily decide.
('55', 13, 1, 22, 23024) Whenever you cannot decide you may consult me.
('55', 13, 1, 23, 23071) Personally, however, I don’t see what difficulty you can experience in this matter.
('55', 13, 1, 24, 23155) After so many years of the Ashram’s existence, we should be able to tell immediately what kinds of books we generally require.
('55', 13, 1, 25, 23282) If at any time we require some other books, we can take advantage of the collection in the Vidyapith.
('55', 13, 1, 26, 23384) We should not regard the Ashram and the Vidyapith as two independent institutions.
('55', 13, 1, 27, 23467) Their spheres of activity are different, but the two have much in common between them and that area is gradually expanding.
('55', 13, 1, 28, 23591) If you do not understand any point in this, ask me again.
('55', 13, 1, 29, 23649) I am sure I do not consciously refuse to hear or observe
('55', 13, 2, 30, 23706) 1 The addressee had objected to the transfer of books to the Vidyapith as this would be so much loss to the Ashram.
('55', 14, 0, 1, 23822) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 15
('55', 14, 1, 2, 23867) anything against a person about whom my views are formed.
('55', 14, 1, 3, 23925) 1 I always hear what others say, but my views may not change.
('55', 14, 1, 4, 23987) I think it would be wrong for anyone to change, quickly, views formed after careful observation.
('55', 14, 1, 5, 24084) It would, of course, be obstinacy never to change them.
('55', 14, 1, 6, 24140) Hence, that too would be wrong.
('55', 14, 1, 7, 24172) But there should be a sound reason for changing such a view.
('55', 14, 1, 8, 24233) Often I require the evidence of proved facts.
('55', 14, 1, 9, 24279) I cherish this nature of mine, which has saved me from many dangers and kept my relations with people unclouded by suspicion.
('55', 14, 1, 10, 24405) You are, therefore, free to ask me what you like.
('55', 14, 1, 11, 24455) You will not get such an opportunity again.
('55', 14, 1, 12, 24499) The distinction you have made is correct.
('55', 14, 1, 13, 24541) 2 The writer of articles in Young India is one person, and the man whom the inmates of the Ashram know intimately is another.
('55', 14, 1, 14, 24667) In Young India, I might present myself as one of the Pandavas, but, in the Ashram, how can I help showing myself as I am?
('55', 14, 1, 15, 24789) I am, moreover, a votary of truth and can make no attempt consciously to hide my weaknesses.
('55', 14, 1, 16, 24882) Hence, the Kauravas dwelling in me make their presence felt in one way or another.

('55', 14, 1, 20, 25160) As Solon 3 has said, the final judgment about a man can be expressed only after his death.
('55', 14, 1, 21, 25251) I have known cases in which crores were reduced to a cowrie in a moment.
('55', 14, 1, 22, 25324) I have, therefore, no pride in me at all.
('55', 14, 1, 23, 25366) And what does pride avail one?
('55', 14, 1, 24, 25397) Remember that I do not revise the letters after writing them.

('55', 18, 4, 9, 31486) 27. LETTER TO PHILIP HARTOG
('55', 18, 5, 10, 31514) February 15, 1932
('55', 18, 6, 11, 31532) DEAR FRIEND, I am sorry I was unable, owing to circumstances beyond my control, to fulfil the promise I gave you about my statement 3 on the condition of primary education in India during the pre British time.
('55', 18, 6, 12, 31742) Immediately on my landing I entrusted the research to Advocate Munshi, a member of the Bombay University Senate, and two other educationist 4 friends.
('55', 18, 6, 13, 31893) But they too like me find themselves civil resistance prisoners.
('55', 18, 6, 14, 31958) I had asked Advocate Munshi to put himself in direct touch with you.
('55', 18, 6, 15, 32027) But his arrest came so soon after mine that I hardly think he could have corresponded with you.
('55', 18, 6, 16, 32123) As I am permitted to carry on non political correspondence, I have now asked Prof.
('55', 18, 6, 17, 32206) Shah to test my statement and give you the result of his test.
('55', 18, 6, 18, 32269) As I found in you a fellow seeker after the truth, I was most anxious to give you satisfaction either by confirming my statement or withdrawing it as publicly as I had made it.
('55', 18, 6, 19, 32446) I thought that I would tell you what I had done in pursuance of my promise.

('55', 19, 8, 14, 33449) February 16, 1932
('55', 19, 9, 15, 33467) DEAR MAJOR MARTIN, In continuation of my letter 3 to Major Bhandari and in confirmation of our conversation of today, what I need is the human touch with the co workers who are not known to political fame and who have been brought to Yeravda.
('55', 19, 9, 16, 33710) I have specially in mind Messrs Chhaganlal Joshi, Surendranath, Somabhai and my son, Ramdas.

('55', 19, 9, 19, 33952) And I can have no idea whatsoever of interfering with jail discipline.
('55', 19, 9, 20, 34023) As the matter has been now hanging for some time I would thank you to expedite it as much as possible.
('55', 19, 9, 21, 34126) Yours sincerely, Home Department, Government of Bombay, I.G.P. File No.

('55', 21, 1, 2, 35751) 32. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('55', 21, 2, 3, 35778) February 18, 1932
('55', 21, 3, 4, 35796) DEAR SISTERS, Regardless of your number, someone among you should still shoulder the responsibility and keep your Association going.
('55', 21, 3, 5, 35929) Prayers should continue without any change.
('55', 21, 3, 6, 35973) I should regularly get a letter on behalf of all the women.
('55', 21, 3, 7, 36033) Otherwise I, too, am likely by and by to get tired of writing.
('55', 21, 3, 8, 36096) Who among you has charge of my letters and preserves them?
('55', 21, 3, 9, 36155) I will write today about a school that struck me as a wonderful institution.
('55', 21, 3, 10, 36232) One or two men and one or two women run it jointly.
('55', 21, 3, 11, 36284) They believe that even the dullest child responds to the law of love.
('55', 21, 3, 12, 36354) And, accordingly, they have taken in hand the work of educating abandoned orphans who have become practically mindless.
('55', 21, 3, 13, 36474) The school is run according to certain principles which their teacher has discovered through experiments in the method of love.
('55', 21, 3, 14, 36602) These men and women have dedicated their lives to such children, who do not know that they are destitute and have no parents.
('55', 21, 3, 15, 36728) They are brought up in open air and sunshine; the building they live in stands on spacious open ground.
('55', 21, 3, 16, 36832) They are cured chiefly with the help of music.
('55', 21, 3, 17, 36879) They make some slow artistic movements to the accompaniment of music, and even become absorbed in them.
('55', 21, 3, 18, 36983) The women teachers treat the children as their own.
('55', 21, 3, 19, 37035) They have their meals with the children, keep them cheerful and busy in games the whole day and gradually bring them out of their stupor.
('55', 21, 3, 20, 37173) These kind hearted men and women have been carrying on this experiment for the last three or four years only.
('55', 21, 3, 21, 37283) This wonderful school is situated very near to where Mr. Horace Alexander lives.
('55', 21, 3, 22, 37364) Seeing the school, I bowed my head in reverence and wondered what love could not do.
('55', 21, 3, 23, 37449) It can make the dumb speak and the lame climb a mountain.
('55', 21, 4, 24, 37507) Blessings from
('55', 21, 6, 25, 37522) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./III.

('55', 23, 9, 18, 39704) 38. LETTER TO SHARDA C. SHAH February 18, 1932
('55', 23, 10, 19, 39751) SHARDA, You have raised a correct question.
('55', 23, 10, 20, 39795) You are sure that beating necessarily involves violence but it is not so.
('55', 23, 10, 21, 39869) Supposing somebody has been bitten by a snake and is about to faint.
('55', 23, 10, 22, 39938) In that case he will have to be fed even if it means beating him.
('55', 23, 10, 23, 40004) This is no violence because this beating is inspired by love and is for the good of the patient.But supposing I have an ill feeling for you in my mind but do not beat you for want of an opportunity.
('55', 23, 10, 24, 40203) Such an ill feeling is violence.
('55', 23, 10, 25, 40236) The origin of violence lies in our own minds.

('55', 25, 5, 11, 42099) 42. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK February 19, 1932
('55', 25, 6, 12, 42148) PREMA, Your letter was very good.
('55', 25, 6, 13, 42182) I was glad that you wrote quite freely.
('55', 25, 6, 14, 42222) This is my reply to your criticism 1. I must hear what the persons concerned have to say in their defence.
('55', 25, 6, 15, 42329) Only after that can I express my opinion in each case.
('55', 25, 6, 16, 42384) In a general way, however, I can say that, whenever some freedom was permitted, it was done not as a privilege but as a matter of necessity.
('55', 25, 6, 17, 42525) I have formed the impression that those who permit themselves any freedom do so not out of lethargy but because their bodies, or say their natures, demand it.
('55', 25, 6, 18, 42684) We ought not to sit in judgment over others.
('55', 25, 6, 19, 42729) We may not even be aware of the effort they make [to follow the rules].
('55', 25, 6, 20, 42801) This does not mean that such persons have no imperfection in them.
('55', 25, 6, 21, 42868) If they did not have any, why did they join the Ashram at all?
('55', 25, 6, 22, 42931) They are not hypocrites.
('55', 25, 6, 23, 42956) There is a great error in believing that everyone should or can do what one does.
('55', 25, 6, 24, 43038) If I tried to lift a weight which Hariyomal 2 can, I would die that very moment.
('55', 25, 6, 25, 43119) Similarly, it would be wrong of him to envy me my weakness.
('55', 25, 6, 26, 43179) Many have said that people deceive me.
('55', 25, 6, 27, 43218) I don’t say that no one deceives me, but the number of such persons is certainly not large.
('55', 25, 7, 28, 43310) 1 Regarding inmates of the Ashram allowing themselves freedom from one or other of the Ashram rules 2 A strong man from Sind who worked on the Ashram farm
('55', 26, 0, 1, 43465) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 27
('55', 26, 1, 2, 43510) have observed that many persons cannot, when they are away from me, keep up the standard of behaviour which they preserve when I am there.
('55', 26, 1, 3, 43649) Some even leave me for this reason.
('55', 26, 1, 4, 43685) There are many such instances and that is why I have been accused of possessing a kind of magnetism.
('55', 26, 1, 5, 43786) But this is not likely to satisfy you or others.
('55', 26, 1, 6, 43835) Nor have I said this to defend myself.
('55', 26, 1, 7, 43874) I have only explained my attitude.
('55', 26, 1, 8, 43909) The real position, however, is this, and I have held this belief for many years.
('55', 26, 1, 9, 43990) The deficiencies of the Ashram reflect my own.
('55', 26, 1, 10, 44037) I have told many people that they cannot know me by meeting me.
('55', 26, 1, 11, 44101) When they meet me, I may even impress them as being good.
('55', 26, 1, 12, 44159) Even if I am not good, people would believe that I was because I am a lover of truth.
('55', 26, 1, 13, 44245) My love of truth casts a momentary spell over people.
('55', 26, 1, 14, 44299) In order to know me, people should see the Ashram in my absence.
('55', 26, 1, 15, 44364) There would be no error and no injustice to me in believing that all its deficiencies are a reflection of my own deficiencies.
('55', 26, 1, 16, 44491) It is but true that I have drawn the crowd which has gathered in the Ashram.
('55', 26, 1, 17, 44568) If, though living in the Ashram, they have not been able to overcome their weaknesses but have, on the contrary, developed more, the fault is not theirs but mine.
('55', 26, 1, 18, 44731) The imperfection of my spiritual striving is responsible for this state of affairs.
('55', 26, 1, 19, 44815) Nor is it that I do not observe or know about my shortcomings.
('55', 26, 1, 20, 44878) All that I can say is that they are there despite my best efforts to overcome them.
('55', 26, 1, 21, 44962) And, moreover, I am convinced that, because I am ceaselessly striving to improve the Ashram, it has not, on the whole, fallen altogether from its ideal.
('55', 26, 1, 22, 45115) I derive some satisfaction from the thought that every one of the three Ashrams which I established served or has served its immediate aim.
('55', 26, 1, 23, 45255) I will not, however, deceive myself or anybody else with this comforting thought.
('55', 26, 1, 24, 45337) I wish to travel far and there are hills and valleys to be crossed on the way.
('55', 26, 1, 25, 45416) I am resolved, however, to continue the journey.
('55', 26, 1, 26, 45465) And I rest in peace in the knowledge that there is no defeat in the quest for truth.
('55', 26, 1, 27, 45550) It is true indeed that the Ashram has not been able to attract the learned class.
('55', 26, 1, 28, 45632) The reason is that I don’t regard myself as a learned man.
('55', 26, 1, 29, 45691) The few learned men who were drawn to the Ashram joined it not in order to pursue their learned callings but to receive and nurse something else altogether.
('55', 26, 1, 30, 45848) They [are] seekers after truth.
('55', 26, 1, 31, 45880) The quest of truth may be undertaken even by the illiterate, by children and by theold, by women and by men.
('55', 26, 1, 32, 45989) Literary education sometimes serves as the golden lid which covers the face of truth.
('55', 26, 1, 33, 46075) I do not, by saying this,
('55', 27, 0, 1, 46101) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 27, 1, 2, 46142) condemn such education, but only put it in its proper place.
('55', 27, 1, 3, 46203) It is one of the means [in the pursuit of truth].
('55', 27, 1, 4, 46253) We have selected most of the prayers from Sanskrit because it is chiefly Hindus who joined the Ashram.
('55', 27, 1, 5, 46356) We have no aversion to prayers in other languages.
('55', 27, 1, 6, 46407) Don’t we use such prayers occasionally?
('55', 27, 1, 7, 46447) If, instead of a large number of Hindus, a large number of Muslims had joined the Ashram, prayers from the Koran would be recited every day and I would even join such prayers.
('55', 27, 1, 8, 46623) Does this answer your doubts?
('55', 27, 1, 9, 46653) Does it satisfy you?
('55', 27, 1, 10, 46674) If it does not, ask me again and again.
('55', 27, 1, 11, 46714) I shall not get tired.
('55', 27, 1, 12, 46737) I wish to satisfy you.
('55', 27, 1, 13, 46760) Don’t get tired.
('55', 27, 2, 14, 46777) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10273. Also C.W. 6721. Courtesy: Premabehn Kantak
('55', 27, 3, 15, 46886) 43. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM February 20, 1932
('55', 27, 4, 16, 46941) MATHURADAS 1, I am glad that you have gone to the Ashram.
('55', 27, 4, 17, 46999) I wrote that to Kamu many years ago.
('55', 27, 4, 18, 47036) Doctors are now gradually coming to the conclusion that all diseases have one common cause and that, therefore, their main remedy also should be one.
('55', 27, 4, 19, 47186) If anybody disregards modifications of that one remedy, that would not do him much or any harm.
('55', 27, 4, 20, 47282) It might be said that the disease was not cured.
('55', 27, 4, 21, 47331) But what even if the disease is cured?
('55', 27, 4, 22, 47370) Surely the body does not become immune to death.
('55', 27, 4, 23, 47419) Hence, if anybody sticks to only one remedy with faith, he commits no sin.
('55', 27, 4, 24, 47494) This is also true about spiritual maladies.
('55', 27, 4, 25, 47538) The cause is always one, and that is the ego.
('55', 27, 4, 26, 47584) The remedy also is one—giving up the ego, that is, reducing oneself to a cipher.
('55', 27, 4, 27, 47665) How will one who is a cipher steal?
('55', 27, 4, 28, 47701) How will he tell a lie or commit adultery?
('55', 27, 4, 29, 47744) The very questions you have asked spring from ignorance.
('55', 27, 4, 30, 47801) Let us take just one example.
('55', 27, 4, 31, 47831) Of course you do not steal in the ordinary sense, but you are right in thinking that your lack of control in eating is a form of stealing.
('55', 27, 4, 32, 47970) The remedy for this kind of stealing and the ordinary kind must be the same, that is, to give up the habit, to stop eating what you should not.
('55', 27, 5, 33, 48114) 1 Mathuradas P. Asar, an expert carder and khadi worker of the Ashram
('55', 28, 0, 1, 48184) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 29
('55', 28, 1, 2, 48229) But who is it that eats such food?
('55', 28, 1, 3, 48264) The ego self.
('55', 28, 1, 4, 48278) Once that has vanished, the other self, though eating, will not be eating and will only give the body its wages.
('55', 28, 1, 5, 48391) There will be no more question, then, of indulging the palate.
('55', 28, 1, 6, 48454) Probably you will accept all this with your reason, but it will have meaning only if it sinks into the heart.
('55', 28, 1, 7, 48564) We live in the Ashram and seek good company, sing bhajans, etc., daily, in order that this truth may sink into the heart.
('55', 28, 1, 8, 48686) Some day we shall find what we are seeking.
('55', 28, 1, 9, 48730) In other words, our malady in the form of the ego will be cured.
('55', 28, 1, 10, 48795) From this you should be able to deduce all the answers, and if you cannot, no matter how much I write and explain, you will not feel satisfied.
('55', 28, 1, 11, 48939) Ask me again and again till your doubts are resolved.
('55', 28, 2, 12, 48993) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3753

('55', 29, 0, 1, 49810) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 29, 1, 2, 49851) 45. LETTER TO SHIVABHAI G. PATEL February 20, 1932
('55', 29, 2, 3, 49902) SHIVABHAI, I have your letter.
('55', 29, 2, 4, 49933) There is not the slightest doubt that if we condone or take direct or indirect advantage of the untruth spoken or practised by a person with whom we associate, we become party to his untruth.
('55', 29, 2, 5, 50125) It is for this reason that Tulsidas advises us to seek the company of the good.
('55', 29, 2, 6, 50205) However, in practical life we cannot always live up to the ideal.
('55', 29, 2, 7, 50271) We have to bear with our co workers.
('55', 29, 2, 8, 50308) We may consider the circumstances in each case and act within the limits of our capacity.
('55', 29, 2, 9, 50398) We ought not to join where untruth is being deliberately practised, but having once found ourselves in a certain situation, it may not be possible to force ourselves out of it.
('55', 29, 2, 10, 50575) Where the situation is ab initio permeated with untruth, we have of course the weapon of non co operation.
('55', 29, 2, 11, 50682) Surely, it cannot be claimed that no one practises untruth in the Ashram.
('55', 29, 2, 12, 50756) Still, we do not close down the Ashram, nor do we condone untruth; but we bear with our associates and strive to advance further every day.
('55', 29, 2, 13, 50896) Nobody in this world can do more than this.
('55', 29, 2, 14, 50940) Have you come to know about the new method of spinning the takli?
('55', 29, 2, 15, 51006) It is being practised at Wardha.
('55', 29, 2, 16, 51039) One can draw 160 rounds in half an hour by following it.
('55', 29, 2, 17, 51096) Why should your diary include anything other than your own daily activities?
('55', 29, 2, 18, 51173) If necessary, you may give up recording even these.

('55', 31, 3, 15, 53651) 49. LETTERS ON THE “GITA” 2
('55', 31, 4, 16, 53679) CHAPTER I 3
('55', 31, 5, 17, 53691) Tuesday Morning, November 11, 1930 The Gita is a small portion of the Mahabharata.
('55', 31, 5, 18, 53774) The latter is generally looked upon as a historical work.
('55', 31, 5, 19, 53832) To us, however, the Mahabharata and the Ramayana are not historical works but are treatises on religion.
('55', 31, 5, 20, 53937) Or, if we call them histories, they narrate the
('55', 31, 6, 21, 53985) 1 Rukmini Benarsilal Bazaj, daughter of Maganlal Gandhi 2 Written during Gandhiji’s incarceration in Yeravda Central Prison in 1930 and 1932, these were sent weekly along with letters to Narandas Gandhi for being read out at the Ashram prayer meetings.
('55', 31, 6, 22, 54238) Gandhiji commenced the series with Chapter Xll; vide “Letter to Behramji Khambhatta”, 4 11 1930. The following week Gandhiji sent Chapter I, with a general introductory note on the Gita.
('55', 31, 6, 23, 54425) All the chapters are given here under February 19/21, 1932, the date of despatch of the letter to Narandas Gandhi, which carried the discourse on Chapter XVllI and concluded the series; vide the following item.
('55', 31, 6, 24, 54636) The translation is reproduced from the Discourses on the Gita (Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad 14, 1960) with slight changes to bring the text into conformity with the Gujarati original.
('55', 31, 6, 25, 54829) The Translator’s Preface in the Discourses on the Gita says: “Gandhiji’s Gujarati translation of the Gita was published on March 12, 1930, the never to be forgotten day on which he marched to Dandi from Sabarmati.
('55', 31, 6, 26, 55043) A member of the Ashram who read it found it very difficult to understand and complained about it to Gandhiji who was then in Yeravda Prison.
('55', 31, 6, 27, 55184) Thereupon, he wrote a series of letters to the Ashram in which he devoted one letter to each chapter on the Gita.
('55', 31, 6, 28, 55298) .” For Gandhiji’s discourses on the Gita at Ashram prayer meetings in 1926, vide “Discourses on the Gita”, and for his Gujarati translation of the Gita with a commentary thereon written in 1929, vide “Anasaktiyoga”.
('55', 31, 6, 29, 55514) 3 This was sent along with ‘‘Letter to Narandas Gandhi” 11 11 1930; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11 11 1930
('55', 32, 0, 1, 55627) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 33
('55', 32, 1, 2, 55672) history of the human soul; they do not tell of what happened thousands of years ago, but depict what takes place in the heart of every human being today.
('55', 32, 1, 3, 55826) Both the works describe the eternal war between the God and the demon in man—between Rama and Ravana.
('55', 32, 1, 4, 55928) The Gita does this in the form of a dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna.
('55', 32, 1, 5, 56001) The dialogue is narrated to the blind Dhritarashtra by Sanjaya.
('55', 32, 1, 6, 56065) Literally Gita means that which is sung.
('55', 32, 1, 7, 56106) The adjective applies to the noun Upanishad, which is understood, and so the full meaning of the phrase is “the Upanishad which was sung”.
('55', 32, 1, 8, 56245) Upanishad means knowledge teaching.
('55', 32, 1, 9, 56281) The word ‘Gita,’ therefore, means Shri Krishna’s teaching to Arjuna.
('55', 32, 1, 10, 56350) In reading the Gita we should feel that Shri Krishna—God—dwells in our hearts as the holy spirit within us, and that when, yearning for knowledge, like Arjuna, we take our spiritual difficulties to Him and seek His guidance, seek refuge in Him, He is ever ready to instruct us.
('55', 32, 1, 11, 56628) We slumber, but the Lord within us is ever awake.
('55', 32, 1, 12, 56678) He is only waiting for spiritual yearning to be awakened in us.
('55', 32, 1, 13, 56742) We, however, do not know how to question Him, do not even feel the desire to do so.
('55', 32, 1, 14, 56826) And so we read a work like the Gita every day and meditate over its teaching.
('55', 32, 1, 15, 56904) By doing so, we wish to awaken spiritual yearning in us and learn what questions to put to the Lord.
('55', 32, 1, 16, 57005) Whenever we are faced with spiritual difficulties, we turn to the Gita for their solution and obtain peace of mind through it.
('55', 32, 1, 17, 57132) This is the spirit in which we should read the work.
('55', 32, 1, 18, 57185) It is as it were our revered guru, our mother, and we should have faith that we shall be safe if we seek shelter in her lap.
('55', 32, 1, 19, 57310) We can get all our spiritual difficulties solved through the Gita.
('55', 32, 1, 20, 57377) Anyone who daily meditates over the teaching of the Gita in this manner will ever experience new joy in his study and find new meanings.
('55', 32, 1, 21, 57514) There is no spiritual problem which the Gita cannot solve, though it may be that owing to our imperfect faith we do not know how to read and understand the work.
('55', 32, 1, 22, 57676) We read the Gita as daily spiritual practice so that our faith may increase from day to day and we may become vigilant.
('55', 32, 1, 23, 57796) I give here, for the guidance of the inmates of the Ashram, the meaning of the Gita which my daily meditation over its teaching has revealed or reveals to me.
('55', 32, 1, 24, 57955) When the Pandavas and the Kauravas gathered together on the battle field of Kurukshetra (the field of Kuru) with their armies, Duryodhana, the king of the Kauravas, approached Drona (his teacher in the science of war) and named the leading warriors on either side.
('55', 32, 1, 25, 58220) As a signal for the battle to begin, conch shell horns were sounded on both the sides and Shri Krishna who was Arjuna’s charioteer drove his
('55', 33, 0, 1, 58361) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 33, 1, 2, 58402) chariot into a place between the two armies.
('55', 33, 1, 3, 58447) The scene which greeted Arjuna’s eyes unnerved him, and he said to Shri Krishna: “How can I attack these in battle?
('55', 33, 1, 4, 58563) I might readily enough if I had to fight with strangers, but these are my kinsmen.
('55', 33, 1, 5, 58646) The Kauravas and the Pandavas are first cousins.
('55', 33, 1, 6, 58695) We were brought up together.
('55', 33, 1, 7, 58724) Drona is our teacher as well as the Kauravas’.
('55', 33, 1, 8, 58771) Bhishma is a revered elder for both.
('55', 33, 1, 9, 58808) How can I fight against him?
('55', 33, 1, 10, 58837) It is true that the Kauravas are miscreants and doers of evil deeds.
('55', 33, 1, 11, 58906) They have wronged the Pandavas and deprived them oftheir lands.
('55', 33, 1, 12, 58970) They have insulted the saintly Draupadi.
('55', 33, 1, 13, 59011) But what shall I gain by killing them?
('55', 33, 1, 14, 59050) They are fools indeed.
('55', 33, 1, 15, 59073) But shall I also be equally foolish?
('55', 33, 1, 16, 59110) I have some little knowledge.
('55', 33, 1, 17, 59140) I can discriminate between right and wrong.
('55', 33, 1, 18, 59184) I thus see that it is a sin to fight against relatives.
('55', 33, 1, 19, 59240) Never mind if they have taken wrongful possession of the Pandavas’ share in the kingdom.
('55', 33, 1, 20, 59329) Never mind even if they kill us.
('55', 33, 1, 21, 59362) But how dare we raise our hand against them?
('55', 33, 1, 22, 59407) O Krishna, I will not fight against my kith and kin.” With these words, Arjuna sank down on the seat of the chariot, being overwhelmed by grief.
('55', 33, 1, 23, 59552) Here ends the first Chapter which is entitled “The Sorrow of Arjuna”.
('55', 33, 1, 24, 59622) All of us should feel pain even as Arjuna did.
('55', 33, 1, 25, 59669) No acquisition of knowledge is possible unless there is in us a sense of something lacking and a desire to know the truth.
('55', 33, 1, 26, 59792) If a man is not curious even to know what is wrong and what is right, what is the use of religion for him?
('55', 33, 1, 27, 59899) The battle field of Kurukshetra only provides the occasion for the dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna.
('55', 33, 1, 28, 60003) The real Kurukshetra is the human heart, which is also a dharmakshetra (the field of righteousness) if we look upon it as the abode of God and invite Him to take hold of it.
('55', 33, 1, 29, 60177) Some battle or other is fought on this battle field from day to day.
('55', 33, 1, 30, 60246) Most of these battles arise from the distinction between ‘mine’ and ‘thine’, between kinsmen and strangers.
('55', 33, 1, 31, 60354) Therefore, as we shall find later on, the Lord tells Arjuna that attraction (raga) and repulsion (dvesha) lie at the root of sin.
('55', 33, 1, 32, 60484) When I look upon a person or thing as ‘mine’, raga takes hold of my mind; and when I look upon him as a stranger, aversion or hatred enters the mind.
('55', 33, 1, 33, 60634) Therefore we must forget the distinction between ‘mine’ and ‘thine’.
('55', 33, 1, 34, 60703) That is to say, we must give up our likes and dislikes.
('55', 33, 1, 35, 60759) This is the teaching of the Gita and all other scriptures.
('55', 33, 1, 36, 60818) To say this is one thing; to practise it is quite another.
('55', 33, 1, 37, 60877) The Gita is there to teach us how to practise We will try to understand the method it recommends.
('55', 34, 0, 1, 60975) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 35
('55', 34, 1, 2, 61020) CHAPTER II 1
('55', 34, 2, 3, 61033) Monday Morning, November 17, 1930 When Arjuna had picked himself up a little, the Lord rebuked him and said: “How is it that this delusion has come to you?
('55', 34, 2, 4, 61189) It is unworthy of a warrior like you.” But even then Arjuna stuck to his first position, refused to fight and said: “If in order to get it, I have toslay elders and other relations, I do not want not only a kingdom on this earth but even the delights of paradise.
('55', 34, 2, 5, 61453) My mind gropes in darkness.
('55', 34, 2, 6, 61481) I do not know where my duty lies.
('55', 34, 2, 7, 61515) I put myself into your hands.
('55', 34, 2, 8, 61545) Please guide me.” Finding that Arjuna was bewildered and aspired after knowledge, Krishna had pity on him and proceeded to explain things to him: “Your sorrow is for nothing, and you utter words about wisdom without understanding.
('55', 34, 2, 9, 61776) You have evidently forgotten the distinction between the body and the embodied soul.
('55', 34, 2, 10, 61861) The soul never dies; but the body passes through childhood, youth and old age and perishes in the end.
('55', 34, 2, 11, 61964) The body is born but the soul is birthless and unchanging.
('55', 34, 2, 12, 62023) It ever was, is now and will be there for all time to come.
('55', 34, 2, 13, 62083) For whom then do you grieve?
('55', 34, 2, 14, 62112) Your grief arises from a delusion.
('55', 34, 2, 15, 62147) You look upon these Kauravas as your own, but you are aware that their bodies will come to an end.
('55', 34, 2, 16, 62246) And as for the souls which inhabit these bodies, no one can destroy them.
('55', 34, 2, 17, 62320) The soul cannot be wounded by weapons, burned by fire, dried by the wind or drowned in water.
('55', 34, 2, 18, 62414) Then again, consider this from the standpoint of your duty as a warrior with an army under his command.
('55', 34, 2, 19, 62518) If you refuse to fight this righteous war, the consequences will be the very reverse of what you expect and you will become an object of ridicule.
('55', 34, 2, 20, 62665) You have always enjoyed the reputation of being a brave man.
('55', 34, 2, 21, 62726) But if now you withdraw from the battle, you will be supposed to have been driven from it by fear.
('55', 34, 2, 22, 62825) If it were part of your duty to flee in the face of danger, disgrace would not matter, but if you retire from battle now, you will have failed to discharge your duty, and people will be justified in condemning your flight.
('55', 34, 2, 23, 63048) “Thus far, I have tried to reason out things, draw a distinction between the body and the soul and remind you of your duty as a warrior.
('55', 34, 2, 24, 63185) But let me now explain karmayoga (the method of action).
('55', 34, 2, 25, 63242) A practitioner of karmayoga never comes to harm.
('55', 34, 2, 26, 63291) It has nothing to do
('55', 34, 3, 27, 63312) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 13/17 11 1930; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi
('55', 35, 0, 1, 63415) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 35, 1, 2, 63456) with chopping logic.
('55', 35, 1, 3, 63477) It is something to be translated into action and experience.
('55', 35, 1, 4, 63538) An ounce of practice is more profitable than tons of argumentation.
('55', 35, 1, 5, 63606) And this practice too must not be vitiated by speculation about its fruit.
('55', 35, 1, 6, 63681) Literalists perform Vedic rites directed to the acquisition of material rewards.
('55', 35, 1, 7, 63762) If one rite does not yield the expected fruit, they have recourse to another, and being disappointed once more, they take up a third.
('55', 35, 1, 8, 63896) And thus they suffer from utter mental confusion.
('55', 35, 1, 9, 63946) As a matter of fact, it is up to us to do our duty without wasting a single thought on the fruits of our action.
('55', 35, 1, 10, 64059) To fight is the duty you have to discharge at present.
('55', 35, 1, 11, 64114) Gain or loss, defeat or victory, is not in your power.
('55', 35, 1, 12, 64169) Why should you carry the needless burden of thinking about them and be like the dog who walks under a cart and imagines that it is being drawn by himself and not by the bullocks?
('55', 35, 1, 13, 64348) Defeat and victory, heat and cold, pleasure and pain come to a man in turn and he must put up with them.
('55', 35, 1, 14, 64453) Without worrying about the fruit of action, a man must devote himself to the performance of his duty with an evenness of temper.
('55', 35, 1, 15, 64582) This is yoga, or skill in action.
('55', 35, 1, 16, 64616) The success of an act lies in performing it, and not in its result, whatever it is.
('55', 35, 1, 17, 64700) Therefore be calm and do your duty regardless of consequences.” On hearing all this Arjuna said: “The course of conduct you have mapped out for me seems to be beyond my capacity.
('55', 35, 1, 18, 64879) Not to worry about defeat or victory, not to waste a thought on the result how can one attain such evenness of temper and steadfastness in spirit?
('55', 35, 1, 19, 65026) How does a man with such attainments behave, and how are we to recognize him?” The Lord replied: “O King, one who renounces all the cravings which torment the heart and derives his contentment from within himself is said to be a sthitaprajna or samadhistha (one stable in spirit).
('55', 35, 1, 20, 65307) He is unruffled in adversity, and he does not hanker after happiness.
('55', 35, 1, 21, 65377) Pleasure and pain are felt through the five senses.
('55', 35, 1, 22, 65429) Therefore this wise man draws his senses away from sense objects even as a tortoise draws in his limbs.
('55', 35, 1, 23, 65533) The tortoise withdraws into his shell when he apprehends danger.
('55', 35, 1, 24, 65598) But in the case of human beings sense objects are ready to attack the senses at all times; therefore their senses must always be drawn in, and they should be ever ready to fight against sense objects.
('55', 35, 1, 25, 65799) This is the real battle.
('55', 35, 1, 26, 65824) Some people resort to self mortification and fasting as weapons of defence against sense objects.
('55', 35, 1, 27, 65922) These measures have their limited use.
('55', 35, 1, 28, 65961) The senses do not make for sense objects so long as a man is fasting, but fasting
('55', 36, 0, 1, 66043) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 37
('55', 36, 1, 2, 66088) alone does not destroy his relish for them.
('55', 36, 1, 3, 66132) On the other hand that relish may be heightened when the fast is broken, and a man can get rid of it only with the grace of God.
('55', 36, 1, 4, 66261) The senses are so powerful that they drag a man behind them by force if he is not on his guard.
('55', 36, 1, 5, 66357) Therefore a man must always keep them under control.
('55', 36, 1, 6, 66410) This end he can achieve only if he turns his eyes inward, realizes God who resides in his heart and is devoted to Him.
('55', 36, 1, 7, 66529) One who thus looks upon Me as His goal and surrenders his all to Me, keeping his senses in control, is a yogi stable in spirit.
('55', 36, 1, 8, 66657) “On the other hand, if a man is not master of his senses, he is always musing on the objects of sense and conceives an attachment for them, so that he can hardly think of anything else.
('55', 36, 1, 9, 66843) From thisattachment arises desire; and when the desire is thwarted he gets angry.
('55', 36, 1, 10, 66925) Anger drives him nearly mad.
('55', 36, 1, 11, 66954) He cannot understand what he is about.
('55', 36, 1, 12, 66993) He thus loses his memory, behaves in a disorderly manner and comes to an ignoble end.
('55', 36, 1, 13, 67079) When a man’s senses rove at will, he is like a rudderless ship which is at the mercy of the gale and is broken to pieces on the rocks.
('55', 36, 1, 14, 67214) Men should therefore abandon all desires and restrain their senses, so that these do not indulge in undesirable activity.
('55', 36, 1, 15, 67336) The eyes then will look straight and that too only at holy objects; the ears will listen to hymns in praise of God or to cries of distress; hands and feet will be engaged in service.
('55', 36, 1, 16, 67519) Indeed all the organs of sense and of action will be employed in helping a man to do his duty and making him a fit recipient of the grace of God.
('55', 36, 1, 17, 67665) And once the grace of God has descended upon him, all his sorrows are at an end.
('55', 36, 1, 18, 67746) As snow melts in the sunshine, all pain vanishes when the grace of God shines upon him and he is said to be stable in spirit.
('55', 36, 1, 19, 67872) “But if a man is not stable minded, how can he think good thoughts?
('55', 36, 1, 20, 67940) Without good thoughts there is no peace, and without peace there is no happiness.
('55', 36, 1, 21, 68022) Where a stable minded man sees things clear as daylight, the unstable man distracted by the turmoil of the world is as good as blind.
('55', 36, 1, 22, 68156) On the other hand what is pure in the eyes of the worldly wise looks unclean to and repels the stable minded man.
('55', 36, 1, 23, 68270) Rivers continuously flow into the sea, but the sea remains unmoved; in the same way all sense objects come to the yogi, but he always remains calm like the sea.
('55', 36, 1, 24, 68431) Thus one who abandons all desires, is free from pride and selfishness and behaves as one apart, finds peace.
('55', 36, 1, 25, 68540) This is the condition of a perfect man of God, and he who is established therein even at the final hour attains the beatitude of Brahman.”
('55', 37, 0, 1, 68679) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 37, 1, 2, 68720) CHAPTER III 1
('55', 37, 2, 3, 68734) Monday Morning, November 24, 1930 When Krishna had thus set forth the marks of identification for a sthitaprajna person, Arjuna received the impression that one had only to sit quiet in order to attain such a state, as Krishna had not made the slightest reference to any need for action on his part.
('55', 37, 2, 4, 69034) He therefore asked Krishna: “It seems as if you hold that knowledge is superior to action.
('55', 37, 2, 5, 69125) If so, why are you urging me to this terrible deed and thus confusing my mind?
('55', 37, 2, 6, 69204) Please tell me clearly where my welfare lies.” Krishna replied: “O sinless Arjuna, since the beginning of time seekers have taken one or the other of two different paths.
('55', 37, 2, 7, 69375) In one of these the pride of place is given to knowledge and in the other it is given to action.
('55', 37, 2, 8, 69472) But you will find that freedom from action cannot be attained without action, that wisdom never comes to a man simply on account of his having ceased to act.
('55', 37, 2, 9, 69630) Man does not become perfect merely by renouncing everything.
('55', 37, 2, 10, 69691) Don’t you see that every one of us is doing something or other all the time?
('55', 37, 2, 11, 69768) Our very nature impels us to action.
('55', 37, 2, 12, 69805) Such being the law of nature, one who sits with folded hands but lets his mind dwell on the objects of sense is a fool and may even be called a hypocrite.
('55', 37, 2, 13, 69960) Rather than indulge in such senseless inactivity, is it not better that a man should control the senses, overcome his likes and dislikes, and engage himself in some activity or other without fuss and in a spirit of detachment?
('55', 37, 2, 14, 70187) Do your allotted duty, restraining the organs of sense, for that is better than inaction.
('55', 37, 2, 15, 70277) An idler will only meet his end the sooner for his idleness.
('55', 37, 2, 16, 70338) But while acting, remember that action leads to bondage unless it is performed in a spirit of sacrifice.
('55', 37, 2, 17, 70443) Sacrifice (yajna) means exerting oneself for the benefit of others, in a word, service.

('55', 45, 2, 10, 90914) CHAPTER VI 1
('55', 45, 3, 11, 90927) Tuesday Morning, December 16, 1930 The Lord said: “The man who does his duty without any selfish desire for fruit may be called a sannyasi as well as a yogi.
('55', 45, 3, 12, 91085) But he who abstains from action altogether is only an idler.
('55', 45, 3, 13, 91146) The root of the matter is that one should not allow his mind to flit from one object of desire to another and from that to a third.
('55', 45, 3, 14, 91278) He who would practise yoga, i.e., evenness of temper (samatvam), cannot but perform action.
('55', 45, 3, 15, 91370) The man who has achieved such evenness of temper will be serene, because his mere thoughts are charged with the strength of action.
('55', 45, 3, 16, 91502) A yogi is one who is not attached to the objects of sense or to action and whose mind has ceased to roam restlessly.
('55', 45, 3, 17, 91619) “A man can be saved or ruined by himself alone.

('55', 45, 3, 19, 91740) To one who has subdued his mind, his soul is a friend; while the soul is an enemy for him who has failed to achieve self control.
('55', 45, 3, 20, 91870) The test for self control is that heat and cold, pleasure and pain, honour and dishonour do not disturb one’s inner serenity.
('55', 45, 3, 21, 91996) He is a yogi who is a man of knowledge as well as experience, who is unwavering and master of his senses and to whom gold, stone and earth seem all alike.
('55', 45, 3, 22, 92151) He regards with an equal eye friend and foe, sinner and saint.
('55', 45, 3, 23, 92214) With a view to attaining this state a man should stabilize his mind, divest it of all sensual desires, and meditate in solitude on the Supreme Self.
('55', 45, 3, 24, 92363) It is not enough to practise yogic asanas (postures), etc.
('55', 45, 3, 25, 92422) In order to achieve evenness of temper, one must scrupulously keep the major observances (vratas), such as brahmacharya (chastity) and the like.
('55', 45, 3, 26, 92567) A man who thus takes his place on a firm seat, keeps the observances and concentrates his mind on God, enters into perfect peace.

('55', 46, 0, 1, 92816) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 47
('55', 46, 1, 2, 92861) “This equanimity is not for one who overeats or merely fasts, nor for one who is too much addicted to sleep or to vigils.
('55', 46, 1, 3, 92983) Its seeker has to keep a sense of proportion in all his actions such as eating and drinking, sleeping and keeping awake.
('55', 46, 1, 4, 93104) To overeat one day and fast the next day, to oversleep for a day and keep a vigil the next, to work hard for a day and pass the next in idleness is no characteristic of a yogi.
('55', 46, 1, 5, 93281) The yogi is stable minded at all times, and is without effort free from all desires.
('55', 46, 1, 6, 93366) He is like an unflickering lamp burning in a windless place.
('55', 46, 1, 7, 93427) He is not tossed to and fro by dramatic events on the world stage or by hisown brain waves.
('55', 46, 1, 8, 93519) Such mental poise can be acquired by slow but steady effort.
('55', 46, 1, 9, 93580) The mind is fickle and restless, but it should be gradually stabilized, for a man can have peace of mind only when he is firm of understanding.
('55', 46, 1, 10, 93724) In order thus to stabilize the mind, he should constantly fix it on the soul.
('55', 46, 1, 11, 93802) He will then see all beings in himself and himself in all beings, for he will see Me in all beings and all beings in Me.
('55', 46, 1, 12, 93923) He who is absorbed in Me, and sees Me everywhere ceases to be himself, so that he is at all times attuned to Me irrespective of what he is doing, and is incapable of sin.” Yoga thus described seemed to Arjuna to be a tall order, and he exclaimed: “How is one to achieve such equanimity?
('55', 46, 1, 13, 94210) The human mind is restless like a monkey, and as difficult to control as the wind.
('55', 46, 1, 14, 94293) How is it to be curbed?” The Lord replied: “You are right.
('55', 46, 1, 15, 94352) But if a man earnestly sets about conquering attachment and aversion, yoga will not be difficult for him to practise.
('55', 46, 1, 16, 94470) But it should be clear to you that it is not for one who cannot control his mind.” Then Arjuna posed another question: “Supposing a man has faith, but is lax in his effort and is thus unsuccessful in perfecting himself, what happens to him?
('55', 46, 1, 17, 94711) Is he destroyed like a broken cloud in the sky?” The Lord said: “Such a man of faith is never lost, for no one who takes the right path ever comes to an evil end.
('55', 46, 1, 18, 94874) After death he lives for a time in some celestial world according to his merit and is then reborn on the earth into a holy family.
('55', 46, 1, 19, 95005) But such a birth is difficult to obtain.
('55', 46, 1, 20, 95046) He then regains the mental impressions developed in his former lives, and struggling harder for perfection, reaches the supreme goal.
('55', 46, 1, 21, 95180) Thus making an assiduous effort some attain equanimity soon, while others do so after a number of lives in accordance with the measure of their faith and endeavour.

('55', 47, 1, 3, 95534) Do you therefore become evenminded and a yogi.
('55', 47, 1, 4, 95581) And even among yogis hold him to be the best who dedicates his all to Me and worships Me alone in full faith.”
('55', 47, 2, 5, 95692) [NOTE.] Pranayama (control of breath) and asanas (yogic postures) are referred to appreciatively in this chapter, but we should remember that at the same time the Lord has stressed the need for brahmacharya, i.e., keeping the observances calculated to take us nearer and nearer to God.
('55', 47, 2, 6, 95978) It should be clearly understood that the mere practice of asanas and the like can never take us to the goal of evenmindedness.Asanas and pranayama may be of some slight help in steadying the mind and making it single purposed, provided that they are practised to that end.
('55', 47, 2, 7, 96251) Otherwise they are no better than other methods of physical training.
('55', 47, 2, 8, 96321) They are very useful indeed as physical exercise and I believe that this type of exercise is good for the soul, and may be performed from a bodily standpoint.
('55', 47, 2, 9, 96480) But I have observed that these practices do only harm when indulged in for the acquisition of supernormal powers (siddhi) and the performance of miracles.
('55', 47, 2, 10, 96635) This chapter should be studied as a summary of the teaching in the preceding three chapters.
('55', 47, 2, 11, 96728) It cheers us up in our spiritual struggle.
('55', 47, 2, 12, 96771) We should never be down hearted and give up the endeavour to reach evenness of temper.

('55', 51, 3, 9, 106598) For the yogi in terms of the Gita is neither a dry as dust man of knowledge, nor a devotee carried away by his own enthusiasm, but a selfless performer of action imbued with the spirit of wisdom as well as devotion.

('55', 53, 3, 12, 111580) We learn from this Chapter that devotion (bhakti) means attachment (asakti) to God.
('55', 53, 3, 13, 111664) This is the royal road to the cultivation of a selfless spirit.

('55', 53, 3, 24, 112558) ‘Do not prefer the bitter neem to sugarcane or the glow worm to the sun and the moon.’ The ninth chapter thus shows that renunciation of the fruit of action is impossible without devotion (bhakti).

('55', 54, 1, 2, 113212) CHAPTER X 1
('55', 54, 2, 3, 113224) Monday Morning, January 12, 1931 The Lord said: “Hear once more what I say with a view to the welfare of devotees.
('55', 54, 2, 4, 113339) Even gods and great sages do not know my beginning, for the very simple reason that I am without beginning myself and am the origin of the universe including gods and sages.
('55', 54, 2, 5, 113513) The wise man who knows Me to be unborn and without beginning isliberated from all sins, for when he realizes Me as such and himself as My child or as part and parcel of Me, he overcomes the human liability to sin.
('55', 54, 2, 6, 113727) Ignorance of one’s real nature is the root of sin.
('55', 54, 2, 7, 113778) “As all beings derive from Me, so do the various natures distributed to them, such as for instance forgiveness, truth, joy andsorrow, birth and death, fear and fearlessness.
('55', 54, 2, 8, 113952) Those who know all these to be My glorious manifestations easily become even minded, as they cease to be egotistic.

('55', 57, 1, 2, 120346) CHAPTER XII 1
('55', 57, 2, 3, 120360) Tuesday Morning, November 4, 1930 Arjuna asks the Lord: “Some devotees adore a personal (sakara) God while others worship the Absolute (nirakara).
('55', 57, 2, 4, 120507) Which of these two courses is better?” The Lord replies: “Those who fix their minds on Me (as the One Life in all) with perfect faith and are absorbed in Me are My devotees indeed.
('55', 57, 2, 5, 120688) But those who worship the Absolute and restrain and subdue their senses are equiminded towards all living beings and serve them without looking on some as of a superior and others as of an inferior grade—they also will come to Me.
('55', 57, 2, 6, 120919) Neither of these two classes of devotees is superior to the other.
('55', 57, 2, 7, 120986) But a full realization of the Absolute is almost impossible for an embodied being.
('55', 57, 2, 8, 121069) The Absolute is devoid of all attributes and thus difficult for men even to imagine.
('55', 57, 2, 9, 121154) Therefore they are all worshippers of a personal God, whether they are aware of it or not.
('55', 57, 2, 10, 121245) Do you therefore place your mind in Me (the personal God in the universal form) and offer Me your all.
('55', 57, 2, 11, 121348) If this is not possible, try to restrain the aberrations of the mind; that is to say, by observing the yamas and niyamas, and with the help of pranayama and yogic exercises, obtain control over the mind.
('55', 57, 2, 12, 121552) If even this is beyond your capacity, perform all actions for My sake, so that your delusion will be destroyed, and you will be imbued with the spirit of detachment and devotion.
('55', 57, 2, 13, 121731) If you cannot do even this, renounce the fruits of action, that is, cease to have a desire for the fruits of action, and do the task which is allotted to you.
('55', 57, 2, 14, 121890) A man can never have any say as regards the fruit of his action, as the nature of the fruit is determined by a number of independent factors.
('55', 57, 2, 15, 122032) Be you therefore a mere instrument in My hands.
('55', 57, 2, 16, 122080) I have thus described four methods, none of which is superior to the others.
('55', 57, 2, 17, 122157) You may adopt any one of the four you like.
('55', 57, 2, 18, 122201) It may seem as if the path of knowledge (hearing the doctrine, pondering over it, etc.) is easier to take than that of yamas, niyamas, pranayama, asanas, etc.
('55', 57, 2, 19, 122360) Meditation in worship is easier still and the renunciation of the fruit the easiest of all.
('55', 57, 2, 20, 122452) But the same method is not equally well suited for all.
('55', 57, 2, 21, 122508) And some seekers have to adopt all the four methods, which are inter connected.
('55', 57, 2, 22, 122588) You must become a devotee one way or other; you may take any path that leads

('55', 60, 2, 16, 129426) CHAPTER XIV 1
('55', 60, 3, 17, 129440) Silence Day, January 25, 1932
('55', 60, 4, 18, 129470) The Lord said: “Once more I will teach you that supreme wisdom which enabled sages to reach the highest perfection.
('55', 60, 4, 19, 129586) People who find that wisdom and do their duty accordingly are delivered from the cycle of births and deaths.
('55', 60, 4, 20, 129695) O Arjuna, know Me to be the Father and Mother of all beings.
('55', 60, 4, 21, 129756) The three gunas born of nature, viz., sattva (goodness), rajas (passion) and tamas (ignorance) bind the soul down.
('55', 60, 4, 22, 129871) They may be described respectively as the highest, the middling and the lowest.
('55', 60, 4, 23, 129951) Of these sattva is pure and unsullied and gives light; it is therefore the source of happiness.
('55', 60, 4, 24, 130047) Rajas arises from attachment and craving and makes a man indulge in all manner of activities.
('55', 60, 4, 25, 130141) Tamas is rooted in ignorance and delusion and makes one negligent and indolent.
('55', 60, 4, 26, 130221) In short, sattva makes for happiness, rajas for restlessness and tamas for sloth.
('55', 60, 4, 27, 130303) Sometimes sattva prevails, overpowering rajas and tamas; at other times rajas prevails,

('55', 61, 0, 1, 130508) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 61, 1, 2, 130549) overpowering sattva and tamas; at still other times tamas prevails, overpowering sattva and rajas.
('55', 61, 1, 3, 130648) When the light of wisdom shines through all the activities of the body it may be known that sattva is increasing.
('55', 61, 1, 4, 130762) Where greed, bustle, unrest and competition are observed, rajas is the ruler.
('55', 61, 1, 5, 130840) And the predominance of tamas is characterized by ignorance, sloth and delusion.
('55', 61, 1, 6, 130921) If sattva prevails in a man’s life, he is born in the sinless worlds of the great sages after death.
('55', 61, 1, 7, 131022) If rajas dominates his life, he is born among those who are attached to action.
('55', 61, 1, 8, 131102) And if tamas is the ruling principle, he returns to the womb of the senseless.
('55', 61, 1, 9, 131181) The fruit of sattvik action is purity, while the fruit of rajas is pain and the fruit of tamas is ignorance.
('55', 61, 1, 10, 131290) A sattvik man rises to the higher regions; a rajasik person remains in this world, while a tamasik individual sinks to the underworld.
('55', 61, 1, 11, 131425) When a man perceives no doer of action other than these qualities and knows Me who am beyond them he enters into My nature.
('55', 61, 1, 12, 131549) When the dweller in the body has overcome the three qualities from which all bodies arise, he is freed from birth and death, old age and pain and drinks the nectar of eternal life.” On hearing that one who transcends the qualities makes such great progress on the pilgrim’s path, Arjuna asked: “What are the marks of such perfection?
('55', 61, 1, 13, 131883) How does such a perfect being conduct himself?
('55', 61, 1, 14, 131930) And how does he cross over the qualities?”The Lord replied: “A man is said to have risen above the qualities when he is not angry if the light and knowledge of sattva or the activity and bustle of rajas or the delusion and ignorance of tamas are there and is not wishful if they are not.
('55', 61, 1, 15, 132218) He sits like one who is unconcerned and is not disturbed by the qualities.

('55', 61, 1, 18, 132458) The pleasant and the unpleasant are alike to him.
('55', 61, 1, 19, 132508) He is unaffected by either praise or blame.
('55', 61, 1, 20, 132552) He is the same in honour and evil fame.
('55', 61, 1, 21, 132592) He is alike to friend and foe.
('55', 61, 1, 22, 132623) And he has abandoned all undertakings.

('55', 61, 1, 24, 132763) What I have described is the state of a perfect man.

('55', 62, 4, 6, 133490) The Lord said: “This world is like an ashvattha (sacred fig) tree with roots above and branches below and with the Vedic hymns as its leaves.

('55', 62, 4, 8, 133669) The branches of this cosmic tree nourished by the qualities shoot to heaven and sink to earth.
('55', 62, 4, 9, 133764) Sense objects are its sprouts.
('55', 62, 4, 10, 133795) It is these things of the senses which bind the soul with the bonds of karma in the world of men.
('55', 62, 4, 11, 133893) The real nature of this tree cannot be known here, nor its beginning, nor end, nor foundation.
('55', 62, 4, 12, 133988) “This strongly rooted cosmic tree should be cut down with the weapon of non co operation, so that the soul may rise to a higher world from which there is no return [to the world of mortals].
('55', 62, 4, 13, 134179) With this end in view a man should engage himself in the constant worshipof the Ancient of Days, from whom all this activity (the cosmic process) seems to flow.
('55', 62, 4, 14, 134340) The wise man who is free from pride and delusion, victorious over the vice of attachment and devoted to the Supreme Soul, who is free from cravings and to whom pleasure and pain are alike—that wise man reaches the state which is beyond all change, and which does not need to be illumined by the sun, the moon or fire.
('55', 62, 4, 15, 134658) That is my Supreme abode.
('55', 62, 4, 16, 134684) “An eternal part of Myself tansformed into the individual soul in this world draws to itself the senses including the mind which reside in matter.
('55', 62, 4, 17, 134831) When the soul enters the body or leaves it, it takes these senses with it even as the wind carries fragrance from its places.
('55', 62, 4, 18, 134957) It enjoys sense objects with the help of the ear, the eye, the senses of touch and taste, the nose and the mind.
('55', 62, 4, 19, 135070) The ignorant cannot recognize it as it goes or stays or enjoys itself under the influence of the qualities, but the sages see it [with the eye of wisdom].
('55', 62, 4, 20, 135225) Striving yogis see it living in their own bodies, but those who have not achieved evenness of temper cannot see it even if they try.
('55', 62, 4, 21, 135358) “The light of the sun that illumines all the world, that which is in the moon and in fire—

('55', 63, 1, 2, 135654) know that all that light is Mine.
('55', 63, 1, 3, 135688) Permeating the soil 1 I sustain all living beings.
('55', 63, 1, 4, 135739) I become the sapproducing moon and feed the plants.
('55', 63, 1, 5, 135791) Becoming the fire of life in the bodies of all living creatures and being united with the life breaths, I digest the four kinds of food.

('55', 63, 1, 11, 136251) The perishable is all beings; and the imperishable is I who am the same for ever.

('55', 63, 3, 18, 136869) February 7, I 932 The Lord said: “I will now point out the distinction between the divine and the demoniacal natures.
('55', 63, 3, 19, 136987) I have earlier described at length what is meant by divine nature but I will repeat its distinctive features.
('55', 63, 3, 20, 137097) Among the signs of the divine are fearlessness, purity of heart, wisdom, evenness of temper, self control, alms giving, sacrifice, study of the scriptures, austerity, straightforwardness, non violence, truth, freedom from anger, renunciation, peacefulness, not speaking evil of others, compassion to all living beings, absence of greed, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness, vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, internal as well as external, freedom from malice and pride.
('55', 63, 3, 21, 137579) “Among the signs of the demoniacal are hypocrisy, arrogance, conceit, anger, cruelty and ignorance.
('55', 63, 3, 22, 137679) “The divine nature leads to liberation while the demoniacal
