('55', 65, 0, 1, 139990) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 65, 1, 2, 140031) CHAPTER XVII 1
('55', 65, 2, 3, 140046) February 14, 1932 Arjuna asked: “What happens to those who serve in faith, neglecting the prevailing code of conduct?” The Lord replied: “There are three kinds of faith, characterized by sattva, rajas or tames as the case may be.
('55', 65, 2, 4, 140276) As is a man’s faith, so is he.
('55', 65, 2, 5, 140307) “ Sattvik men worship the gods; rajasik men worship demigods and demons; and tamasik men worship the spirits of the dead.
('55', 65, 2, 6, 140429) “The nature of a man’s faith cannot be ascertained offhand.
('55', 65, 2, 7, 140489) In order to assess it correctly, one must know the precise nature of his food, austerity, sacrifice and alms giving.
('55', 65, 2, 8, 140606) “Foods which make for long life and increase the vital force, energy, strength and health are said to be sattvik.
('55', 65, 2, 9, 140720) Rajasik foods are violently bitter, sour, hot or pungent and give rise to disease and aches and pains.
('55', 65, 2, 10, 140823) And cooked food which is stale or gives out a bad smell and the leavings of others are said to be tamasik.
('55', 65, 2, 11, 140930) “The sacrifice which is offered as a matter of duty without expecting a reward and with mental concentration is said to be sattvik.
('55', 65, 2, 12, 141062) A rajasik sacrifice is that in which a reward is desired and which is offered for outward show.
('55', 65, 2, 13, 141158) And a tamasik sacrifice is one in which scriptural rules are disobeyed, no eatables or alms are given away and no hymns are chanted.
('55', 65, 2, 14, 141291) “Honouring the saintly purity, brahmacharya and non violence constitute austerity of the body.
('55', 65, 2, 15, 141386) Truthful, pleasant and beneficial speech as well as a study of the scriptures is austerity of speech.
('55', 65, 2, 16, 141488) Andcheerfulness, gentleness, silence, self control and purity of motive—these are called austerity of the mind.
('55', 65, 2, 17, 141600) Such austerity of the mind, body and speech as is practised without desire of fruit by men with an evenness of temper is said to be sattvik.
('55', 65, 2, 18, 141741) Austerity practised for ostentation and with a view to gaining honour is said to be rajasik.
('55', 65, 2, 19, 141834) And austerity done by obstinate fools with self torture or with the object of hurting others is said to be tamasik.
('55', 65, 2, 20, 141950) “A gift ‘made in due place, due time and to a fit recipient’ without expecting a reward and with a feeling that it is right for a man to give is said to be sattvik.
('55', 65, 2, 21, 142115) A gift made grudgingly with a view to
('55', 65, 3, 22, 142153) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11/15 2 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11/15 2 1932
('55', 66, 0, 1, 142270) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 67
('55', 66, 1, 2, 142315) getting something in return is regarded as rajasik.
('55', 66, 1, 3, 142367) And the gift which is given in a contemptuous spirit, and without honour done to the recipient and without considering the proper time and place for it is said to be tamasik.
('55', 66, 1, 4, 142542) “Brahman is designated in the Vedas as Om tat sat.
('55', 66, 1, 5, 142593) Therefore men of faith pronounce the sacred syllable ‘Om’ when they commence any rite of sacrifice, alms giving or austerity.
('55', 66, 1, 6, 142719) This single syllable stands for Brahman.
('55', 66, 1, 7, 142760) Tat means that.
('55', 66, 1, 8, 142776) And sat means satya, beneficient.
('55', 66, 1, 9, 142810) That is to say, God is one, He alone is, He alone is truth and the benefactor of the world.
('55', 66, 1, 10, 142902) He who offers a sacrifice, makes gifts or practises austerity with a realization of this truth and in a spirit of dedication is a man of sattvik faith.
('55', 66, 1, 11, 143054) And he is free from blame if he knowingly or unknowingly does something different from the correct procedure in the spirit of dedication.
('55', 66, 1, 12, 143192) But acts undertaken in the absence of such a spirit are said to be performed without faith and therefore are asat (unreal).”
('55', 66, 2, 13, 143317) CHAPTER XVIII 1
('55', 66, 3, 14, 143333) February 21, 1932
('55', 66, 4, 15, 143351) Even after he had pondered over the teaching in all the previous Chapters, there was still a doubt in Arjuna’s mind.
('55', 66, 4, 16, 143468) So he said: “The sannyasa of the Gita seems to be different from renunciation as currently understood.
('55', 66, 4, 17, 143571) Are sannyasa and tyaga really different?” While resolving Arjuna’s doubt in answer to this question, the Lord summarized the Gita doctrine in a concise manner: “Some actions are motivated by desire.
('55', 66, 4, 18, 143770) Various activities are indulged in by men with a view to fulfilling various desires.
('55', 66, 4, 19, 143855) These are called kamya actions.
('55', 66, 4, 20, 143887) Then again there are certain necessary and natural actions such as breathing, eating, drinking, Iying down, sitting, etc., with aview to keep the body [a fit instrument of service].
('55', 66, 4, 21, 144069) And thirdly there are actions done with a view to serving others.
('55', 66, 4, 22, 144135) Giving up kamya actions is sannyasa, and renunciation of fruits of all actions is tyaga as recommended to you all along.
('55', 66, 4, 23, 144256) “Some people maintain that there is evil, no matter how little, in all actions whatever.
('55', 66, 4, 24, 144345) Even so, a man must not give up actions done with a view to yajna (sacrifice), that is to say, the service of others.
('55', 66, 4, 25, 144463) Alms giving and austerity are included in yajna.
('55', 66, 4, 26, 144512) But even while
('55', 66, 5, 27, 144527) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 19/21 2 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 19/21 2 1932
('55', 67, 0, 1, 144644) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 67, 1, 2, 144685) serving others, a man should act in a spirit of detachment.
('55', 67, 1, 3, 144745) Otherwise his activity is likely to be mixed up with evil.
('55', 67, 1, 4, 144804) “Renunciation owing to ignorance of duties that must be done is said to be inspired by tamas.
('55', 67, 1, 5, 144898) Giving up any action merely because it involves physical suffering is said to be rajasik.
('55', 67, 1, 6, 144988) But service rendered to others because of a feeling that it must be done and without the desire for the fruits is real sattvik tyaga.
('55', 67, 1, 7, 145122) In this tyaga therefore there is no giving up of all actions, but only of the fruit of duties that must be done, and of course of other, that is, kamya actions.
('55', 67, 1, 8, 145283) When a [wise] man acts in such a selfless spirit, all his doubts are dispelled, his motives are pure and he has no thought of personal comfort and discomfort.
('55', 67, 1, 9, 145442) “He who does not abandon the fruits of action must enjoy or put up with the natural consequences of his own acts, and is thus a bondslave for ever.
('55', 67, 1, 10, 145590) But he who gives up the fruits of action achieves freedom.
('55', 67, 1, 11, 145649) “And why should a man feel attachment for action?
('55', 67, 1, 12, 145699) It is idle for anybody to imagine that he himself is a doer.
('55', 67, 1, 13, 145760) There are five causes for the accomplishment of all actions, namely, this body, the doer, the various instruments, efforts, and last but by no means the least, providence.
('55', 67, 1, 14, 145932) “Realizing this, a man should give up pride.
('55', 67, 1, 15, 145977) He who does something without egoism may be said to be not doing it in spite of his doing it, for he is not bound by his action.
('55', 67, 1, 16, 146106) Of a humble man who has reduced himself to zero it may be said that he does not kill though he kills.
('55', 67, 1, 17, 146208) This does not mean that the man in spite of his humility may kill and yet be unaffected by the killing.
('55', 67, 1, 18, 146312) For no occasion can arise for such a man to indulge in violence.
('55', 67, 1, 19, 146377) “There are three things that inspire action: knowledge, the object of knowledge and the knower.
('55', 67, 1, 20, 146473) And there are three constituents of action: the organ, the deed and the doer.
('55', 67, 1, 21, 146551) The thing to be done is the object of knowledge; the method of doing it is knowledge and he who knows it is the knower.
('55', 67, 1, 22, 146671) After he has thus received an impulse toaction, he performs an action in which the senses serve as instruments.
('55', 67, 1, 23, 146783) Thought is thus translated into action.
('55', 67, 1, 24, 146823) “That by which a man is able ‘To see one changeless Life in all the lives’ and to realize the essential unity that underlies all diversities is sattvik knowledge.
('55', 67, 1, 25, 146986) In rajasik knowledge one holds that there are different souls in different creatures, while in tamasik knowledge a
('55', 68, 0, 1, 147101) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 69
('55', 68, 1, 2, 147146) man does not know a thing and imagines that everything is mixed up without rhyme or reason.
('55', 68, 1, 3, 147238) “Similarly there are three kinds of action.
('55', 68, 1, 4, 147282) Action in which there are no likes and dislikes and no desire for personal gains is sattvik.
('55', 68, 1, 5, 147375) That in which there are desires for enjoyment, egoism and restlessness is rajasik action.
('55', 68, 1, 6, 147465) And tamasik action is one in which no thought at all is given to personal capacity and consequential injury or violence and which is undertaken through delusion.
('55', 68, 1, 7, 147627) “So also there are three classes of doers.
('55', 68, 1, 8, 147670) Of course having understood the action it could not be difficult to know the doer.
('55', 68, 1, 9, 147753) A sattvik doer is free from attachment and egoism and yet firm and enterprising and is neither elated by success nor worried by failure.
('55', 68, 1, 10, 147890) A rajasik doer is impassioned, greedy and violent, ‘slave by turns of sorrow and of joy’ and of course desires to obtain the fruit of his actions.
('55', 68, 1, 11, 148037) And a tamasik doer is unsystematic, procrastinating, obstinate, malicious and indolent; in short, without an iota of self culture.
('55', 68, 1, 12, 148168) “Intellect, firmness and happiness also are said to be of three kinds.
('55', 68, 1, 13, 148239) “The sattvik intellect is able properly to distinguish between action and non action,
('55', 68, 2, 14, 148325) What must be done, and what must not be done, What should be feared, and what should not be feared, What binds and what emancipates the soul.
('55', 68, 2, 15, 148467) The rajasik intellect tries to draw these distinctions but generally fails to do so correctly, while the tamasik intellect ‘looks upon wrong as right and sees all things contrariwise of truth.’ “Firmness is the power of taking up some thing and sticking to it through thick and thin.
('55', 68, 2, 16, 148751) It is more or less inherent in all things; otherwise the world could not subsist for a single moment.
('55', 68, 2, 17, 148853) Firmness is sattvik when there is a constantly maintained balance between the activities of the mind, the vital airs (pranas) and the senses.
('55', 68, 2, 18, 148995) The firmness by which a man holds fast to duty, pleasure and wealth from attachment and with a view to personal advantage is rajasik.
('55', 68, 2, 19, 149129) And firmness is tamasik,
('55', 68, 3, 20, 149154) wherewith the fool Cleaves to his sloth, his sorrow and his fears, His vanity and despair.
('55', 68, 3, 21, 149245) “ Sattvik happiness is the
('55', 68, 4, 22, 149272) pleasure that endures, Banishing pain for aye, bitter at first
('55', 69, 0, 1, 149335) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 69, 1, 2, 149376) As poison to the soul, but afterwards Sweet as the taste of amrit.
('55', 69, 1, 3, 149443) It arises from true self knowledge.
('55', 69, 1, 4, 149479) “ Rajasik happiness arises from sensual enjoyment.
('55', 69, 2, 5, 149530) Sweet As amrit is its first taste, but its last Bitter as poison.
('55', 69, 2, 6, 149596) “And tamasik happiness is that
('55', 69, 3, 7, 149627) which springs From sloth and sleep and foolishness.
('55', 69, 4, 8, 149679) —EDWIN ARNOLD “This threefold classification is thus applicable to all things.
('55', 69, 4, 9, 149758) The duties of the four varnas are fixed by reason of the dominance or recession of the qualities planted in each.
('55', 69, 4, 10, 149872) “A Brahmin’s conduct is characterized by calmness, self discipline, austerity, purity, forgiveness, uprightness, wisdom, experience and faith in God.
('55', 69, 4, 11, 150022) The characteristics of a Kshatriya are valour, splendour, firmness, resourcefulness, not flying from battle, open handedness and leadership.
('55', 69, 4, 12, 150163) A Vaishya’s task is ‘to till the ground, tend cattle, venture trade’, and service is the Sudra’s work.
('55', 69, 4, 13, 150266) This is not to say that a member of any one of these classes may not be endowed with qualities characteristic of other classes or is not entitled to cultivate them in himself.
('55', 69, 4, 14, 150442) But qualities and work as mentioned above serve as signs for the recognition of a man’s varna.
('55', 69, 4, 15, 150537) If the qualities and tasks of each varna are recognized, there is no undesirable competition or feeling of hatred among them.
('55', 69, 4, 16, 150663) There is no question here of high and low.
('55', 69, 4, 17, 150706) But if each does his duty selflessly according to his nature, he will reach perfection.
('55', 69, 4, 18, 150794) Therefore one’s own duty, though it appears to be valueless, is better than the duty of another which seems to be easy.
('55', 69, 4, 19, 150914) A man may remain free from sin when he performs the task naturally allotted to him, as he is then free from selfish desires; the very wish to do something else arises from selfishness.
('55', 69, 4, 20, 151099) For the rest, all actions are clouded by defects as fire by smoke.
('55', 69, 4, 21, 151166) But the natural duty is done without desire for its fruit, and thus loses its binding force.
('55', 69, 4, 22, 151259) “The calm yogi who has been sanctified by thus performing his own duty, who has his mind under control, who has given up the five sense objects, who has overcome likes and dislikes, who lives in solitude, i.e., whose eyes are turned inward, who achieves mastery of his mind, body and speech by abstemiousness, who is ever conscious
('55', 70, 0, 1, 151591) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 71
('55', 70, 1, 2, 151636) of the living presence of God, and who has given up pride, desire, anger, acquisitiveness and the like—that yogi is fit to be united with Brahman.
('55', 70, 1, 3, 151783) He is equi minded towards all men.
('55', 70, 1, 4, 151818) He neither rejoices nor indulges in grief.
('55', 70, 1, 5, 151861) Such a devotee has true knowledge of God and is absorbed in Him.
('55', 70, 1, 6, 151926) Thus taking refuge in Me, he gains the eternal place.
('55', 70, 1, 7, 151980) “Therefore dedicate your all to Me, regard Me as the supreme object of your love, and with discrimination, fix your mind on Me.
('55', 70, 1, 8, 152108) As you do this, you will overcome all difficulties.
('55', 70, 1, 9, 152160) But if out of egoism you do not listen to Me, you will perish.
('55', 70, 1, 10, 152223) The one thing needful is that, abandoning all conflicting views, you should come to Me alone for shelter, and thus be freed from sin.
('55', 70, 1, 11, 152357) “Do not tell this truth to anyone who is not a devotee, austere in life, and hating Me, does not wish to listen.
('55', 70, 1, 12, 152470) But one who communicates this great secret to My devotees will surely come to Me in virtue of his devotion.” After having thus reported to Dhritarashtra the dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna, Sanjaya said: “Where there is Krishna, the prince of yoga, and Arjuna with his bow and arrows, there are prosperity, victory, happiness and fundamental morality.” [NOTE.] Krishna to whom the epithet ‘prince of yoga’ has here been applied means pure knowledge based on spiritual experience, and by referring to Arjuna as an archer it is suggested that where there is action in accordance with such knowledge, the doer obtains every wish that is not contrary to lofty morals.

('55', 71, 2, 23, 154700) Such faith can do no harm in any case.

('55', 79, 10, 31, 172125) His greatness lay in the fact that as soon as he realized his
('55', 79, 11, 32, 172187) 1 Chhotubhai, Kunvarji Mehta’s son
('55', 80, 0, 1, 172222) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 81
('55', 80, 1, 2, 172267) mistake, he confessed it and corrected it.
('55', 80, 1, 3, 172310) Moreover, there were so many changes in his way of life that one should also take into account the time when he expressed a particular opinion.
('55', 80, 1, 4, 172454) In any case, in the matter of husband wife relationship, I myself am definitely of the opinion that the consent of both should be necessary for their union and not for living apart.
('55', 80, 1, 5, 172636) If that were not so, both would ordinarily remain in a fallen state.
('55', 80, 1, 6, 172705) It happens only in rare cases that both wake up at thesame time and remain awake together.

('55', 82, 4, 6, 175515) 65. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA
('55', 82, 5, 7, 175549) February 26, 1932
('55', 82, 6, 8, 175567) BHAGWANJI, I got your letter.
('55', 82, 6, 9, 175597) I did reply to you.
('55', 82, 6, 10, 175617) 1 It is certainly possible to acquire control over the sense organs.
('55', 82, 6, 11, 175686) The Shastras proclaim in the clearest words that such control is difficult, but they were composed to help people to acquire it.
('55', 82, 6, 12, 175815) It becomes possible through hard practice and the cultivation of disinterestedness.
('55', 82, 6, 13, 175899) Spiritual development and self realization go hand in hand.
('55', 82, 6, 14, 175959) The remedy for your mental agitation lies in you, and rest also depends on you.
('55', 82, 6, 15, 176039) I see many in jails who do no work, but all of them appear agitated.
('55', 82, 6, 16, 176108) Rest for the body is not true rest.
('55', 82, 6, 17, 176144) The sun that takes no rest even for a moment is always fresh.
('55', 82, 6, 18, 176206) The Lord says that, though He works ceaselessly without rest and without one moment of relaxation, He is the abode of peace.
('55', 82, 6, 19, 176331) You should, therefore, seek everything within yourself.At this time when the inmates of the Ashram are doing real work and not merely play acting, you find it uninteresting.
('55', 82, 6, 20, 176505) Though there are numerous weaknesses in the Ashram, I describe its work as real because it is not a shop doing business but a means of serving the world and a sincere attempt in that direction to the best of our ability.
('55', 82, 6, 21, 176726) For anybody who understands the things aright, the Ashram activities are in truth rest from work.

('55', 85, 1, 2, 179494) 71. LETTER TO ESTHER MENON February 28, 1932
('55', 85, 2, 3, 179539) MY DEAR CHILD, I was delighted to have your letter again and the unexpected scribble from Nani 1. I see you have a cosmopolitan company 2. I only hope this does not give you more than your health can manage.
('55', 85, 2, 4, 179747) No, the Gita does not teach differently.
('55', 85, 2, 5, 179788) What it does teach is that all our acts must be natural and spontaneous even when unconscious.
('55', 85, 2, 6, 179883) When they are so, there is no thought of reward or result.
('55', 85, 2, 7, 179942) There is, therefore, in pure love no giving and no taking.
('55', 85, 2, 8, 180001) Put in another way there is no giving on earth without taking.
('55', 85, 2, 9, 180064) Love gives because it must; it is its nature.
('55', 85, 2, 10, 180110) It therefore does not calculate whether there is a corresponding gain.
('55', 85, 2, 11, 180181) It is unconscious of the giving and more so of the taking.
('55', 85, 2, 12, 180240) Love is its own reward.
('55', 85, 2, 13, 180264) When there is that ineffable love, there is a joy which is above all the so called joys we think we experience from outward circumstances.
('55', 85, 2, 14, 180403) It is that joy I want you to possess.
('55', 85, 2, 15, 180441) There was a time when you thought, I thought, you had it.
('55', 85, 2, 16, 180499) But you had not then gone through the fire.
('55', 85, 2, 17, 180543) The joy that will surely be yours one day will come out of the purifying richness of that fire.
('55', 85, 2, 18, 180639) It will steal over you when it does come.
('55', 85, 2, 19, 180681) May it come soon.
('55', 85, 2, 20, 180699) We are both well.

('55', 86, 3, 8, 181528) 73. LETTER TO ABBAS
('55', 86, 4, 9, 181548) February 28, 1932
('55', 86, 6, 10, 181566) In spite of his struggles a man is carried away by passion, since to destroy it completely requires an immense effort.
('55', 86, 6, 11, 181685) Some things require comparatively less effort and some others require a much greater effort.
('55', 86, 6, 12, 181778) We require less effort to spin yarn of 10 or 20 counts, but none has progressed so far as to spin yarn of 200 counts.
('55', 86, 6, 13, 181896) To do that requires better equipment and a far greater effort.
('55', 86, 6, 14, 181959) We do know that they spun yarn of 200 counts in Bengal a hundred years ago.
('55', 86, 6, 15, 182035) If different degrees of effort are required in such a small matter as spinning, it is bound to be so in acquiring freedom from passion.
('55', 86, 6, 16, 182171) Knowing this, the more we meet with failure the greater should our efforts be.
('55', 86, 6, 17, 182250) Some mountaineers have been attempting to reach the top of the Himalayas.
('55', 86, 6, 18, 182324) But none has succeeded so far.
('55', 86, 6, 19, 182355) Our attempt is for a still higher cause, and it knows no failure.
('55', 86, 7, 20, 182421) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 6315. Also C.W. 8951. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('55', 86, 8, 21, 182528) 74. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('55', 86, 9, 22, 182564) February 28, 1932
('55', 86, 10, 23, 182582) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, I am waiting for your reply to my letter 1. Meanwhile, I congratulate those of you who have undertaken to help in the kitchen.
('55', 86, 10, 24, 182730) Some of you are old enough to be able, if they wish, to assume the whole responsibility for it.
('55', 86, 10, 25, 182826) The fact that we experience difficulties
('55', 86, 11, 26, 182867) 1Vide “Letter to Ashram Boys and Girls”, 21 2 1932
('55', 87, 0, 1, 182918) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 87, 1, 2, 182959) particularly in the kitchen is due entirely to our shortcomings.
('55', 87, 1, 3, 183024) I list below for your information as many rules as I can think of.
('55', 87, 1, 4, 183091) If you follow them, you will not find the least difficulty in running the kitchen.
('55', 87, 1, 5, 183174) 1. Never lose your temper whatever happens, whether something is spoilt or broken.
('55', 87, 1, 6, 183257) Never be impatient.
('55', 87, 1, 7, 183277) Never worry about anything.
('55', 87, 1, 8, 183305) Find out the cause of the trouble and remove it.
('55', 87, 1, 9, 183354) 2. If a co worker does not finish his work or is lazy about it do not get irritated with him, but take upon yourself the additional burden.
('55', 87, 1, 10, 183494) 3. Do thoroughly and as perfectly as you can whatever you do.
('55', 87, 1, 11, 183556) 4. Never play with one another while in the kitchen.
('55', 87, 1, 12, 183609) Do not hit anybody even in jest.
('55', 87, 1, 13, 183642) 5. The best thing is not to speak a word unless necessary.
('55', 87, 1, 14, 183701) If anybody cannot control himself, he may talk in low whispers and make harmless and innocent jokes.
('55', 87, 1, 15, 183802) However, everybody should gradually form the habit of speaking nothing at all.
('55', 87, 1, 16, 183881) 6. If you do talk, do not indulge in malicious criticism of one another or back biting.
('55', 87, 1, 17, 183969) 7. It is enough for small boys to wear only tucked up dhotis in the kitchen.
('55', 87, 1, 18, 184046) The girls also, when sitting, should tuck up their skirts behind and wear only jackets above them.
('55', 87, 1, 19, 184145) It is not necessary for them to wear the half sari in the kitchen.
('55', 87, 1, 20, 184212) This saves cloth and minimizes the danger of clothes catching fire.
('55', 87, 1, 21, 184280) If anybody wears a shirt, the sleeves should be tucked up at the elbow.
('55', 87, 1, 22, 184352) 8. When anybody feels the urge to sneeze, he should hold the kerchief over his mouth before sneezing, so that he does not blow spittle from the mouth.
('55', 87, 1, 23, 184503) Use tie kerchief for blowing the nose and, if you perspire, wipe the drops with it.
('55', 87, 1, 24, 184587) One ought not to let the drops fall into anything.
('55', 87, 1, 25, 184638) This means that everyone must carry a handkerchief.
('55', 87, 1, 26, 184690) 9. For wiping the utensils, etc., there should be a separate towel in the kitchen and it should be washed everyday with soap.
('55', 87, 1, 27, 184816) 10. Everyone working in the kitchen should take special care to keep his nails clean.
('55', 87, 1, 28, 184902) They should be trimmed regularly.
('55', 87, 1, 29, 184936) If there is still any dirt under them, it should be removed with pointed straw.
('55', 87, 1, 30, 185016) 11. No one should touch or taste any cooked item for sampling it.
('55', 87, 1, 31, 185082) 12. If, to ascertain whether a vegetable or some similar dish has
('55', 88, 0, 1, 185148) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 89
('55', 88, 1, 2, 185193) been properly salted, it has to be tasted, the leader of the boys may take some in a spoon and taste it and, after doing so, immediately wash the spoon clean.
('55', 88, 1, 3, 185352) 13. If some special dish or dishes have to be cooked for a sick person or a person who is observing a vow, do not regard this as a burden but cook the thing cheerfully.
('55', 88, 1, 4, 185521) Experience will show that, if the time table for the various jobs has been strictly followed, no burden will be felt at all.
('55', 88, 1, 5, 185646) 14. Make it a point to arrive at the kitchen punctually at the time appointed for you.
('55', 88, 1, 6, 185733) Know that every minute matters, so that you should arrive two minutes earlier but never a minute later.
('55', 88, 1, 7, 185837) 15. If you have no work in the kitchen, do not remain there to gossip or just to look at the others working.
('55', 88, 1, 8, 185946) 16. The kitchen should be kept clean all the time.
('55', 88, 1, 9, 185997) All the things should be in their proper places.
('55', 88, 1, 10, 186046) After one’s job is done, one should not leave without arranging the things in order.
('55', 88, 1, 11, 186131) In addition to these, you may introduce other rules that you may think of.
('55', 88, 1, 12, 186206) If you think that any of those given by me should be dropped, you may drop them with the consent of the elders.
('55', 88, 1, 13, 186318) But scrupulously follow whatever rules you lay down.
('55', 88, 1, 14, 186371) Everyone should make a copy of the rules and keep it with him.
('55', 88, 1, 15, 186434) I have often felt that the kitchen provides a means for us to test how far we practise the teaching of the Gita.
('55', 88, 2, 16, 186547) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] I am not writing a separate letter to the women today, since this one is already longer than I had intended it to be, and, moreover, such a letter should do quite well for them also.
('55', 88, 3, 17, 186756) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II.
('55', 88, 3, 18, 186801) Also C.W. 8955. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('55', 90, 1, 2, 188288) 77. DEATH, A FRIEND 1
('55', 90, 2, 3, 188310) February 29, 1932
('55', 90, 3, 4, 188328) There was once a wise man, named Socrates, who lived in Athens.
('55', 90, 3, 5, 188392) His unconventional ideas, which, however, spread love of truth and goodness, displeased the authorities, and he was sentenced to death.
('55', 90, 3, 6, 188528) In that country people were in those days sometimes sentenced to die by drinking poison.
('55', 90, 3, 7, 188617) Like Mirabai, Socrates was asked to drink a cup of poison.
('55', 90, 3, 8, 188676) Our purpose here is to discuss the substance of the concluding words of Socrates’s defence at the time of his trial.
('55', 90, 3, 9, 188793) We can all derive a moral from it.
('55', 90, 3, 10, 188828) Let us call Socrates by the name Sukrit.
('55', 90, 3, 11, 188869) The Arabs knew him as Sokrat.
('55', 90, 3, 12, 188899) This is what Sukrit said: ‘It is my unshakable faith that no harm comes to a good man either in this world or the next.
('55', 90, 3, 13, 189019) God never forsakes good men and their friends.
('55', 90, 3, 14, 189066) I also believe that nobody ever dies before his time.
('55', 90, 3, 15, 189120) I don’t look upon the sentence of death as a punishment.
('55', 90, 3, 16, 189177) The time has come for me to die and be delivered from the sufferings of this life.
('55', 90, 3, 17, 189260) That is why you have condemned me to die by drinking poison.
('55', 90, 3, 18, 189321) I am sure that my good lies in that.
('55', 90, 3, 19, 189358) I, therefore, bear no anger against my prosecutors or against those who have condemned me.
('55', 90, 3, 20, 189449) They may not have meant well by me, but they can do me no harm either.
('55', 90, 3, 21, 189520) ‘I have one request to make to the council of elders.
('55', 90, 3, 22, 189574) If my sons forsake the path of goodness and follow that of evil, if they become lovers of wealth, punish them as you have punished me.
('55', 90, 3, 23, 189709) Punish them also if they become hypocrites and try to show themselves other than what they are.
('55', 90, 3, 24, 189805) If you do so, my sons and I will believe that you have acted justly.’ This is a request of Sukrit in regard to his sons.
('55', 90, 3, 25, 189926) The elders of the city who had assembled to pass judgment on him, did not know the law of non violence.
('55', 90, 3, 26, 190030) He, therefore, made the foregoing request and thereby warned his sons and told them what he expected of them, and also rebuked the elders gently for punishing him for doing good.
('55', 90, 3, 27, 190209) By suggesting to his sons that they should follow in his footsteps, he told them in effect that the path which he had shown to the citizens of
('55', 90, 4, 28, 190352) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”; vide the following item.
('55', 91, 0, 1, 190433) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 91, 1, 2, 190474) Athens was also meant for them, and even went to the extent of saying that, if they did not follow that path, they should be treated as deserving punishment.
('55', 91, 1, 3, 190632) I had decided to let this week be blank.
('55', 91, 1, 4, 190673) But I could not reconcile myself to the idea.
('55', 91, 1, 5, 190719) Glancing at the books, I saw Socrates’s speech.
('55', 91, 1, 6, 190767) I opened the book, intending to send something from it, and my eyes fell on the world famous passage in it which I have summarized above.

('55', 94, 5, 11, 196031) March 1, 1932
('55', 94, 6, 12, 196045) DEAR SISTER, I have been robbing you of lots of honey these days.
('55', 94, 6, 13, 196111) Both of us have to take it frequently with warm water, and so two bottles get exhausted in nine or ten days.
('55', 94, 6, 14, 196220) If you experience difficulty in getting honey, please let me know.
('55', 94, 6, 15, 196287) Sometimes the honey is mixed with dirt and sometimes there are pieces of cork in it.

('55', 94, 6, 18, 196608) I, therefore, eat only the honey which is collected scientifically.
('55', 94, 6, 19, 196676) Such honey is now collected in our country.
('55', 94, 6, 20, 196720) Please inquire how the honey which you send is collected and let me know.
('55', 94, 7, 21, 196794) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('55', 95, 9, 20, 197911) March 1, 1932
('55', 95, 10, 21, 197925) RUKMINI,
('55', 95, 11, 22, 197934) I got your letter.
('55', 95, 11, 23, 197953) It is my habit to give to children names which suggest the qualities we wish them to have.
('55', 95, 11, 24, 198044) Following that practice, I suggest Gopal (lal or das) or Madhav (lal or das).
('55', 95, 11, 25, 198122) Both are names of the Lord whose pet (lal) or servant (das) I would like myself or anybody else to be.
('55', 95, 11, 26, 198225) Further, the word Gopal has two beautiful meanings: Go means a cow or a sense organ, so that the name would also signify one who keeps cows or one who controls the senses.
('55', 95, 11, 27, 198397) Madhav, too, means nearly the same thing.
('55', 95, 11, 28, 198439) Madhav is the destroyer of the demon Madhu, who dwells in our bodies.
('55', 95, 11, 29, 198509) If you have any difficulty in choosing between these two names you may cast lots and decide.
('55', 95, 11, 30, 198602) If the choice were left to me, I would prefer Gopal.
('55', 95, 12, 31, 198655) 1 The reference is to the following sentences in the letter dated February 2, 1932: “I ate for many days the honey which you had given me for the voyage.

('55', 100, 7, 21, 204963) The issue of visitors has been partly settled.

('55', 100, 7, 25, 205273) The Superintendent should be informed in advance.

('55', 103, 0, 1, 207736) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 103, 1, 2, 207778) 99. PREFACE TO “FROM YERAVDA MANDIR”
('55', 103, 2, 3, 207815) March 6, 1932
('55', 103, 3, 4, 207829) During my incarceration in 1930 in the Yeravda Central Prison, I wrote weekly letters to the Satyagraha Ashrams containing a cursory examination of the principal Ashram observances.
('55', 103, 3, 5, 208011) 1 As the Ashram influence had already travelled beyond its geographical limits, copies of the letters were multiplied for distribution.
('55', 103, 3, 6, 208147) They were written in Gujarati.
('55', 103, 3, 7, 208178) There was a demand for translation into Hindi and other Indian languages, and also into English.
('55', 103, 3, 8, 208275) Shri Valji Desai gave a fairly full translation in English.
('55', 103, 3, 9, 208335) But seeing me in possession of comparative leisure during the recurrent incarceration, he has sent me his translation for revision.
('55', 103, 3, 10, 208467) I have gone through it carefully, and touched up several passages to bring out my meaning more to my liking.
('55', 103, 3, 11, 208576) I need hardly add that, if I was writing anew for the English reader, perhaps I should write a wholly new thing.
('55', 103, 3, 12, 208689) But that would be going beyond my commission.
('55', 103, 3, 13, 208735) And perhaps it is as well that even the English reader has the trend of my thought as expressed to the inmates of the Ashram, and in the year 1930. I have therefore taken the least liberty with the original argument.
('55', 103, 4, 14, 208952) M. K. GANDHI
('55', 103, 5, 15, 208965) From Yeravda Mandir
('55', 103, 6, 16, 208985) 100. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('55', 103, 7, 17, 209015) March 6, 1932
('55', 103, 8, 18, 209029) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, You have kindly given me a copy of the fresh instructions issued by the Government about the weekly visits.
('55', 103, 8, 19, 209158) I appreciate the trust reposed in me regarding the determination as to who shall be considered political inmates of the Ashram.
('55', 103, 8, 20, 209286) I am anxious to be true to the trust.
('55', 103, 8, 21, 209324) But before I could do so, there should be a common definition of the adjective ‘political’ between the Government and me.
('55', 103, 8, 22, 209446) I take ‘political’ to mean those who are politically minded and are actually taking part in politics as apart
('55', 103, 9, 23, 209556) 1Vide footnote 1, “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 27 1 1932
('55', 104, 0, 1, 209613) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 105
('55', 104, 1, 2, 209659) from civil resistance.
('55', 104, 1, 3, 209682) For if by ‘political’ are meant those who have been heretofore imprisoned as civil resisters or are believers in the doctrine of civil resistance, then there is no non political inmate in the Ashram.
('55', 104, 1, 4, 209882) If, however, the meaning is [as] I have given it, there are only three political inmates.
('55', 104, 1, 5, 209972) I mean Sjts.
('55', 104, 1, 6, 209985) Mahadev Desai, Pyarelal and Devdas Gandhi.
('55', 104, 1, 7, 210028) But if I may not see the first two, I may not see Devdas Gandhi for they are like Devdas to me.
('55', 104, 1, 8, 210124) As it so happens, they are all incarcerated.
('55', 104, 1, 9, 210169) I may also mention that at the present moment there are only boys and girls and the few adults who are reserved for looking after the youngsters and the multifarious industrial activities of the Ashram.
('55', 104, 1, 10, 210372) It is difficult, too, for me to submit a list of non Ashram friends till I know the definition that the Government have in mind of the term ‘political’.
('55', 104, 1, 11, 210525) I shall await reply to this before I submit a fairly full list for approval.
('55', 104, 1, 12, 210602) But, meanwhile, I give below illustrative names of those friends whom I regard as non political and whom I would put in the same category as my relatives.
('55', 104, 1, 13, 210757) Lady Thackersey, residence—Yeravda Hill.
('55', 104, 1, 14, 210798) She is a social worker.
('55', 104, 1, 15, 210822) She helped me during my serious illness in 1923 when I was a patient in the Sasoon Hospital.
('55', 104, 1, 16, 210915) Trivedi of the Agriculture College, Poona.
('55', 104, 1, 17, 210958) He stands to me in the same close contact as Lady Thackersey.
('55', 104, 1, 18, 211020) Yeshvantprasad Desai, mill owner residing in Matunga.
('55', 104, 1, 19, 211074) He nursed me during the same illness and took up his abode in Poona for helping me.
('55', 104, 1, 20, 211158) Pyare Ali and his wife, living in retirement at a retreat near Thana, where they have taken in a few Muslim orphans.
('55', 104, 1, 21, 211275) They lived nearly a year at the Ashram.
('55', 104, 1, 22, 211315) They are a deeply religious couple.
('55', 104, 1, 23, 211351) These friends are in no sense political.
('55', 104, 1, 24, 211392) Pending reply to this letter, I have written to the Manager of the Ashram 1 to send those inmates who may wish to visit me.
('55', 104, 2, 25, 211516) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('55', 105, 1, 2, 211754) 101. IMAM SAHEB I 1
('55', 105, 2, 3, 211774) March 7, 1932
('55', 105, 3, 4, 211788) I am not yet ready to write and send chapters of the ‘Bal Gita’.
('55', 105, 3, 5, 211853) As I was wondering what I should send this time, it occurred to me that I should give to the inmates of the Ashram my reminiscences of the Imam Saheb and should carry out this good resolution without delay.
('55', 105, 3, 6, 212060) I, therefore, wish to write out such reminiscences as occur to me and as I think I may narrate.
('55', 105, 3, 7, 212156) Imam Saheb went to South Africa about the same year as I (1893).
('55', 105, 3, 8, 212221) His real name was Abdul Kadir Bawazeer, but, as he served as Imam in South Africa, most people knew him as Imam Saheb.
('55', 105, 3, 9, 212340) I always addressed him by this name.
('55', 105, 3, 10, 212377) The Imam Saheb’s father was the Muezzin of the famous Jumma Masjid in Bombay and served in that capacity right till his death.
('55', 105, 3, 11, 212504) He died only a few years ago, after the Imam Saheb’s return to India.
('55', 105, 3, 12, 212574) He fell dead just as he was washing and getting ready for the azan 2. Such a death comes only to the blessed.
('55', 105, 3, 13, 212684) The Imam Saheb’s forefathers were Arabs and had come to India and settled in the Konkan years ago.
('55', 105, 3, 14, 212783) Hence he knew the Konkani language too.
('55', 105, 3, 15, 212823) His mother tongue was Gujarati, but he had little schooling.
('55', 105, 3, 16, 212884) He knew Arabic well enough to be able to read from the Koran Sharif with a pleasing intonation, though not so well as to be able to understand everything in the Koran.
('55', 105, 3, 17, 213052) He had picked up, through contacts inpractical life, English, Dutch and Creole French.
('55', 105, 3, 18, 213139) Urdu, of course, he knew.
('55', 105, 3, 19, 213165) He had also a working knowledge of Zulu.
('55', 105, 3, 20, 213206) His intellect was so sharp that, if he had regularly studied in a school, he would have earned reputation as a great scholar.
('55', 105, 3, 21, 213332) Though he was not a lawyer, he had come to understand subtleties of law through practical experience.
('55', 105, 3, 22, 213434) The Imam Saheb had gone to South Africa for trade and had earned much.
('55', 105, 3, 23, 213505) When he gave up business, he kept coaches which he supplied on hire and had a fairly good income from that calling.
('55', 105, 3, 24, 213621) Being a man of independent temper, he never tried his fortune in big
('55', 105, 4, 25, 213690) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”; vide the following item.
('55', 105, 4, 26, 213771) 2 Call to the faithful
('55', 106, 0, 1, 213794) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 107
('55', 106, 1, 2, 213840) business.
('55', 106, 1, 3, 213850) He had a sweet voice, and, since his father was a Muezzin, he occasionally officiated as Imam in the mosque in Johannesburg.
('55', 106, 1, 4, 213975) But he accepted no honorarium for his services.
('55', 106, 1, 5, 214023) The Imam Saheb had married twice.
('55', 106, 1, 6, 214057) Both the wives were Malays.
('55', 106, 1, 7, 214085) His first marriage was not successful, and so he married the lady whom we knew as his wife.
('55', 106, 1, 8, 214177) This marriage had given him much happiness.
('55', 106, 1, 9, 214221) He and the Haji Saheba served each other with great devotion.
('55', 106, 1, 10, 214283) He was a sincere friend.
('55', 106, 1, 11, 214308) So far as I know, the Imam Saheb’s views about marriage had undergone a complete change and he had come to believe in monogamy.

('55', 108, 4, 13, 218243) 104. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('55', 108, 5, 14, 218275) March 7, 1932
('55', 108, 7, 15, 218289) I think Rama humbled your pride by making you forget to complete your sacrificial spinning.
('55', 108, 7, 16, 218381) 1 I don’t count your lapse to be as serious as you do.
('55', 108, 7, 17, 218436) It is right, however, that you should regard it as big enough.
('55', 108, 7, 18, 218499) I say that Rama humbled your pride because if we, who are but puppets constantly liable to err, did not commit a single mistake in doing something, we are likely to be filled with pride (however subtle it may be).
('55', 108, 7, 19, 218713) Rama seems to have treated you in the same way as He— or was it Siva?—had treated Narad.
('55', 108, 7, 20, 218802) The incident has had two good results—your pride has been humbled and you will not make the same mistake again.
('55', 108, 7, 21, 218914) I have no comment to make here on the vivid sketches in your letter.
('55', 108, 7, 22, 218983) I have never believed that you are hard hearted.
('55', 108, 7, 23, 219032) Your criticisms help me.
('55', 108, 7, 24, 219057) Every one of us has virtues and weaknesses.
('55', 108, 7, 25, 219101) If you are less inclined to see the virtues of others, try to see them more often.
('55', 108, 7, 26, 219184) There was nothing in my letter to make Narandas ask questions about himself.
('55', 108, 7, 27, 219261) He does work in the spirit of yajna.
('55', 108, 7, 28, 219298) It is not his fault that I have left him no time to do any body labour.
('55', 108, 7, 29, 219370) This, too, is evidence of my lack of organizing ability.
('55', 108, 7, 30, 219427) If I had been able to make efficient arrangements from the time that the Ashram was started, it
('55', 108, 8, 31, 219523) 1 The addressee was rather proud of her unfailing observance of the Ashram rules.
('55', 108, 8, 32, 219605) But once her spinning was short by eight to ten rounds and she atoned for it by a three day fast.

('55', 109, 1, 2, 219745) would not have been necessary for several persons, as it is now, to be busy only in general supervision.
('55', 109, 1, 3, 219850) We have gone on the way we started.
('55', 109, 1, 4, 219886) I believe that it is still possible to change things, but I do not know how, and the Ashram has still not got a man or a woman, who will give more thought to the problem and enforce the Ashram rules more strictly.
('55', 109, 1, 5, 220100) Till we get such a person, we should tolerate the present conditions.
('55', 109, 1, 6, 220170) Let us always remember that the Ashram very much falls short of its ideal, for I believe it quite possible to organize things so well that everyone in it will do his or her share of body labour and good order will bepreserved.

('55', 111, 4, 8, 223760) 108. LETTER TO SIR SAMUEL HOARE
('55', 111, 5, 9, 223792) March 11, 1932 2
('55', 111, 6, 10, 223809) DEAR SIR SAMUEL, You will perhaps recollect that at the end of my speech 3 at the Round Table Conference when the minorities’ claim was presented, I had said that I should resist with my life the grant of separate electorate to the Depressed Classes.
('55', 111, 6, 11, 224060) This was not said in the heat of the moment, nor by way of rhetoric.
('55', 111, 6, 12, 224129) It was meant to be a serious statement.
('55', 111, 6, 13, 224169) In pursuance of that statement, I had hoped on my return to India to mobilize public opinion against separate electorate, at any rate, for the Depressed Classes.
('55', 111, 6, 14, 224331) But it was not to be.
('55', 111, 6, 15, 224353) From the newspapers which I am permitted to read, I observe that any moment His Majesty’s Government may declare their decision.
('55', 111, 6, 16, 224482) At first I had thought that if the decision was found to create separate electorates for the Depressed Classes, I should take such steps as I might then consider necessary to give effect to my vow.
('55', 111, 6, 17, 224680) But I feel that it would be unfair to the British Government for me to act without giving previous notice.
('55', 111, 6, 18, 224787) Naturally they could not attach the significance I give to my statement.
('55', 111, 6, 19, 224860) I need hardly reiterate all the objections I have to the creation of
('55', 111, 7, 20, 224929) 1 Gandhiji’s letters from correspondents abroad were misdirected to the addressee.
('55', 111, 7, 21, 225012) 2 Despatched on this date, the letter was drafted on March 9 and revised on March 10; vide “Diary, 1932”.
('55', 111, 7, 22, 225118) 3Vide “Speech at Minoriteies Committee Meeting”, 13 11 1931
('55', 112, 0, 1, 225178) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 113
('55', 112, 1, 2, 225224) separate electorates for the Depressed Classes.
('55', 112, 1, 3, 225272) I feel as if I was oneof them.
('55', 112, 1, 4, 225303) Their case stands on a wholly different footing from that of the others.
('55', 112, 1, 5, 225376) I am not against their representation in the legislatures.
('55', 112, 1, 6, 225435) I should favour every one of their adults, male or female, being registered as voters, irrespective of education or property qualifications, even though the franchise test may be stricter for the others.
('55', 112, 1, 7, 225639) But I hold that separate electorate is harmful for them and for Hinduism, whatever it may be from a purely political standpoint.
('55', 112, 1, 8, 225768) To appreciate the harm that separate electorates would do to them, one has to know how they are distributed amongst the so called caste Hindus, and how dependent they are on the latter.
('55', 112, 1, 9, 225954) So far as Hinduism is concerned separate electorate would simply vivisect and disrupt it.
('55', 112, 1, 10, 226044) For me the question of these classes is predominantly moral and religious.
('55', 112, 1, 11, 226119) The political aspect, important though it is, dwindles into insignificance compared to the moral and religious issue.
('55', 112, 1, 12, 226237) You will have to appreciate my feelings in this matter by remembering that I have been interested in the condition of these classes from my boyhood and have more than once staked my all for their sake.
('55', 112, 1, 13, 226439) I say this not to pride myself in any way.
('55', 112, 1, 14, 226482) For, I feel that no penance that caste Hindus may do can, in any way, compensate for the calculated degradation to which they have consigned the Depressed Classes for centuries.
('55', 112, 1, 15, 226660) But I know that separate electorate is neither penance nor any remedy for the crushing degradation they have groaned under.
('55', 112, 1, 16, 226784) I therefore respectfully inform His Majesty’s Government that in the event of their decision creating separate electorate for the Depressed Classes, I must fast unto death.
('55', 112, 1, 17, 226957) I am painfully conscious of the fact that such a step whilst I am a prisoner must cause grave embarrassment to His Majesty’s Government and that it will be regarded by many as highly improper on the part of one holding my position to introduce into the political field methods which they would describe as hysterical, if not much worse.
('55', 112, 1, 18, 227294) All I can urge in defence is that for me the contemplated step is not a method, it is part of my being.
('55', 112, 1, 19, 227398) It is a call of conscience which I dare not disobey, even though it may cost whatever reputation for sanity I may possess.
('55', 112, 1, 20, 227521) So far as I can see now, my discharge from imprisonment would not make the duty of fasting any the less imperative.
('55', 112, 1, 21, 227637) I am hoping, however, that all my fears are wholly unjustified and that the British Government have no intention whatever of
('55', 113, 0, 1, 227762) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 113, 1, 2, 227804) creating separate electorate for the Depressed classes.
('55', 113, 1, 3, 227860) It is perhaps as well for me to refer to another matter that is agitating me and may also enforce a similar fast.
('55', 113, 1, 4, 227974) It is the wayrepression is going.
('55', 113, 1, 5, 228008) I have no notion when I may receive a shock that would compel the sacrifice.
('55', 113, 1, 6, 228085) Repression appears to me to be crossing what might be called the legitimate limit.
('55', 113, 1, 7, 228168) A Governmental terrorism is spreading through the land.
('55', 113, 1, 8, 228224) Both English and Indian officials are being brutalized.
('55', 113, 1, 9, 228280) The latter, high and low, are becoming demoralized by reason of the Government rewarding as meritorious, disloyalty to the people and inhuman conduct towards their own kith and kin.
('55', 113, 1, 10, 228462) The latter are being cowed down.
('55', 113, 1, 11, 228495) Free speech has been stifled.
('55', 113, 1, 12, 228525) Goondaism is being practised in the name of law and order.
('55', 113, 1, 13, 228584) Women who have come out for public service stand in fear of their honour being insulted.
('55', 113, 1, 14, 228673) And all this, as it seems to me, is being done in order to crush the spirit of freedom which the Congress represents.
('55', 113, 1, 15, 228791) Repression is not confined to punishing civil breaches of the common law.
('55', 113, 1, 16, 228865) It goads people to break newly made orders of autocracy designed for the most part to humiliate them.
('55', 113, 1, 17, 228967) In all these doings as I read them, I see no spirit of democracy.
('55', 113, 1, 18, 229033) Indeed, my recent visit to England has confirmed my opinion that your democracy is a superficial circumscribed thing.
('55', 113, 1, 19, 229151) In the weightiest matters decisions are taken by individuals or groups, without any reference to the Parliament, and these have been ratified by the Members having but a vague notion of what they were doing.
('55', 113, 1, 20, 229359) Such was the case with Egypt, the War of 1914, and such is the case with India.
('55', 113, 1, 21, 229439) My whole being rebels against the idea that in a system called democratic, one man should have the unfettered power of affecting the destiny of the ancient people numbering over three hundred millions, and that his decisions can be enforced by mobilizing the most terrible forces of destruction.
('55', 113, 1, 22, 229735) To me this is a negation of democracy.
('55', 113, 1, 23, 229774) And this repression cannot be prolonged without further embittering the already bitter relations between the two peoples.
('55', 113, 1, 24, 229896) In so far as I am responsible and can help it, how am I to arrest the process?
('55', 113, 1, 25, 229975) Not by stopping civil disobedience.
('55', 113, 1, 26, 230011) For me it is an article of faith.
('55', 113, 1, 27, 230045) I regard myself by nature a democrat.
('55', 113, 1, 28, 230083) Democracy of my conception is wholly inconsistent with the use of physical force for enforcing its will.
('55', 113, 1, 29, 230188) Civil resistance therefore has been conceived to be a proper substitute for physical force to be used wherever generally the latter is
('55', 114, 0, 1, 230323) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 115
('55', 114, 1, 2, 230369) held necessary or justifiable.
('55', 114, 1, 3, 230400) It is a process of self suffering and a part of the plan is that in given circumstances a civil resister must sacrifice himself even by fasting to a finish.
('55', 114, 1, 4, 230557) That moment has not yet arrived for me.
('55', 114, 1, 5, 230597) I have no undeniable call from within for such a step.
('55', 114, 1, 6, 230652) But the events happening outside are alarming enough to agitate my fundamental being.
('55', 114, 1, 7, 230738) Therefore, in writing to you about the possibility of a fast regarding Depressed Classes, I felt that I would be untrue to you if I did not tell you also that there was another possibility, not remote, of such a fast.
('55', 114, 1, 8, 230956) Needless to say that from my side absolute secrecy has been maintained about all the correspondence I have carried on with you.
('55', 114, 1, 9, 231084) Of course Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Mahadev Desai, who has just been sent to join us, know all about it.
('55', 114, 1, 10, 231192) But you will no doubt make whatever use you wish of this letter.
('55', 114, 2, 11, 231257) Yours sincerely, BAPU SIR SAMUEL HOARE WHITEHALL LONDON Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.

('55', 117, 3, 4, 234290) CHI., Learning the Gita by heart only requires a good memory, and the task is easy.
('55', 117, 3, 5, 234374) But understanding the meaning calls for the use of one’s intellect.
('55', 117, 3, 6, 234442) This is a difficult thing, and, therefore, uninteresting.
('55', 117, 3, 7, 234500) When, however, you feel interest in exercising your intellect, the desire to understand the meaning will come to you.
('55', 117, 3, 8, 234618) You should, therefore, learn to take interest in subjects which require you to use your intellect.

('55', 118, 1, 2, 235436) 116. LETTER TO NARAYAN M. KHARE
('55', 118, 2, 3, 235468) March 12, 1932
('55', 118, 3, 4, 235483) PANDITJI, If instead of reading many books we read only one and reflect over it and put its teaching into practice, we get the desired result.
('55', 118, 3, 5, 235626) Sannyasa does not mean the renunciation of all activities; it means only the renunciation of activities prompted by desire and of the fruits of action performed as duty.
('55', 118, 3, 6, 235796) This is real freedom from activity.
('55', 118, 3, 7, 235832) That is why one must learn to see inactivity in activity and activity in inactivity.
('55', 118, 3, 8, 235917) Freedom from activity means only one thing, and it is what I have explained above.
('55', 118, 3, 9, 236000) And still one must win such freedom.
('55', 118, 3, 10, 236037) This problem led to the idea of renunciation of the fruits of action.

('55', 118, 6, 13, 236202) 117. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('55', 118, 7, 14, 236231) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, March 13, 1932
('55', 118, 8, 15, 236270) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I must thank you for your kind letter of the 2nd instant given to me on the 10th.
('55', 118, 8, 16, 236370) Though I do not share your rosy opinion about the working of repression, I know I must not enter into any argument.
('55', 118, 8, 17, 236486) I write this only to correct one grave misunderstanding.
('55', 118, 8, 18, 236543) I cannot accept the compliment you pay me for my loyalty to my colleagues as if it was the highest thing in life to me.
('55', 118, 8, 19, 236663) I wish you could have known that all my loyalties are subservient to my loyalty to truth.
('55', 118, 8, 20, 236753) I have been known, even during the past twelve years, to sacrifice friendships for the sake of what I have considered to be truth.
('55', 118, 8, 21, 236884) I am happy in the knowledge that at no time have I had colleagues more disposed than now to follow my guidance even though they might differ with me in important matters short of vital principle.
('55', 118, 8, 22, 237080) Might not history have been written differently, if among the celestials I had enjoyed for my loyalty to truth the credit you kindly give me for my loyalty to my
('55', 119, 0, 1, 237242) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 119, 1, 2, 237284) colleagues, and if therefore I had received glad response to my request for the interview?
('55', 119, 1, 3, 237375) God or the gods in New Delhi had willed otherwise!!!
('55', 119, 1, 4, 237428) The Bombay Government have now sent Mahadev Desai as an additional companion.
('55', 119, 1, 5, 237506) Hence I am able to spare you my wretched handwriting, With kind regards,
('55', 119, 2, 6, 237579) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('55', 119, 9, 18, 238005) 119. A LETTER
('55', 119, 10, 19, 238019) March 13, 1932
('55', 119, 11, 20, 238034) CHI., Family influences by themselves cannot ensure one’s moral and spiritual progress.
('55', 119, 11, 21, 238122) Such progress is impossible without effort on one’s part.
('55', 119, 11, 22, 238180) If there is no progress despite such effort, we need not worry.
('55', 119, 11, 23, 238244) It is as true in the science of spiritual progress as it is in the science of mechanics that no force ever fails to produce its result.
('55', 119, 11, 24, 238380) If five maunds of force push an object towards the north and an equal amount pushes it towards the south, the object will remain stationary, but both the forces will have done their full work and the stationary state of the object will in fact amount to its motion.
('55', 119, 11, 25, 238646) It is this truth which suggested
('55', 120, 0, 1, 238679) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 121
('55', 120, 1, 2, 238725) the method of working without attachment.
('55', 120, 1, 3, 238767) We should go on doing our best.

('55', 121, 4, 6, 239999) 123. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('55', 121, 5, 7, 240031) March 13, 1932
('55', 121, 7, 8, 240046) I have your letter.
('55', 121, 7, 9, 240066) For some time I shall have to write with my left hand and I shall not, therefore, be able to write very long letters.
('55', 121, 7, 10, 240184) The left hand cannot write as fast as the right hand can.
('55', 121, 7, 11, 240242) True, Mahadev’s help will be available, but dictating to him will be a new practice so far as letters written from jail are concerned.

('55', 121, 8, 27, 241329) They will have to study law together.

('55', 121, 8, 30, 241514) No one has been able to demonstrate decisive results in any country in this field.
('55', 121, 8, 31, 241597) The whole matter is in an experimental stage.

('55', 123, 6, 10, 244249) 126. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('55', 123, 7, 11, 244286) March 14, 1932
('55', 123, 8, 12, 244301) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, I got your letter.
('55', 123, 8, 13, 244341) It is not right for a brahmachari to attend to several things at a time.
('55', 123, 8, 14, 244414) He takes up only one thing at a time and concentrates all the energy of his body and mind on that thing.
('55', 123, 8, 15, 244519) If, therefore, you are occupied in manual work and there is no necessity for you to talk about anything relating to it, the proper thing would be to remain silent.
('55', 123, 8, 16, 244683) However, if we are playing or have gone out for a walk, talking is a part of the activity and so we can talk at that time.
('55', 123, 8, 17, 244806) Anybody who regulates his life strictly according to this principle, can make it full of interest.
('55', 123, 8, 18, 244905) And an institution where people work in complete silence and speak only when necessary impresses us as a very quiet place.
('55', 123, 8, 19, 245028) Not only do I see no harm in the girls putting on shorts and a shirt when doing exercises and also at other times, but I actually like the thing.
('55', 123, 8, 20, 245174) For the Ashram residents their goal in life has already been fixed, and it is that they are dedicated to the quest for truth.
('55', 123, 8, 21, 245300) To your question whether one should or should not aim to be like a soldier, I shall give an answer after you tell me in your next letter what all of you understand to be the meaning of the word ‘soldier’.
('55', 124, 0, 1, 245505) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 125
('55', 124, 1, 2, 245551) After travelling in many countries, I have found India to be the most beautiful country.
('55', 124, 1, 3, 245640) But since I am free, as I believe, from blind partiality, I have always been able to see much good in every country and so have found them all to be good and have appreciated the special excellence of each of them.
('55', 124, 1, 4, 245855) On the whole, however, I have felt that India is not inferior to any other country, that one finds in it all that one may want and that what one does not find in India is not quite essential for our life.
('55', 124, 1, 5, 246060) If the Ashram has money to spare and if the things are not likely to cost much, even at such a time as the present I would have no objection to having swings and slides made for you.
('55', 124, 1, 6, 246243) You should, however, bear one thing in mind, namely, that the Ashram should always be a poor people’s institution, and that just because the Ashram has the necessary money we will not be justified in getting anything we want.
('55', 124, 1, 7, 246469) And even things which befit poor people may be ordered only if the Ashram has the necessary funds.
('55', 124, 1, 8, 246568) The question, therefore, is only whether we can afford a thing and whether it is in keeping with our aim.

('55', 125, 0, 1, 247190) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 125, 1, 2, 247232) 128. IMAM SAHEB II 1
('55', 125, 2, 3, 247253) March 14, 1932
('55', 125, 3, 4, 247268) As we know, Imam Saheb had set much store by patriotic considerations in arranging the marriages of his two daughters.
('55', 125, 3, 5, 247387) He wanted to marry them to young men who would devote themselves to the service of the country, would make no difference between Hindus and Muslims and who would, by their manner of living, do honour to the Ashram ideal of life.
('55', 125, 3, 6, 247616) And so he selected two Gujarati Muslims from families of average means.
('55', 125, 3, 7, 247688) My first meeting with Imam Saheb may be said to have taken place in 1903 in South Africa after my return to that country.
('55', 125, 3, 8, 247810) He used to tell me that we had met once before that but I have no recollection of that meeting.
('55', 125, 3, 9, 247906) When I set up practice as a lawyer in Johannesburg, he used to accompany clients to my office.
('55', 125, 3, 10, 248001) He was an altogether different man then in appearance and manners.
('55', 125, 3, 11, 248068) He used to dress himself in English style, and wore a Turkish cap.
('55', 125, 3, 12, 248135) I immediately recognized his intelligence, but otherwise he did not produce a good impression on me at first.
('55', 125, 3, 13, 248245) I thought him rather obstinate, but, as I came to know him better, I liked him more and more.
('55', 125, 3, 14, 248339) I saw, as I had more and more experience of dealing with him, that what I had thought to be obstinacy was only his eagerness to understand fully the implications of every point.
('55', 125, 3, 15, 248517) If he held an opinion on any matter, he would not give it up till his reason was convinced of his error.
('55', 125, 3, 16, 248622) He would not take a lawyer’s word as gospel truth in legal matters merely because he himself was not a lawyer, but would argue against him even in such matters.
('55', 125, 3, 17, 248783) Though he had had no education, he had complete confidence in his judgement.
('55', 125, 3, 18, 248860) Moreover, he had a proud sense of self respect.
('55', 125, 3, 19, 248908) I, therefore, saw very soon that he had sufficient strength of mind to cling to his own view without being overawed by anybody.
('55', 125, 3, 20, 249036) In the beginning, Imam Saheb used to come to me on behalf of clients and explain their cases to me.
('55', 125, 3, 21, 249136) But he took interest in current affairs and would draw me into discussion about them.
('55', 125, 3, 22, 249222) He evinced keen interest in discussing the hardships of our countrymen in South
('55', 125, 4, 23, 249302) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”; vide the following item.
('55', 126, 0, 1, 249383) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 127
('55', 126, 1, 2, 249429) Africa and took part in the meetings, etc.
('55', 126, 1, 3, 249472) On most issues he supportedme, but he never hesitated to oppose me even in public whenever he did not approve of my stand.
('55', 126, 1, 4, 249595) Gradually, however, he was drawn towards me and, when the satyagraha commenced, proved himself as steadfast as a rock.
('55', 126, 1, 5, 249714) Some fell and some weakened, and some opposed me bitterly, but I don’t remember Imam Saheb to have wavered at any time.
('55', 126, 1, 6, 249834) When he was imprisoned for the first time, nobody expected that he would remain strong till the end.
('55', 126, 1, 7, 249935) On the contrary, many persons told me, including some who held him in high respect, that he would not go to jail again, that he had a delicate constitution, was pleasure loving and had many wants.
('55', 126, 1, 8, 250132) This was on the whole true.
('55', 126, 1, 9, 250160) However, Imam Saheb never weakened, whereas I saw many who were known to be simple in their habits withdrawing from the struggle.
('55', 126, 1, 10, 250290) Imam Saheb’s capacity for self sacrifice was very great, and, though he would think long before taking a decision, he showed wonderful strength in clinging to a decision once taken.
('55', 126, 1, 11, 250472) When Imam Saheb plunged into the struggle, he had no thought at all that he would have to break up his home and embrace a life of complete renunciation.
('55', 126, 1, 12, 250625) As soon, however, as he saw that if he wished to remain staunch in the satyagraha movement he would have to give up the attachment to his home, he did so almost in an instant.
('55', 126, 1, 13, 250801) This was no small sacrifice on his part.
('55', 126, 2, 14, 250842) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('55', 126, 3, 15, 250886) 129. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('55', 126, 4, 16, 250917) Monday, March 14, 1932
('55', 126, 5, 17, 250940) NARANDAS, Mahadev has joined me in the nick of time for my right hand has just gone out of service.
('55', 126, 5, 18, 251040) By this I do not meant that it is continually paining, but I certainly mean that it would start doing so if I went on writing with it or doing any other work.
('55', 126, 5, 19, 251199) It may even happen that I shall never be able now to do much work with it, for, I see that, though I gave it complete rest during the return voyage from England, it has not recovered sufficiently well so that I could resume working with it.
('55', 126, 5, 20, 251440) We need not feel sorry even if it becomes useless for ever.
('55', 126, 5, 21, 251500) Sooner or later all the bodily organs will have become weak.
('55', 126, 5, 22, 251561) We need not, therefore, feel concerned when we see them gradually becoming so.
('55', 126, 5, 23, 251640) It is no small grace of God that I have taken from
('55', 127, 0, 1, 251691) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 127, 1, 2, 251733) theright hand the service which I have done.
('55', 127, 1, 3, 251778) And, after all, as our [spiritual] dictionary 1 tells us, it is He who takes work from us, and He will do so as long as He wills and on His own condition.
('55', 127, 1, 4, 251933) Our hands and feet are His tools, and it will be enough if we knowingly do nothing to impair their efficiency.
('55', 127, 1, 5, 252044) We were foolish to the extent that we misused them in the past.
('55', 127, 1, 6, 252108) It is because we misuse our body that, when what we call old age arrives, our limbs and organs begin to decay.
('55', 127, 1, 7, 252219) To one who has never misused his bodily organs, old age will not be painful but, on the contrary, it will bring happiness.
('55', 127, 1, 8, 252342) If trees were thinking beings, we can easily see that they would feel no pain when their fruits, fully ripe, fell to the ground.
('55', 127, 1, 9, 252471) Rather, the knowledge that these fruits would be used by human beings would make them happy.
('55', 127, 1, 10, 252564) Similarly, he whose life is good must feel confident that when old age has worn out the strength of his body, his new condition will serve some greater good.
('55', 127, 1, 11, 252722) But, as things are, all this seems to us as mere wise talk, for we see no instances in the world, or very few, of perfectly happy old age.
('55', 127, 1, 12, 252861) Similarly, we rarely see a person who welcomes his death as a friend.
('55', 127, 1, 13, 252931) The health of all three of us may be described as good.
('55', 127, 1, 14, 252987) It is true that Mahadev has been suffering pain in the bone of one of his legs, but rest and sun bath will probably cure it.
('55', 127, 1, 15, 253112) There is no cause for worry.
('55', 127, 1, 16, 253141) You have given no news about Khushalbhai during the past week.
('55', 127, 1, 17, 253204) I infer from this that the cloud has dispersed for the time being.
('55', 127, 1, 18, 253271) The position about visitors is still not clear.
('55', 127, 1, 19, 253319) It is not improbable that the practice may have to be stopped.
('55', 127, 1, 20, 253382) However, I believe Jaisukhlal, Kashi, Lakshmi and Moti will have come and seen me in a day or two.
('55', 127, 1, 21, 253481) Haridas Gandhi 2 has been brought here.
('55', 127, 1, 22, 253521) He is still in the hospital.
('55', 127, 1, 23, 253550) We get reports about his health from time to time, but none of us has yet been able to see him.
('55', 127, 1, 24, 253646) Ramdas came and saw me.
('55', 127, 1, 25, 253670) Most probably I shall be able to see the others too.
('55', 127, 1, 26, 253723) I had expected a letter from Mirabehn, but I have received none so far.
('55', 127, 1, 27, 253795) It was reported in the newspapers that Gangabehn Jhaveri has been released.
('55', 127, 1, 28, 253871) It seems somebody paid the fine on her behalf.
('55', 127, 1, 29, 253918) Who was that person?
('55', 127, 1, 30, 253939) Do you get any news about Prabhavati?
('55', 127, 2, 31, 253977) 1 Bhagavad Gita 2 A resident of Amreli who came to join the Ashram

('55', 135, 2, 3, 265801) March 20, 1932
('55', 135, 3, 4, 265816) CHI., When manure is spread in the field, it becomes fine earth and the gases which are generated in the process serve as food for the trees.
('55', 135, 3, 5, 265958) Similarly, so long as the saliva remains in the mouth and the mouth is healthy, it helps to digest food.
('55', 135, 3, 6, 266063) When, however, it is spat out, it makes dirt.
('55', 135, 3, 7, 266109) Mixing with dust, it breeds germs.
('55', 135, 3, 8, 266144) The point is that in its own place nothing is dirty, and the second point is that dirt is made by man.
('55', 135, 3, 9, 266247) We should know this and understand and observe the rules of sanitation.

('55', 137, 8, 15, 269264) 148. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('55', 137, 9, 16, 269297) March 20, 1932
('55', 137, 10, 17, 269312) PARASRAM, Brushing the teeth with datan 1 should be supplemented by the use of fingers.
('55', 137, 10, 18, 269400) That is, rub the gums vigorously with the fingers while gargling after you have brushed the teeth with datan and cleansed the tongue with the twig.
('55', 137, 10, 19, 269548) One suffering from pyorrhoea should brush theteeth with datan twice daily, and I would not think it too much to give half an hour each time.
('55', 137, 10, 20, 269689) I have come across negroes brushing their teeth at all times in the day.
('55', 137, 10, 21, 269762) The benefit from the use of datan is
('55', 137, 11, 22, 269799) 1 Same as datun; vide “Letter to Tulsi Maher”, 24 1 1932
('55', 138, 0, 1, 269856) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 139
('55', 138, 1, 2, 269902) not merely that the teeth are brushed with it, but also that all the poisonous matter in the gums is thrown out with the fluids discharged from the mouth while crushing the datan, as we spit out the fluids entirely.
('55', 138, 1, 3, 270118) I myself use nothing else except common salt with the datan.
('55', 138, 1, 4, 270179) Of course, my brushing the teeth does not mean much, because I have not a single tooth left in the upper jaw and even in the lower only a few remain.
('55', 138, 1, 5, 270329) Both the babul and the neem twigs are good for datan but perhaps the neem is likely to be better for one suffering from pyorrhoea as the bitterness of the neem is highly beneficial.
('55', 138, 1, 6, 270511) There is not the slightest need for the girls to use a fountain pen.
('55', 138, 1, 7, 270580) Really speaking, nobody in the Ashram should need a fountain pen.
('55', 138, 1, 8, 270646) Why should anybody be in such hurry?
('55', 138, 1, 9, 270683) For students at any rate, it is certainly a harmful thing to use.
('55', 138, 1, 10, 270749) The reed pen is the best for writing Gujarati, Hindi, Urdu and other Indian scripts.
('55', 138, 1, 11, 270834) We should teach the children to use it properly.
('55', 138, 1, 12, 270883) During prayers at the Ashram, none should start reciting or singing before the leader begins.
('55', 138, 1, 13, 270977) And again, the rule is that when he leads, only those can join in the recitation or singing who can do so in tune.
('55', 138, 1, 14, 271092) When the whole community sings harmoniously in one tune, their singing never fails to produce an effect.
('55', 138, 1, 15, 271197) Nor does silence fail.
('55', 138, 1, 16, 271220) Both are beneficial, each in its proper place.
('55', 138, 1, 17, 271267) In offering oblations, etc., at a sacrifice, the incantations used to be chanted aloud in the belief that thousands were witnessing the ceremony with reverence.
('55', 138, 1, 18, 271428) Once that became a custom, even when only five or ten persons are present the incantations at a sacrifice continue to be chanted aloud.
('55', 138, 1, 19, 271564) The observance of one principal vow mostly includes that of several minor ones.
('55', 138, 1, 20, 271644) Just as a neem tree comes out of another neem tree, so human beings are born from human beings, and just as the general properties of the neem are transmitted from one to another, so are those of human beings.
('55', 138, 1, 21, 271854) But because of several other factors which also operate, the transmission of all characteristics is not, as it should not be, maintained.
('55', 138, 1, 22, 271992) Moreover, we observe certain peculiarities in man also because of the difference that exists between man and other living creatures.
