('55', 140, 0, 1, 273232) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 141
('55', 140, 1, 2, 273278) 151. IMAM SAHEB III 1
('55', 140, 2, 3, 273300) March 21, 1932
('55', 140, 3, 4, 273315) We should remember that Imam Saheb had set up his home in English style.
('55', 140, 3, 5, 273388) Haji Saheba had lived in that style from her very birth.
('55', 140, 3, 6, 273445) Fatima and Amina also were brought up like English children.
('55', 140, 3, 7, 273506) For one who had lived in this manner, it was extremely difficult to curtail his heavy expenditure and adopt an utterly simple mode of life.
('55', 140, 3, 8, 273646) For Imam Saheb, however, once he had made up his mind to do a particular thing, it was quite easy to carry out his resolve.
('55', 140, 3, 9, 273770) And, therefore, when I decided to leave Johannesburg and to settle in Phoenix, he himself proposed that he, too, would live there.
('55', 140, 3, 10, 273901) Though I knew his firmness of mind, I was completely at a loss what to say in reply to his proposal.
('55', 140, 3, 11, 274002) I described to him the hardships of life in Phoenix.
('55', 140, 3, 12, 274055) A man who had never put his body to the slightest trouble and had always lived surrounded by comforts and luxuries, I wondered how such a person would be able to start forthwith living like a labourer.
('55', 140, 3, 13, 274257) Even if he himself could bear the hardships of life in Phoenix, what about Haji Saheba, and Fatima and Amina, I asked.
('55', 140, 3, 14, 274376) Imam Saheb’s reply was brief.
('55', 140, 3, 15, 274406) He said: “I have put my trust in God.
('55', 140, 3, 16, 274444) And you do not know Haji Saheba.
('55', 140, 3, 17, 274477) She will always be ready to live where I live, and as I live.
('55', 140, 3, 18, 274539) If, therefore, you have no other difficulty in the matter, I have decided to come and live in Phoenix.
('55', 140, 3, 19, 274642) No one knows when the struggle will end.
('55', 140, 3, 20, 274683) I don’t think I shall be able to carry on my old business of supplying coaches on hire, or take up any other occupation.
('55', 140, 3, 21, 274804) Like you, I too have realized that a satyagrahi should give up love of wealth and possessions.” Imam Saheb’s proposal pleased me very much.
('55', 140, 3, 22, 274944) I wrote to my co workers in Phoenix.
('55', 140, 3, 23, 274981) They also welcomed the proposal.
('55', 140, 3, 24, 275014) And so Imam Saheb and his family came over.
('55', 140, 3, 25, 275058) Many inmates of the Ashram probably do not know that Imam Saheb joined the residents of Phoenix in all their activities.
('55', 140, 3, 26, 275179) Everybody fetched water for his or her own use from a spring below.
('55', 140, 3, 27, 275247) It flowed at some depth below the level of the Phoenix Settlement.
('55', 140, 3, 28, 275314) The Phoenix buildings were on a hill and one had to climb about fifty feet to reach the place.
('55', 140, 3, 29, 275409) Imam Saheb had a delicate constitution even atthat time, but
('55', 140, 4, 30, 275470) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”; vide the following item.
('55', 141, 0, 1, 275551) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 141, 1, 2, 275593) every morning one saw him walking down to the spring with a kavad 1
('55', 141, 2, 3, 275661) on his shoulders and climbing up slowly with the buckets filled with water.
('55', 141, 2, 4, 275737) The place now occupied by the spinning wheel in the Ashram was held in Phoenix by the printing press.
('55', 141, 2, 5, 275839) All the inmates, boys and girls, old men and women, educated and uneducated, had to work in some department of the press.
('55', 141, 2, 6, 275961) There were all kinds of big or small tasks, composing, folding the printed copies of the paper, making wrappers, pasting stamps, moving the wheel with the hand whenever the machine stopped, etc., etc.
('55', 141, 2, 7, 276162) Everybody was required to give some time and help in these tasks, especially on the day on which the journal was to be published.
('55', 141, 2, 8, 276292) Imam Saheb, Haji Saheba, Fatima and Amina, all four of them joined in this work.
('55', 141, 2, 9, 276373) Imam Saheb had learned composing.
('55', 141, 2, 10, 276407) For a man of his temper and habits and of his age, this was indeed wonderful.
('55', 141, 2, 11, 276485) In this way, Imam Saheb identified himself completely with the life at Phoenix.
('55', 141, 2, 12, 276565) He and the other members of his family were non vegetarian, but I don’t remember any time when they cooked such food at Phoenix.
('55', 141, 2, 13, 276694) This, however, does not mean that Imam Saheb was in any way a less devout Muslim.
('55', 141, 2, 14, 276776) He never missed namaz, nor did he or his family ever fail to observe the roza.
('55', 141, 2, 15, 276855) By adopting the manner of life of the other inmates and making a sacrifice for their sake, he really demonstrated the nobility of Islamic culture.
('55', 141, 2, 16, 277002) Imam Saheb’s capacity for self sacrifice was to be put to a still severe test.
('55', 141, 2, 17, 277081) He went to jail again several times, and proved himself a model prisoner.
('55', 141, 2, 18, 277155) When, however, in the year 1914 it was decided that most of the inmates of the Ashram should return to India, leaving only a few of them in Phoenix, Imam Saheb was put to a real test.
('55', 141, 2, 19, 277339) South Africa had practically become his home.
('55', 141, 2, 20, 277385) Haji Saheba, Fatima and Amina were complete strangers to India and did not know any Indian language—a little English and Dutch was all the language that they knew.
('55', 141, 2, 21, 277549) But Imam Saheb took no time to come to a decision.
('55', 141, 2, 22, 277600) He had made up his mind that he and his family would live wherever I did.
('55', 141, 2, 23, 277674) That was his self sacrifice for the cause of satyagraha and his contribution towards Hindu Muslim unity.
('55', 141, 2, 24, 277779) All the inmates of the Ashram know about his life after his coming to India.
('55', 141, 2, 25, 277856) I am convinced that he was rising higher day by day: his heart was becoming purer, his devotion to God was
('55', 141, 3, 26, 277963) 1 Two baskets or vessels suspended from the ends of a stick carried horizontally over the shoulders
('55', 142, 0, 1, 278063) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 143
('55', 142, 1, 2, 278109) becomingdeeper and his faith in the Ashram rules also was increasing.

('55', 143, 5, 17, 281020) 153. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('55', 143, 6, 18, 281057) March 21, 1932
('55', 143, 7, 19, 281072) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, There is of course no sin if one has to go to answer calls of nature during the hours for manual work, but it is certainly a bad habit.
('55', 143, 7, 20, 281229) A boy or girl who feels interested in such work should attend to calls before joining it.
('55', 143, 7, 21, 281319) Moreover, one who has a fixed time for such calls would always go at that time.
('55', 143, 7, 22, 281399) If the hours for manual work come together, then a person would certainly have to go during that period.
('55', 143, 7, 23, 281504) For this reason, manual work is never prescribed for more than four consecutive hours.
('55', 143, 7, 24, 281591) Spinning is primarily an education, for it arouses in us a sense of the duty of service, we learn in it a very useful occupation and there is beautiful art in it.
('55', 143, 7, 25, 281754) One never goes to join any work unless the wish is there.
('55', 143, 7, 26, 281812) But children who are not properly trained never feel the desire to do a good thing.
('55', 143, 7, 27, 281896) The best rule, therefore, is to join in good work whether
('55', 143, 8, 28, 281954) 1 For the article “Imam Saheb III” which followed, vide the preceding item.
('55', 144, 0, 1, 282030) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 145
('55', 144, 1, 2, 282076) the desire is there or not.
('55', 144, 1, 3, 282104) A child who does this regularly comes to like the work in course of time, that is, he feels a desire to join it.
('55', 144, 1, 4, 282217) If we always follow only our desires, we would become self indulgent.We should try our best to save ourselves from that fate.
('55', 144, 1, 5, 282343) You may say of me that my favourite subjects were languages and geometry.
('55', 144, 1, 6, 282417) You can come when Narandas permits you to do so, but it would be good if you control your desire to come.
('55', 144, 1, 7, 282523) Remember that we are poor, wish to remain so and aspire to vie with our starving countrymen.
('55', 144, 1, 8, 282616) I will now narrate an incident.
('55', 144, 1, 9, 282648) I see here with my own eyes something I had formerly heard about.
('55', 144, 1, 10, 282714) We have here a cat which, when it wants to answer nature’s call, goes to a place where it would not be observed by anybody.
('55', 144, 1, 11, 282838) It finds for the purpose a dusty spot and, after answering the call, scratches the ground and covers up the faeces with earth.
('55', 144, 1, 12, 282965) After doing that, the cat sniffs at the spot and, if there is the slightest smell, it throws more earth on the spot.
('55', 144, 1, 13, 283082) On seeing this, I asked myself: ‘Do all of us cover up the excreta as carefully as this cat does?’ We daily bow to Mother Earth and ask her forgiveness for walking on her with our feet; but do we cover up the ground after spitting, blowing our nose or passing urine, etc.?
('55', 144, 1, 14, 283355) Those who have not been observing this rule should start doing so immediately.

('55', 146, 3, 4, 285289) CHI., Do you remember my definition of God?
('55', 146, 3, 5, 285333) Instead of saying that God is Truth, I say that Truth is God.
('55', 146, 3, 6, 285395) I did not always think thus.
('55', 146, 3, 7, 285424) I realized this only four years ago.
('55', 146, 3, 8, 285461) But without knowing it I always acted as if it was so.
('55', 146, 3, 9, 285516) I have always known God as Truth.
('55', 146, 3, 10, 285550) There was a time when I doubted the existence of God, but even at that time I did not doubt the existence of Truth.
('55', 146, 3, 11, 285666) This Truth is not a material quality but is pure consciousness.
('55', 146, 3, 12, 285730) That alone holds the universe together.
('55', 146, 3, 13, 285770) It is God because it rules the whole universe.
('55', 146, 3, 14, 285817) If you follow this idea, it contains the answer to all your other questions.
('55', 146, 3, 15, 285894) If you have any difficulty, however, put your question to me.
('55', 146, 3, 16, 285956) For me this is almost a matter of direct experience.
('55', 146, 3, 17, 286009) I say “almost” because I have not seen face to face God Who is Truth.
('55', 146, 3, 18, 286079) I have had only a glimpse of Him.
('55', 146, 3, 19, 286113) But my faith is unshakable.

('55', 153, 1, 2, 296489) 169. LETTER TO HEMPRABHA DAS GUPTA
('55', 153, 2, 3, 296524) March 22, 1932
('55', 153, 3, 4, 296539) A devotee of the Gita never concerns himself with the question whether he can see God while in this body, for it is his duty to do work but he has no right to claim the fruit.
('55', 153, 3, 5, 296715) If so, why should we think about that to which we have no right?
('55', 153, 3, 6, 296780) All the same, it is my view that full realization of God is impossible while in this body.
('55', 153, 3, 7, 296871) We may almost reach the goal, but, because of the body, it seems impossible that we can go through the doorway.
('55', 153, 3, 8, 296983) We must, of course, feel continually the misery of separation from God, otherwise we would give up or relax our effort.
('55', 153, 3, 9, 297103) Such misery, however, should leadnot to despair but to hope, not to relaxation of effort but to even greater effort.
('55', 153, 3, 10, 297220) We have God’s assurance that however small the effort, it is never wasted.
('55', 153, 3, 11, 297295) In view of this, even the misery of separation should be a cause of joy to us, for we must have faith that one day we shall realize Him.
('55', 153, 4, 12, 297432) [From Gujarati]
('55', 153, 5, 13, 297448) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 154, 7, 14, 298515) 172. LETTER TO TILAKAM
('55', 154, 8, 15, 298538) March 24, 1932
('55', 154, 9, 16, 298553) MY DEAR, In working out plans for self restraint, attention must not for a single moment be withdrawn from the fact that we are all sparks of the divine and, therefore, partake of its nature, and since there can be no such thing as self indulgence with the divine it must of necessity be foreign to human nature.
('55', 154, 9, 17, 298866) If we get a hard grasp of that elementary fact, we should have no difficulty in attaining self control, and that is exactly what is implied in the verses we sing every evening.
('55', 154, 9, 18, 299043) You will recall that one of the verses says that the craving for self indulgence abates only when one sees God face to face.
('55', 154, 10, 19, 299168) From a copy: C.W. 8961. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi.

('55', 161, 8, 14, 308766) MIRA, No letter from you as you had promised.
('55', 161, 8, 15, 308812) But I am not surprised.
('55', 161, 8, 16, 308836) Such correspondence was held up.
('55', 161, 8, 17, 308869) But the bar is now lifted at least so far as I am concerned and therefore presumably so far as my correspondents are concerned.
('55', 161, 8, 18, 308997) I therefore expect from you an answer almost per return.

('55', 166, 6, 16, 315577) 194. SOME REFLECTIONS ON EDUCATION 2
('55', 166, 7, 17, 315614) March 28, 1932
('55', 166, 8, 18, 315629) John Ruskin was a great writer, teacher and religious thinker.
('55', 166, 8, 19, 315692) He died about 1880. 3 I suppose most inmates of the Ashram know that one book 4 of his had a great effect on me and that it was this book which inspired me to introduce an important change in my life practically on the instant.
('55', 166, 8, 20, 315920) He started in 1871 writing monthly letters addressed to factory workers.
('55', 166, 8, 21, 315993) I had read praise of these letters in some article of Tolstoy, but I had not been able to secure them till now.
('55', 166, 8, 22, 316105) I had brought with me [from England] a book about Ruskin’s workand his efforts in the field of constructive activities.
('55', 166, 8, 23, 316225) I read it here.
('55', 166, 8, 24, 316241) This book also mentioned the letters referred to above.
('55', 166, 8, 25, 316297) So I wrote to a
('55', 166, 9, 26, 316313) 1 Giving news of the death of Dhirajlal Banker, addressee’s younger brother 2 This was sent along with ‘‘Letter to Narandas Gandhi”,24/29 3 1932 3 He died in 1900. 4 Unto This Last
('55', 167, 0, 1, 316494) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 167, 1, 2, 316536) woman disciple of Ruskin in England, who was none else but the author of that book.
('55', 167, 1, 3, 316620) Being a poor woman, she could not send me the volumes of these letters.
('55', 167, 1, 4, 316692) Through foolishness or false courtesy, I had not asked her to write to the Ashram for the money.
('55', 167, 1, 5, 316789) This good woman sent my letter to a friend of hers who was comparatively in better circumstances.
('55', 167, 1, 6, 316887) This friend was the editor of The spectator.
('55', 167, 1, 7, 316932) I had even met him while in England.
('55', 167, 1, 8, 316969) He sent me the four volumes in which these letters had been published.
('55', 167, 1, 9, 317040) I have been reading the first part.
('55', 167, 1, 10, 317076) The thoughts expressed in these letters are beautiful and resemble some of our own ideas, so much so that an outsider would think that the ideas which I have set forth in my writings and which we try to put into practice in the Ashram, I had stolen from these letters of Ruskin.
('55', 167, 1, 11, 317355) I hope readers will understand what is meant by ‘stolen’.
('55', 167, 1, 12, 317413) If an idea or ideal of life is borrowed from somebody but is presented as one’s own conception, it is said to be stolen.
('55', 167, 1, 13, 317534) Ruskin has discussed many matters.
('55', 167, 1, 14, 317569) Here I will mention only a few of his ideas.
('55', 167, 1, 15, 317614) He says that it is a sheer error to suppose, as is generally done, that some education however little or however faulty is better than no literary education at all.
('55', 167, 1, 16, 317779) It is his view that we should strive for real education alone.
('55', 167, 1, 17, 317842) And then he says that every human being requires three things and three virtues.
('55', 167, 1, 18, 317923) Anyone who fails to cultivate them does not know the secret of life.
('55', 167, 1, 19, 317992) These six things should therefore form the basis of education.
('55', 167, 1, 20, 318055) Every child, whether boy or girl, should learn the properties of pure air, clean water and clean earth, and should also learn how to keep air, water and earth pure or clean and know their benefits.
('55', 167, 1, 21, 318253) Likewise, he has mentioned gratitude, hope and charity as the three virtues.
('55', 167, 1, 22, 318330) Anybody who does not love truth and cannot recognize goodness or beauty lives in his own selfconceit and remains ignorant of spiritual joy.
('55', 167, 1, 23, 318470) Similarly, he who has no hope, who has, in other words, no faith in divine justice, will never be cheerful in heart.
('55', 167, 1, 24, 318587) And he who is without love, that is, lacks the spirit of ahimsa, who cannot look upon all living things as his kith and kin, will never know the secret of living.
('55', 167, 1, 25, 318750) Ruskin has explained these ideas at great length in his wonderful language.
('55', 167, 1, 26, 318826) I hope I shall be able to write about them some time in a language which all the inmates of the Ashram can understand.
('55', 167, 1, 27, 318945) Today I rest content with the brief precis given above.
('55', 167, 1, 28, 319001) But I will say one thing, that what Ruskin has explained in his finished and cultivated prose with English readers in view, is practically thesame ideas which
('55', 168, 0, 1, 319160) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 169
('55', 168, 1, 2, 319206) we discuss in our rustic language and which we have been trying to put into practice.
('55', 168, 1, 3, 319292) I am comparing here not two languages, but two writers.
('55', 168, 1, 4, 319348) I cannot hope to equal Ruskin’s mastery of language.
('55', 168, 1, 5, 319401) But a time will certainly come when the love of our language will have become universal and we shall have writers like Ruskin who will have dedicated themselves heart and soul to it and will write as powerful Gujarati as the English of Ruskin.
('55', 168, 2, 6, 319645) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('55', 168, 8, 27, 320655) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I was distressed to read a note by the Director of Information, Bombay, that the Bombay Government intended to sell out beyond recall the lands of ‘recalcitrant’ farmers of Ras and such other villages.

('55', 169, 0, 1, 320933) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 169, 1, 2, 320975) Irwin last year, in the course of the conversations, that under a recurrence of the circumstances which had actuated the Government to sell out some holdings in Ras during the previous satyagraha campaign, the experiment must not be repeated.
('55', 169, 1, 3, 321218) I do not suggest that this remark was anything more than the then personal wish of Lord Irwin.
('55', 169, 1, 4, 321313) But I cannot help feeling hurt that all such generous wishes of an honourable and high functionary should be in danger of being set aside or overlooked.
('55', 169, 1, 5, 321466) And even apart from Lord Irwin’s obiter statement, I would like the legacies of bitternesses to be left either by Government officials or Congressmen to be reduced to a minimum, if they cannot be avoided altogether.
('55', 169, 1, 6, 321682) Surely all irrevocable acts which parties might possibly deplore in future or for which posterity may curse us should be avoided.

('55', 171, 1, 16, 325276) If you do so, however, you must resolve not to be defeated.
('55', 171, 1, 17, 325336) We have, in fact, achieved nothing if we are able to do something when all the circumstances are favourable.
('55', 171, 1, 18, 325445) A carpenter gives shape to any piece of wood and a sculptor makes an image from any stone; we are, likewise, worth our salt only if we know how to live with all types of people and get work from them.
('55', 171, 1, 19, 325646) I think this is the main thing we have to learn in this life.
('55', 171, 1, 20, 325708) For that, our heart should be as large as the sea.

('55', 171, 1, 25, 326032) I know thatthis is a difficult task.

('55', 174, 1, 2, 328995) 205. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('55', 174, 2, 3, 329026) March 24/29, 1932
('55', 174, 3, 4, 329044) NARANDAS,
('55', 174, 4, 5, 329054) I got your packet yesterday.
('55', 174, 4, 6, 329083) Gangabehn came and saw me.
('55', 174, 4, 7, 329110) It is necessary that we should think about Indu’s health.
('55', 174, 4, 8, 329168) When he returned from Bangalore, he weighed 100 lb., and he is 90 now.
('55', 174, 4, 9, 329239) Discover the cause.
('55', 174, 4, 10, 329259) Know from him where and what he eats, what he used to eat in Bangalore and what was his way of life there, and how, according to him, he can keep better health in the Ashram.
('55', 174, 4, 11, 329434) If anybody does not keep good health in the Ashram, we should try and discover the cause and, if he or she does not improve with such measures and changes as we can try and as would be in keeping with the principles of the Ashram, we should send the person to some other place, to Visapur or Wardha, for instance.
('55', 174, 4, 12, 329748) Think over this problem and, if you consider it necessary, entrust the responsibility in this matter to one particular person.
('55', 174, 4, 13, 329875) You will not be able to look after every inmate of the Ashram.

('55', 174, 5, 17, 330221) There were two or three other points too.

('55', 175, 1, 4, 331206) I don’t think we do any good by repeatedly presenting to children unworthy actions of great men, even though we represent the actions as unworthy, unless it is absolutely necessary to tell them about such actions.

('55', 176, 1, 13, 334166) Why should a child of his age continually show 99° temperature?
('55', 176, 1, 14, 334230) Or, maybe, just because he is a child, on taking his temperature with a thermometer or examining his pulse, we may feel that he is having fever but in fact there may be no fever.
('55', 176, 1, 15, 334409) The heart beat of a very active child who is playing about the whole day is bound to be faster, and, therefore, he is bound to have more heat in him and the thermometer or the examination of his pulse may show a little fever.
('55', 176, 1, 16, 334635) In such a case, the real test is provided by the child’s stool, the appearance of his tongue, his digestion and his weight.
('55', 176, 1, 17, 334759) A child’s weight must show increase every weak.
('55', 176, 1, 18, 334807) His tongue should be clean and moist, he should be passing stool without effort and it must be well formed and without foul smell.

('55', 178, 1, 2, 337254) 206. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('55', 178, 2, 3, 337291) March 29, 1932
('55', 178, 3, 4, 337306) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, As there was no letter from you this week, there was no need for me to write to you.
('55', 178, 3, 5, 337412) But this time I ignore the omission.
('55', 178, 3, 6, 337449) Knowledge should be given only to a jijnasu.
('55', 178, 3, 7, 337494) A jijnasu means a person who hungers for knowledge.
('55', 178, 3, 8, 337546) As a child fed by its mother even when it is not hungry will fall ill, so also, if you are not hungry for knowledge you will not be able to digest knowledge which is forced on you, that is, you will derive no benefit from it.
('55', 178, 3, 9, 337772) Hence, not only should I get a letter from you every week, but the letter should also be an interesting one.
('55', 178, 3, 10, 337881) “Interesting” means sweet, one which gave you pleasure in writing and will give me pleasure in reading.
('55', 178, 3, 11, 337985) If you are interested in lejim exercises, you may write an interesting letter on that subject but it may not be interesting to me because I may know nothing about these exercises and have no means here of knowing anything.
('55', 178, 3, 12, 338208) If you write such a letter, what can I write in reply?
('55', 178, 3, 13, 338263) Do you understand now the two conditions your letters must fulfil so that they may be interesting?
('55', 178, 3, 14, 338362) I, too, must fulfil those conditions in my letters.
('55', 178, 3, 15, 338414) That is why I once wrote to Sharda that, if you could take no interest in my letters about the Gita, the fault must be mine.
('55', 178, 3, 16, 338539) So be it.

('55', 181, 8, 21, 342725) 1 A prisoner ought not to even think of the outside world.
('55', 181, 8, 22, 342784) Karmayoga for him would mean doing the duty which now has become his in jail.
('55', 181, 8, 23, 342862) In the verse cq_kS 'kj.kefUoPN 2; “seek refuge in the attitude of detachment”, etc., the word buddhi certainly does not mean the samkhya, or the path of knowledge.
('55', 181, 8, 24, 343026) Here it has the meaning which it bears in the phrase yogabuddhi, about which the Lord had promised to explain in the verse ,"kk rs·fHkfgrk lka[;s cqf_;ksxsfRoeka J`.kqA3 “Thus have I set before thee the attitude of Knowledge; hear now the attitude of Action”, etc.
('55', 181, 8, 25, 343291) That is to say, if any comparison is to
('55', 181, 9, 26, 343331) 1 Omission as in the source 2 Bhagavad Gita, II.
('55', 181, 9, 27, 343380) 49 3 Ibid
('55', 182, 0, 1, 343390) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 183
('55', 182, 1, 2, 343436) be made at all, it is between karmayoga and bhaktiyoga.
('55', 182, 1, 3, 343492) But instead of making a comparison between jnanayoga, karmayoga and bhaktiyoga, the Gita aims at a synthesis of the three.
('55', 182, 1, 4, 343615) To practise any one of them perfectly, one must also practise the other two.
('55', 182, 1, 5, 343692) That is, the three are inseparable.
('55', 182, 1, 6, 343728) There is some indication of the superiority of karmayoga from among the three, but only because there is less risk in it of being deceived.
('55', 182, 1, 7, 343868) usgkfHkØeuk'kks·fLr izR;ok;ks u fo|rs1 “Here no effort undertaken is lost, no disaster befalls”, etc.
('55', 182, 1, 8, 343970) I believe that we must first grasp the general purport of the book we are trying to study.
('55', 182, 1, 9, 344061) In other words, our thinking about it should be independent.
('55', 182, 1, 10, 344122) As for rebirth, there is no room for doubt at all.
('55', 182, 1, 11, 344173) Our body changes a little every day, so that in seven years the whole gets changed altogether.
('55', 182, 1, 12, 344268) It seems to be the same because the form remains the same.
('55', 182, 1, 13, 344327) If the body can be transformed every seven years, there is no reason whatever to think that what we know as death means complete annihilation.
('55', 182, 1, 14, 344470) The atman is different from the body and it is certainly not destroyed when the body is destroyed.
('55', 182, 1, 15, 344569) Then, all that takes place at death is a change of state.
('55', 182, 1, 16, 344627) If a change of state is possible, why not a change of the body?
('55', 182, 1, 17, 344691) However, we can have a full discussion of this subject only when we meet.
('55', 182, 1, 18, 344765) Meanwhile, I certainly wish that you should be able to get rid of your doubts about certain conclusions.
('55', 182, 1, 19, 344870) For this purpose, you may put me any questions that you wish.
('55', 182, 1, 20, 344932) I don’t think that I can write a smriti.
('55', 182, 1, 21, 344973) What I write or say has not been thought out in conformity with a system.
('55', 182, 1, 22, 345047) I have only enough strength to enable me to meet every situation as it arises in the course of my quest for truth.
('55', 182, 1, 23, 345162) That is to say, I am no Shastri, and only a person learned enough to write a Shastra can compose a smriti.
('55', 182, 1, 24, 345269) This suggestion was first made to me by Kishorelal.
('55', 182, 1, 25, 345321) I would certainly write such a treatise if I could.
('55', 182, 1, 26, 345373) I would be fortunate, however, if I can use rightly whatever powers God has given me.
('55', 182, 1, 27, 345459) We three are quite well.
('55', 182, 1, 28, 345484) The third is Mahadev.
('55', 182, 1, 29, 345506) [PS.] I see nothing wrong in your trying without concern for the result to come to see me.
('55', 182, 1, 30, 345597) I would be very happy if you succeed.

('55', 187, 1, 2, 351039) 222. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('55', 187, 2, 3, 351070) April 3, 1932
('55', 187, 3, 4, 351084) NARANDAS, Generally I get your letters on Wednesday immediately on arrival.
('55', 187, 3, 5, 351160) This time, too, I have received a beautiful question from Indu: “Can we practise sword and dagger exercises in the Ashram?” 1 I don’t know or remember when swords and daggers were introduced in the Ashram.
('55', 187, 3, 6, 351366) Nor do I remember whether, if they were introduced when I was there, I had been consulted.
('55', 187, 3, 7, 351457) Whether or not I was, I now think that these things have no place in the Ashram.
('55', 187, 3, 8, 351538) All of you should sit together and think over this matter and, if you feel that their introduction cannot be defended in any way, get rid of them immediately.
('55', 187, 3, 9, 351697) It seems to me that keeping lathis is the utmost limit to which we can go.
('55', 187, 3, 10, 351772) However, you and other responsible inmates of the Ashram should think independently over this matter and discuss it among yourselves.
('55', 187, 3, 11, 351906) If there are any other issues besides this, small or big, you should think over them too.
('55', 187, 3, 12, 351996) The other problem is about illness.
('55', 187, 3, 13, 352032) Anybody who falls ill, as Indu did, as soon as he or she comes to live in the Ashram, should be sent away to some other place.
('55', 187, 3, 14, 352159) For instance, Jamna 2 has returned there after gaining 12 lb.
('55', 187, 3, 15, 352221) of weight.
('55', 187, 3, 16, 352232) If she were to lose it all now, I would certainly feel very unhappy.
('55', 187, 3, 17, 352301) If a person keeps better health at some other place than he does in the Ashram, it would be good both for him and for the Ashram to send him to stay at that place.
('55', 187, 3, 18, 352465) We should try and discover the deficiencies of the Ashram because of which some persons do not keep good health there.
('55', 187, 3, 19, 352584) The water there is of course one cause, but there may be other factors too.
('55', 187, 3, 20, 352660) These are air and food.
('55', 187, 3, 21, 352684) We should find out if we are polluting the air in any way.
('55', 187, 3, 22, 352743) For this, we should examine whether the arrangements for the disposal of night soil and the excreta of cattle are satisfactory.
('55', 187, 3, 23, 352871) If Anandi is always ill, she should be sent somewhere.
('55', 187, 3, 24, 352926) Sharda told me that if I did not object, Velanbehn would send Anandi to live with her at Matheran.
('55', 187, 3, 25, 353025) Really speaking, my permission is not required at all.
('55', 187, 3, 26, 353080) It is for you to decide whether or not she should be permitted to go.
('55', 187, 3, 27, 353150) Personally, I see no objection to the suggestion.
('55', 187, 3, 28, 353200) At present, her expenses even in Deolali are borne by us.
('55', 187, 3, 29, 353258) If, therefore, Anandi can be

('55', 189, 2, 3, 355697) April 3, 1932
('55', 189, 3, 4, 355711) PREMA, I got your letter.
('55', 189, 3, 5, 355737) Indu has put me some fine questions.
('55', 189, 3, 6, 355774) Why should we do in the Ashram exercises with swords, jamaiya 1, etc.?
('55', 189, 3, 7, 355845) I have discussed this question in my letter 2 to Narandas.
('55', 189, 3, 8, 355904) Hence I do not say any thing about it here.
('55', 189, 3, 9, 355948) I have mentioned the question only to ask you whether it has also occurred to you, since you have been yourself learning these exercises.
('55', 189, 3, 10, 356086) I would not give to the Ashram the certificate which you do.
('55', 189, 3, 11, 356147) I would certainly be happy if it really deserved such a certificate.
('55', 189, 3, 12, 356216) You may have formed the impression that any person in the Ashram who takes up some work becomes wholly absorbed in it, but your impression is not correct.
('55', 189, 3, 13, 356371) Are we able to observe the Ashram vows faithfully?
('55', 189, 3, 14, 356422) It had been decided to teach Hindi, Urdu, Tamil, Telugu and Sanskrit in the Ashram, but we made only a half hearted effort.
('55', 189, 3, 15, 356546) Have we acquired proficiency in tanning?
('55', 189, 3, 16, 356587) Do we spin fine yarn of the highest count?
('55', 189, 3, 17, 356630) I can point to many such deficiencies, but what I have said is enough to justify my questioning [your certificate].
('55', 189, 3, 18, 356746) Everyone can pay single minded attention to lathi exercises.
('55', 189, 3, 19, 356807) But we can say likewise that everyone runs after sweets.
('55', 189, 3, 20, 356864) There are indeed many things in the world the pursuit of which requires no strenuous effort.
('55', 189, 3, 21, 356957) Since we are also animals in our nature, this quality [of pursuing a thing with single minded attention] is instinctive in us.
('55', 189, 3, 22, 357084) It does not have to be cultivated.
('55', 189, 3, 23, 357119) The question is whether or not [in a particular case] it deserves to be cultivated.
('55', 189, 3, 24, 357203) Every property of animal nature need not of course be regarded as something to be shunned.
('55', 189, 3, 25, 357294) How many persons take meals in the common kitchen these days?
('55', 189, 3, 26, 357356) Do you still make bread in the Ashram?
('55', 189, 3, 27, 357395) If yes, who is in charge of the work?
('55', 189, 3, 28, 357433) If you make good bread, send a loaf or two with any person who may come to see me.
('55', 189, 3, 29, 357516) If anyone from the Ashram meets Lakshmi, he or she should tell her that I do not remember not having replied to any letter from her.

('55', 190, 1, 2, 357731) She should, therefore, write to me.

There is, of course, this truth in my remark, that if a person asks another who loves him or her to criticize him or her, he or she will hear only praise, for love covers defects as with a veil, or sees them as virtues.
('55', 190, 1, 13, 358550) It is the nature of love that it prompts one to point out on occasion the defects of the beloved one because one wants to see perfection in the person whom one loves.

('55', 191, 0, 1, 359640) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 191, 1, 2, 359682) 224. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN Sunday, April 3, [1932] 1
('55', 191, 2, 3, 359736) DEAR SISTERS, Since I cannot write with the left hand as fast as I can with the right, I dictate this letter instead of writing it.
('55', 191, 2, 4, 359868) ‘Whatever women do, how can you, being their elder, employ satyagraha against them?’ There is a big flaw in this argument and it is based on a misunderstanding of the nature of satyagraha.
('55', 191, 2, 5, 360057) In that question, you equate satyagraha with duragraha 2. Satyagraha makes no distinction between the young and the old, the prince and the pauper.
('55', 191, 2, 6, 360205) God also employs satyagraha against us.
('55', 191, 2, 7, 360245) His satyagraha is unceasing.
('55', 191, 2, 8, 360274) In essence, satyagraha means simply this—scrupulous regard for truth.
('55', 191, 2, 9, 360344) If God did not adhere to truth, the whole world would perish in an instant.
('55', 191, 2, 10, 360420) The point is that offering satyagraha is as much a duty as it is a privilege.
('55', 191, 2, 11, 360498) But I shall now take your own instance.
('55', 191, 2, 12, 360538) If you do not discuss my letters among yourselves and reply to them, I really need not write to you every week.
('55', 191, 2, 13, 360650) Even if I write, my letters will have no value and no effect.
('55', 191, 2, 14, 360712) A lover of truth never writes or speaks merely for the sake of writing or speaking.
('55', 191, 2, 15, 360796) There must be some definite purpose in his writing or speaking.
('55', 191, 2, 16, 360860) Ordinarily he should observe complete silence.
('55', 191, 2, 17, 360907) Really speaking, there can be nothing for me to tell you or anybody else, particularly while I am in prison.
('55', 191, 2, 18, 361016) Though I am imprisoned, the Government permits me to maintain limited contact with the outside world, and I avail myself of that freedom.
('55', 191, 2, 19, 361154) But I should do so only for writing letters with a definite aim.
('55', 191, 2, 20, 361219) A person like me should teach what he wishes to teach only through his own conduct.
('55', 191, 2, 21, 361303) Those who do not learn from my actions, how can they learn from my words?
('55', 191, 2, 22, 361377) This is the general rule.
('55', 191, 2, 23, 361403) But there are persons in the Ashram as also outside it who regard my manner of life as worth following and, for that very reason, want me to explain my ideas more clearly.
('55', 191, 2, 24, 361575) It is my duty to write to them.
('55', 191, 2, 25, 361607) You are included among these persons, but only if you ask me some questions.

('55', 192, 1, 2, 361991) I know that you feel shy.

('55', 192, 1, 4, 362042) You do what service you can and say nothing.
('55', 192, 1, 5, 362087) That is perfectly right, and it befits you.
('55', 192, 1, 6, 362131) But even though we should learn to live in that manner, after all we have to mix with one another.
('55', 192, 1, 7, 362230) Living in the Ashram means that we should live as a small community, that is, live together, have our meals together, work and spend our free time together and think together.
('55', 192, 1, 8, 362406) This is the meaning of the mantra which we recite before commencing every meal.
('55', 192, 1, 9, 362486) Animals also have some capacity for living and moving together.

('55', 192, 1, 22, 363578) She asks why women, not only the women in the Ashram but all women with whom she has come in contact, look as if they were dead and have no spirit in them at all.
('55', 192, 1, 23, 363741) There is some truth in her description, though of course it will not apply to all women.
('55', 192, 1, 24, 363830) The reasons which I have been able to discover are these: (1) lack of order in women’s life; (2) excessive worries; (3) wrong upbringing; (4) adoption of unscientific measures at the time of child birth and during confinement; (5) lack of exercise; (6) eating food which is harmful to health; (7) the habit of remaining within the four walls of the home; (8) the habit of eating things which they ought not to eat; (9) in many cases, harmful thoughts which they do not try to regulate wisely, but repress.
('55', 192, 1, 25, 364336) These are the reasons which I can think of.
('55', 192, 1, 26, 364380) I do not mean that all of them apply in every case.
('55', 192, 1, 27, 364432) Every woman should think and find out which reason applies in her own case.
('55', 192, 1, 28, 364508) I have observed one great
('55', 193, 0, 1, 364534) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 193, 1, 2, 364576) defect in our women, namely, that they hide their thoughts from the world.
('55', 193, 1, 3, 364651) As a result, their behaviour becomes hypocritical.
('55', 193, 1, 4, 364702) This can happen only to those who are habitually hypocritical.
('55', 193, 1, 5, 364765) I do not know anything in the world so poisonous as hypocrisy, and especially when the evil affects our middle class women who are suppressed throughout their lives it eats them up like a canker.
('55', 193, 1, 6, 364961) At every step they do things which they dislike in their hearts, and believe that they must do them.

('55', 193, 1, 8, 365182) If they learn this first lesson and cultivate the courage to stand before the world just as they are, they will be able to eliminate the other causes which I have mentioned.
('55', 193, 1, 9, 365356) According to me, this is a very important letter.

('55', 203, 2, 3, 382870) April 7, 1932
('55', 203, 3, 4, 382884) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letters and enclosures, also copy of an article of yours in an old number of Modern Review.
('55', 203, 3, 5, 383005) I understand and even appreciate the moral repulsion against ‘fasting unto death’.
('55', 203, 3, 6, 383088) I have perhaps some repulsion, if not the same repulsion, against fasting unto death myself, but I remain unmoved.
('55', 203, 3, 7, 383203) There are many other things I have done and am still doing against my will, because I count my will as nothing before God’s will when I see it clearly before me.
('55', 203, 3, 8, 383365) I will make myself as certain as it is humanly possible to be, that the will that appears to me to be God’s is really His, and not the Devil’s.
('55', 203, 3, 9, 383509) But when I am clear about it, I rejoice in obeying that will, rather than mine, although I have no human companion to endorse it.
('55', 203, 3, 10, 383639) That this kind of fasting has a definite place in Hinduism, and properly so, I have not a shadow of a doubt, but it is a privilege that comes only to a few, and when it comes in obedience to a call from above, it has a mighty force.
('55', 203, 3, 11, 383872) Only, fasting unto death is a corrupt expression.
('55', 203, 3, 12, 383922) When I used it first, it had its definite meaning.
('55', 203, 3, 13, 383973) Now it is being used torn from its context and looks certainly barbarous.
('55', 203, 3, 14, 384047) But it is there, and its real meaning is unmistakable, and you can almost say that it is not so much of a ‘fast unto death’ as it is a ‘fasting unto a new life’.

('55', 222, 9, 12, 418146) 266. WATCHING THE HEAVENS—I 4
('55', 222, 10, 13, 418176) A lover of truth feels undiminished joy till the end of his life.
('55', 222, 10, 14, 418242) He never regards himself as too old to keep on striving for a vision of the God of Truth.
('55', 222, 10, 15, 418332) He who undertakes every activity in order to see God, also called Truth, who sees Truth in everything [that exists] will not find old age an obstacle [in his quest].
('55', 222, 10, 16, 418498) So far as that quest is concerned, the seeker regards himself as immortal and for ever young.
('55', 222, 10, 17, 418592) I, for one, have been in this beautiful state of mind for years.
('55', 222, 10, 18, 418657) I have never felt old age as an obstacle to devoting myself to learning anything which I believed would take me nearer to the God of Truth.
('55', 222, 10, 19, 418797) A recent example of this is my desire for a study of the heavens.
('55', 222, 10, 20, 418863) Deep in my heart, I had felt often enough the desire to know something about the stars, but I had assumed that the numerous activities which claimed my attention did not permit me to satisfy it.
('55', 222, 10, 21, 419058) Maybe my belief was wrong, but so long as I did not myself see the error in it it could not but prevent me from making the necessary effort.
('55', 222, 10, 22, 419199) I think most probably I myself had prompted Shankerlal, during our

('55', 223, 1, 2, 419607) imprisonment in 1922 [to take up this study].
('55', 223, 1, 3, 419653) Books on the subject were received.
('55', 223, 1, 4, 419689) Shankerlal picked up enough knowledge to satisfy him.
('55', 223, 1, 5, 419743) I could find no time!
('55', 223, 1, 6, 419765) In 1930 31, I had the good fortune to enjoy Kakasaheb’s company [in jail].
('55', 223, 1, 7, 419840) He was well versed in this subject.
('55', 223, 1, 8, 419876) But I did not avail myself of the opportunity, for my desire was not strong enough then.
('55', 223, 1, 9, 419965) In 1931, I was filled with sudden enthusiasm during the last month of my stay in jail.
('55', 223, 1, 10, 420052) Why should I not give time to watch that which, to the outward eye, instantaneously reveals the presence of God?
('55', 223, 1, 11, 420165) How pathetic that one should see like an animal merely with the physical eye without the grand sight penetrating to the sensory nerves behind?
('55', 223, 1, 12, 420308) How could I let go this fine opportunity to watch the great divine lila 1?
('55', 223, 1, 13, 420383) I am now quenching the thirst which was awakened then for a knowledge of the heavens, and I have progressed so far that I cannot restrain myself from sharing with inmates of the Ashram the thoughts which fill my mind.
('55', 223, 1, 14, 420601) We are taught right from our childhood that our bodies are made of the five great elements—earth, water, akash, light and air.
('55', 223, 1, 15, 420728) We ought to know something about them, but in fact we know very little.
('55', 223, 1, 16, 420800) At the moment we are concerned with akash.
('55', 223, 1, 17, 420843) Akash means space.
('55', 223, 1, 18, 420862) If there were no space in our bodies, we would not be able to live even for a moment.
('55', 223, 1, 19, 420948) This is true about the universe too.
('55', 223, 1, 20, 420985) Our earth is surrounded by infinite space.
('55', 223, 1, 21, 421028) The blue which we see extending over us in all directions is akash.
('55', 223, 1, 22, 421096) The earth has poles.
('55', 223, 1, 23, 421117) It is a solid sphere, and its axis is 7,900 miles long.
('55', 223, 1, 24, 421173) But the akash is empty space.
('55', 223, 1, 25, 421203) If we imagine this space to have an axis, we shall have to imagine it to be of infinite length.
('55', 223, 1, 26, 421299) In this infinite space, the earth is like a mere particle of sand, and on this particle of sand each one of us is a particle, of such infinitesimal size that it is impossible to explain how small it is.
('55', 223, 1, 27, 421502) There is, therefore, no exaggeration at all in saying that, as bodies, we are mere ciphers.
('55', 223, 1, 28, 421594) Our body, as compared with the size of the earth, is a thousand times more insignificant than an ant’s is as compared with ours.
('55', 223, 1, 29, 421723) Why, then, should we feel attached to it?
('55', 223, 1, 30, 421765) Why should we grieve when a body perishes?
('55', 223, 1, 31, 421808) However, though in itself the human body is insignificant, it has indeed great value, for it is the house of the atman, in truth of the Paramatman, of the God of Truth, if we but realize it.
('55', 223, 2, 32, 421999) 1 Play, sport
('55', 224, 0, 1, 422013) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 225
('55', 224, 1, 2, 422059) If this thought sinks deep into our heart, we would never want to make it an instrument of enjoying gross pleasures.
('55', 224, 1, 3, 422176) And if we fill our imagination with the heavens and, realizing the meaning of their vastness, understand our utter insignificance, all our pride would vanish.
('55', 224, 1, 4, 422335) If the countless shining divinities in the sky did not exist, we would not have come into existence.
('55', 224, 1, 5, 422436) Inspite of the many discoveries of astronomers, our knowledge about the sky is practically nil.
('55', 224, 1, 6, 422532) What little we know tells us beyond the shadow of a doubt that if the sun god rested even for a day from his ever ceaseless tapascharya, we would perish.
('55', 224, 1, 7, 422686) Likewise, if the moon stopped raining down her cool rays, we would meet with the same fate.
('55', 224, 1, 8, 422778) And we can also infer that the countless stars which we see in the sky at night have some role in maintaining this world in existence.
('55', 224, 1, 9, 422913) Thus, we are most intimately connected with every living creature in the world and with everything that exists; everything depends for its existence on everything else.
('55', 224, 1, 10, 423082) Hence we ought to try and know something about our benefactors the shining divinities gliding in the sky.
('55', 224, 1, 11, 423188) There is one more reason why we ought to do this.
('55', 224, 1, 12, 423238) We have a saying among us: “The hills look beautiful from a distance.” There is much truth in this saying.
('55', 224, 1, 13, 423345) The sun, which keeps us alive from a distance, would instantly burn us to ashes if we went near it.
('55', 224, 1, 14, 423445) This is also true about the other heavenly bodies.
('55', 224, 1, 15, 423496) Since we know both the beneficial and the harmful properties of the things which surround us on this earth, we may sometimes feel aversion to them and even feel ourselves polluted by physical contact with some of them.
('55', 224, 1, 16, 423715) Of the divinities in the sky, however, we know only the merits.
('55', 224, 1, 17, 423779) Hence we never tire of watching them.
('55', 224, 1, 18, 423817) Knowledge about them can never harm us.
('55', 224, 1, 19, 423857) Moreover, as we meditate on these divinities, we can raise our imagination with ennobling ideas as high as we wish.
('55', 224, 1, 20, 423973) There is no doubt at all that every obstacle which we place between ourselves and the sky harms us physically, mentally and spiritually.
('55', 224, 1, 21, 424110) If we lived in a natural state, we would live under the sky for all the twenty four hours of the day.
('55', 224, 1, 22, 424212) If we cannot do that, we should spend in the open as many hours as we can.
('55', 224, 1, 23, 424287) We can watch the heavens, i.e., the stars, only at night, and we can do that best Iying on our backs.
('55', 224, 1, 24, 424389) Hence, anybody who wishes to derive the utmost profit from the observation of the stars should sleep in the open directly under the sky.
('55', 224, 1, 25, 424526) If there are tall buildings or trees near the place where one is sleeping, they will obstruct the view.
('55', 225, 0, 1, 424630) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 225, 1, 2, 424672) Both children and grown ups love dramas and the spectacular scenes which they present.
('55', 225, 1, 3, 424759) But no drama composed or acted by human beings can even equal the great spectacle which Nature has arranged for us on the stage of the sky.
('55', 225, 1, 4, 424899) Moreover, in a theatre we may harm our eyes, breathe unclean air and also run a great risk of our moral sense being weakened.
('55', 225, 1, 5, 425025) On the other hand, this drama arranged by Nature can do us nothing but good.
('55', 225, 1, 6, 425102) Watching the stars soothes the eyes; to watch the stars, one must remain outdoors, and this gives fresh air to the lungs; and we have heard of no instance so far of harm having been done to moral character by watching the stars.
('55', 225, 1, 7, 425331) The more we meditate on this miracle of God, the more we grow spiritually.
('55', 225, 1, 8, 425406) Anybody who is afflicted by impure thoughts and gets dreams in his sleep should try to sleep in the open and let himself be absorbed in watching the stars.
('55', 225, 1, 9, 425562) He will soon fall into dreamless sleep.
('55', 225, 1, 10, 425602) When we are totally absorbed in the grand spectacle in the heavens, we seem to hear those shining bodies in their utter silence, singing the praise of God.

('55', 230, 8, 16, 435858) 271. LETTER TO BEHRAMJI KHAMBHATTA
('55', 230, 9, 17, 435893) April 12, 1932
('55', 230, 10, 18, 435908) BHAISHRI KHAMBHATTA, I got your letter just when I had been thinking of you and wondering why there was no letter from you.
('55', 230, 10, 19, 436032) I gather from it that your health is all right.
('55', 230, 10, 20, 436080) I did get in course of time the letter which you wrote to me from England, and I have the impression that I also replied to it.
('55', 230, 10, 21, 436208) I am not aware that I always keep my hand under the head when sleeping.
('55', 230, 10, 22, 436280) It is possible that the hand got under the head sometimes.
('55', 230, 10, 23, 436339) I was careful in the matter after I got your letter and remained vigilant.
('55', 230, 10, 24, 436414) I can say, therefore, that I have never kept the hand in that position since then.
('55', 230, 10, 25, 436497) However, that seems to have had no effect on the condition of the hand.
('55', 230, 10, 26, 436569) No one has yet been able to make out the cause of this weakness.
('55', 230, 10, 27, 436634) As a precaution I even gave up writing with the right hand.
('55', 230, 10, 28, 436694) But afterwards the doctors also came to the conclusion that the pain was not caused by writer’s cramp.
('55', 230, 10, 29, 436797) If your massaging the hand is likely to cure the pain, I can certainly secure the necessary permission.
('55', 230, 10, 30, 436901) However, if you explain to me the exact manner of doing
('55', 231, 0, 1, 436957) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 231, 1, 2, 436999) the massage, I would do it myself or ask Mahadev to do it.
('55', 231, 1, 3, 437058) But the fact is that the condition is not worth worrying about at all.
('55', 231, 1, 4, 437129) Nor is the pain continuous.
('55', 231, 1, 5, 437157) It occurs only when I use the hand to do certain things.
('55', 231, 1, 6, 437214) The surgeon here was of the opinion that the pain was a sign of old age and that, therefore, no cure was possible.
('55', 231, 1, 7, 437329) Certain weaknesses generally appear in old age, since we do not exercise sufficient self control in our earlier life.
('55', 231, 1, 8, 437447) This weakness may be one such, and there is no reason for sorrow or wonder if it is so.
('55', 231, 1, 9, 437535) Hence, apart from taking necessary precautions, I do not worry about the matter.
('55', 231, 1, 10, 437616) We have now a new doctor here, who believes that the pain can be cured.
('55', 231, 1, 11, 437688) Let me see what he can do.
('55', 231, 1, 12, 437715) I hope both of you enjoy peace of mind.

('55', 233, 2, 10, 441496) 274. LETTER TO SHANKARRAO DEO 1
('55', 233, 3, 11, 441528) April 15, 1932
('55', 233, 4, 12, 441543) BHAI, I thought at length over your problem, considered it at night too and we three discussed it together.
('55', 233, 4, 13, 441651) The conclusion, in our firm opinion, is that your conception of dharma is in fact adharma.
('55', 233, 4, 14, 441742) During satyagraha, no satyagrahi can take any vow at all connected with it without obtaining the sanction of the President.
('55', 233, 4, 15, 441866) Your interpretation of your vow is a gross distortion.
('55', 233, 4, 16, 441921) The vow of madhukari has no place in the jail.
('55', 233, 4, 17, 441968) You have no right at present to judge whether or not you will have any sense of shame in going out for madukari after the release.
('55', 233, 4, 18, 442099) To envisage now the state of your mind upon leaving the jail would be to claim the role of God Almighty.
('55', 233, 4, 19, 442204) All three of us hold that your duty lies in accepting the food provided for ‘C’ class prisoners in the spirit of an offering to God.
('55', 233, 4, 20, 442337) The duty of a sannyasi indicates the same.
('55', 233, 4, 21, 442380) Now, as regards clothes, the insistence upon wearing khadi only while in jail is in no way proper.
('55', 233, 4, 22, 442479) In this matter the duty of every satyagrahi prisoner is to refrain from insisting on wearing khadi until the Congress takes a decision in this.
('55', 233, 4, 23, 442623) This does not in any way affect your vow of self sufficiency.
('55', 233, 4, 24, 442685) I appeal to you to give up the fast, acknowledge your mistake and start eating.
('55', 233, 4, 25, 442765) It would be beneficial to remain on milk or fruit for a day or two because of the fast.
('55', 233, 4, 26, 442853) I am writing this from the medical point of view only.
('55', 233, 4, 27, 442908) I hope you will
('55', 233, 5, 28, 442924) 1 Addressee’s name is supplied from “Diary, 1932”.
('55', 233, 5, 29, 442975) Mahadev Desai explains: “The addressee was under a vow of self sufficiency in cloth, so that he wore only clothes spun by himself, and secondly he had vowed to live on food obtained by madhukari (begging from a number of houses), and if that was not available, on milk and fruit.” (The Diary of Mahadev Desai)

('55', 238, 1, 2, 448687) 284. LETTER TO PRITHURAJ L. ASAR April 17, 1932 CHI.
('55', 238, 1, 3, 448740) PRITHURAJ, I am addressing this letter c/o the Ashram, as you have not mentioned your address.
('55', 238, 1, 4, 448835) In your excellent letter you say nothing about the hand.
('55', 238, 1, 5, 448892) It is not true that the same person cannot be self reliant and also owe something to his parents.
('55', 238, 1, 6, 448990) Just as one inherits certain physical qualities from one’s parents, so also one may inherit from them wealth and prestige too, It would be false pride to reject them.
('55', 238, 1, 7, 449157) A good son’s duty is to make good use of them and add to them.
('55', 238, 1, 8, 449220) In this way, one should see that one’s own efforts carry forward what the parents had achieved.
('55', 238, 1, 9, 449316) We should listen to everybody’s advice, but do only what our conscience tells us.

('55', 238, 1, 11, 449519) We need divine ears to hear it.
('55', 238, 1, 12, 449551) Your handwriting shows considerable improvement, but it has not yet become sufficiently well formed.

('55', 239, 7, 12, 450877) 287. WATCHING THE HEAVENS II 1
('55', 239, 8, 13, 450908) April 18, 1932
('55', 239, 9, 14, 450923) There are many fanciful stories about the cluster of stars of which I drew a figure last time.
('55', 239, 9, 15, 451018) 2 No figure of this cluster shows all the stars in it.
('55', 239, 9, 16, 451073) Actually, there are many more stars than you will see in any such figure.
('55', 239, 9, 17, 451147) Hence the best thing is for everybody to make his or her own drawing and show by dots as many stars as can be seen with the naked eye.
('55', 239, 9, 18, 451282) If we follow this practice, we shall learn to recognize the different constellations much more quickly.
('55', 239, 9, 19, 451386) Moreover, the drawings which we ourselves make will be much better for our purpose than those we find in books, for, when the stars are observed from different places there are bound to be differences in the drawings which represent them.
('55', 239, 9, 20, 451625) It would be advisable for everybody to observe the stars from a fixed place and at a fixed time.
('55', 239, 9, 21, 451722) This suggestion is meant for those who wish to make drawings or who are beginners.
('55', 239, 9, 22, 451805) After we have become familiar with the different constellations, we shall be able to recognize these heavenly friends of ours, or these divinities, from wherever we observe them.
('55', 239, 9, 23, 451984) The Hindu, a daily of Madras, publishes a weekly, as does The Times of Bombay.
('55', 239, 9, 24, 452063) Both of them give maps of the sky showing the
('55', 239, 10, 25, 452109) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, vide the following item.
('55', 239, 10, 26, 452190) 2Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11 4 1932
('55', 240, 0, 1, 452235) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 241
('55', 240, 1, 2, 452281) constellations visible during each month.
('55', 240, 1, 3, 452323) The Hindu gives such a map in its issue of the first week and The Times gives it in its issue of the second week.
('55', 240, 1, 4, 452437) If you can get either of these maps, you will learn much from it.
('55', 240, 1, 5, 452503) The hundredth number of Kumar is due to be published.
('55', 240, 1, 6, 452557) Shri Hiralal Shah has contributed some articles on this subject for that number.
('55', 240, 1, 7, 452638) He seems to have made a deep study of the subject.
('55', 240, 1, 8, 452689) Everybody who is curious may read those articles.
('55', 240, 1, 9, 452739) Having read those articles, I don’t feel inclined to write much here.
('55', 240, 1, 10, 452809) I will only explain a little more clearly my point of view in studying the sky.
('55', 240, 1, 11, 452889) If I attempt more, I shall not be able to write on other subjects along with my weekly letters.
('55', 240, 1, 12, 452985) I may, however, write something occasionally, or in reply to somebody’s question.
('55', 240, 1, 13, 453067) The constellation of which I drew a figure is known among us as Mriga or Mrigashirsha.
('55', 240, 1, 14, 453154) One of the months got its name, Margashirsha—Magshar—from this.
('55', 240, 1, 15, 453218) The months in our calendar got their names from the respective constellations.
('55', 240, 1, 16, 453297) In the West, the Mriga is known as “Orion”.
('55', 240, 1, 17, 453341) The constellation is imagined to be a hunter.
('55', 240, 1, 18, 453387) To its east, there are two very bright stars in a straight line.
('55', 240, 1, 19, 453452) They are imagined to be the hunter’s dogs.
('55', 240, 1, 20, 453495) The star in the west is the bigger dog and the one to the north is the smaller dog.
('55', 240, 1, 21, 453579) The cluster of stars which we see to its east and south, below the star which forms the fourth angle of the figure, is imagined to be a hare.
('55', 240, 1, 22, 453721) The dogs are running towards it.
('55', 240, 1, 23, 453754) The three stars in the middle are the jewels in the hunter’s waist band.
('55', 240, 1, 24, 453827) Those stars have also been shown as representing the following figures: The bigger of the two dogs is called Lubdhak among us, and those three stars represent the deer’s stomach.
('55', 240, 1, 25, 454006) The stars to the south represent the arrow shot by Lubdhak.
('55', 240, 1, 26, 454066) The three stars to the north outside the rectangle represent the deer’s head.
('55', 240, 1, 27, 454144) These may be beautiful fancies.
('55', 240, 1, 28, 454176) A great deal has been written about their origin, but personally I have read very little of all this.
('55', 240, 1, 29, 454278) There is, of course, no such figure in the sky.
('55', 240, 1, 30, 454326) Nor are the stars as near to us as they seem.
('55', 240, 1, 31, 454372) They are not what they look, but are suns far bigger than our sun.
('55', 240, 1, 32, 454439) Being millions and millions of miles away from us, they twinkle in the sky as mere points.
('55', 240, 1, 33, 454530) Our knowledge about these suns is very little.
('55', 240, 1, 34, 454577) But these dusters of stars serve the most illiterate as their friends.
('55', 240, 1, 35, 454648) If one looks at them even for a second, one would forget all one’s misery and burst forth into praise of God’s supreme greatness.
('55', 240, 1, 36, 454778) One would realize that the stars were God’s
('55', 241, 0, 1, 454822) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 241, 1, 2, 454864) messengers and kept watch and guarded us every night and consoled us in our suffering.
('55', 241, 1, 3, 454951) This is the real truth.
('55', 241, 1, 4, 454975) That they are suns and that they are very far from us are mere intellectual conceptions.
('55', 241, 1, 5, 455064) Their service to us in filling us with an awareness of God is the real truth for us.
('55', 241, 1, 6, 455149) From a scientific point of view, we may know a good many properties of water, but may not make any use of our knowledge.
('55', 241, 1, 7, 455270) The knowledge that it is something with which we can quench our thirst and keep our bodies clean, and its use for such purposes, are very important for us and this knowledge of the utility of water is for us the truth about it, even if, in real fact, it is a substance with other properties and uses too.
('55', 241, 1, 8, 455575) And the same is true about the stars.
('55', 241, 1, 9, 455613) They serve us in many ways.
('55', 241, 1, 10, 455641) I have drawn attention to what seems to me their chief function and suggested that one should fix one’s mind on that and benefit from their message.
('55', 241, 1, 11, 455790) This is what people seem to have always done from the oldest times.
('55', 241, 1, 12, 455858) In the course of time, however, all kindsof other stories spread and the various myths concerning the stars arose.
('55', 241, 1, 13, 455973) We may certainly read all this in order to make the study more interesting, but we should not lose sight of the primary benefit which I have suggested.
('55', 241, 1, 14, 456125) Let us now turn our attention to two other groups to the north of Mriga.
('55', 241, 1, 15, 456198) The bigger group is known as the Saptarshi 1, and the smaller one is called Dhruvamatsya 2. I have shown seven stars in each group, but there are many more in the Saptarshi.
('55', 241, 1, 16, 456372) They are shown in the drawings which appear in The Times and The Hindu weeklies.
('55', 241, 1, 17, 456453) In Dhruvamatsya we shall not see more.
('55', 241, 1, 18, 456492) It being the bright half of the month just now, we can see only three, two members of the rectangle and the one at the end of the tail, which is called Dhruva 3. This is the only star which remains practically fixed and that is why it was a great help to sailors in old days.
('55', 241, 1, 19, 456768) Both these groups seem to revolve round Dhruva.
('55', 241, 1, 20, 456816) Here we find it very interesting to watch their motion every night.
('55', 241, 1, 21, 456884) Their positions change continually all through the night.
('55', 241, 1, 22, 456942) If we noted these positions from time to time, we would find that they trace quite a big arch.
('55', 241, 1, 23, 457037) In the West, these two groups are called the Great Bear and the Little Bear respectively.
('55', 241, 1, 24, 457127) In one of the books, I even saw beautiful drawings of them.
('55', 241, 1, 25, 457187) The Great Bear is also known as the
('55', 241, 2, 26, 457223) 1 The Great Bear; literally, ‘the seven sages’ 2 The Little Bear; literally ‘the Dhruva fish’ 3 The Pole star
('55', 242, 0, 1, 457333) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 243
('55', 242, 1, 2, 457379) plough.
('55', 242, 1, 3, 457387) The Saptarshi serves as a clock during the night.
('55', 242, 1, 4, 457437) After some experience, we can always know the time of the night from the position of the Saptarshi.
('55', 242, 1, 5, 457537) However valuable these benefits and however interesting these names may be, they seem insignificant to me in comparison with the primary benefit.
('55', 242, 1, 6, 457683) We should aspire to be as pure as the sky and as bright as the stars.
('55', 242, 1, 7, 457753) We should pray to God, as the latter seem to be doing in their silence.
('55', 242, 1, 8, 457825) Just as they do not depart from their paths even for a moment, so let us never be remiss in doing what we are expected to do.

('55', 247, 6, 9, 468186) 293. A LETTER
('55', 247, 7, 10, 468200) April 18, 1932
('55', 247, 8, 11, 468215) CHI., If ever our sister or any helpless person is assaulted by someone, we should try to save her even at the cost of our life.

('55', 254, 1, 4, 480256) Looked at from this point of view, the verses which you have quoted from the Gita can be reconciled with one another.

('55', 257, 8, 9, 486995) 306. A LETTER
('55', 257, 9, 10, 487009) April 19, 1932
('55', 257, 10, 11, 487024) MY DEAR, We are all sons of rishis and there should be no pride of priestly or any other class.
('55', 257, 10, 12, 487120) Priests are servants, voluntarily, of the people, and so are Kshatriyas.
('55', 257, 10, 13, 487193) And to keep up one’s vow is the duty not merely of the priest and the warrior but of all mankind.
('55', 257, 10, 14, 487291) Therefore I should have respected your vow taken with deliberation and in a worthy manner without regard to your class.
('55', 257, 10, 15, 487411) But if you will respect your vow [you] must surround it with all the protection it needs, i.e., you must take all the rest that your system requires so that your vow may not be discredited and so that it may not be unduly tried.
('55', 257, 10, 16, 487640) Your decision not to draw anything save for your absolute necessity is quite good.

('55', 258, 1, 2, 487805) 307. LETTER TO SURENDRAJI
('55', 258, 2, 3, 487831) April 19, 1932
('55', 258, 3, 4, 487846) Your letter did not require immediate reply, and I also thought that as a prisoner I should keep myself within proper limits.
('55', 258, 3, 5, 487972) Hence I delayed replying to you.
('55', 258, 3, 6, 488005) I have completely forgotten what you had said in your previous letter (written to me when I was in England).
('55', 258, 3, 7, 488114) You should never hesitate to write to me anything you think about me.
('55', 258, 3, 8, 488184) It would be a weakness in you to feel such hesitation.
('55', 258, 3, 9, 488239) If friends and co workers put before me their criticism whenever they think that I am committing an error, I would learn much from it, because there would be no malice in their criticism.
('55', 258, 3, 10, 488427) Moreover, if we are displeased with anything which a friend may have done, it is a test of our friendship and love for him to tell him immediately what has displeased us.
('55', 258, 3, 11, 488598) Love is not love if it hesitates to speak out through consideration for the feelings of the person loved.
('55', 258, 3, 12, 488704) In the statement, “true brahmacharya is that which remains inviolate in any condition” 1, the word ‘condition’ should be understood comprehensively.
('55', 258, 3, 13, 488853) That is true brahmacharya which does not succumb to any temptation or allurement.
('55', 258, 3, 14, 488935) If a beautiful young woman makes advances to the stone image of a man, there will be no effect on the latter.
('55', 258, 3, 15, 489045) A man is a true brahmachari if, in similar circumstances, he remains like a stone.
('55', 258, 3, 16, 489128) And that image neither hears with its ears nor sees with its eyes.
('55', 258, 3, 17, 489195) Similarly, a man also should not go seeking temptations.
('55', 258, 3, 18, 489252) Anybody who does that is not a brahmachari.
('55', 258, 3, 19, 489296) A brahmachari should not knowingly do anything which may be regarded as a sign of lust.
('55', 258, 3, 20, 489384) But your chief contention is this, that the sight and company of women are found in experience to be inimical to self control and must, therefore, be avoided.
('55', 258, 3, 21, 489543) This reasoning seems wrong to me.
('55', 258, 3, 22, 489577) That is not true self control or brahmacharya which can be preserved only by avoiding even such association with women as may occur in the ordinary course and is necessitated by our work of service.
('55', 258, 3, 23, 489776) It is only outward renunciation uninspired by genuine desirelessness.
('55', 258, 3, 24, 489846) The suppressed craving is bound to break through when it gets a suitable opportunity.
('55', 258, 3, 25, 489932) Scripture tells us that our pleasure
('55', 258, 4, 26, 489969) 1Vide “Letter to Surendraji”,4 4 1932
('55', 259, 0, 1, 490007) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 259, 1, 2, 490049) in sense objects does not disappear completely till we have had a vision of the Supreme.
('55', 259, 1, 3, 490138) 1 But the converse is equally true.
('55', 259, 1, 4, 490174) Till our pleasure in sense objects has disappeared completely, we cannot see the Supreme.
('55', 259, 1, 5, 490264) In other words, our progress in regard to both is simultaneous.
('55', 259, 1, 6, 490328) The meaning of the last statement should be carefully understood.
('55', 259, 1, 7, 490394) Our pleasure in sense objects does indeed disappear only after we have had a vision of the Supreme.
('55', 259, 1, 8, 490494) That is, though our cravings may have subsided, our instinctive pleasure in sense objects will have survived somewhere deep in us and, therefore, till we have seen the Supreme there will always be a possibility of the cravings being aroused again.
('55', 259, 1, 9, 490742) After the vision of the Supreme, there can be no cravings whatsoever.
('55', 259, 1, 10, 490812) That means that such a man loses the consciousness of sex and becomes sexless.
('55', 259, 1, 11, 490891) That is to say, he ceases to be a figure and becomes a cipher, in other words, loses his self in God.
('55', 259, 1, 12, 490993) When craving has ceased altogether, there can be no pleasure in sense objects.
('55', 259, 1, 13, 491072) I think this is easy enough to understand.
('55', 259, 1, 14, 491115) If in this discussion we substitute the word ‘Truth’ wherever the words ‘Supreme’, ‘God’, ‘Brahman’, ‘Parabrahman’, etc., occur, the argument will be clear and it will also be easy to understand the meaning of realization.
('55', 259, 1, 15, 491338) Self deception will not avail anybody here.
('55', 259, 1, 16, 491382) Those in the Ashram who, under the pretext of living according to the ideal of the Ashram being one family, gratify their lustful fancies mentally are the hypocrites of Chapter III [of the Gita].
('55', 259, 1, 17, 491578) Here we are talking about persons who scrupulously follow Truth and are considering how they should behave.
('55', 259, 1, 18, 491686) Hence, even if ninety nine per cent of the inmates of the Ashram act as above, so long as the remaining one percent sincerely try to live according to our ideal of the Ashram being one family, the aim of the Ashram will have been fulfilled and the manner of life which we have deliberately adopted in it will be justified.
('55', 259, 1, 19, 492009) We need not, therefore, think what others do, but consider only what is possible for ourselves.
('55', 259, 1, 20, 492105) But, at the same time, we should also take care not to imitate others without regard to our own limitations.
('55', 259, 1, 21, 492214) 2 Others may claim that they can live freely according to the ideal of our being one family, but we ourselves, if we feel that we do not have such strength, should avoid physical contact with women inmates without disputing the claim of those others.
('55', 259, 1, 22, 492465) We are carrying on a new and dangerous experiment in the Ashram.

('55', 260, 1, 3, 492771) We do not regard it as everybody’s duty to mix freely with the women inmates.

('55', 260, 1, 5, 492891) Those members who can take it without violating dharma may do so, but those who are afraid of violating dharma by such freedom may, even though they live in the Ashram, keep themselves miles away from the company of women.

('55', 260, 1, 22, 494255) All of us have a right to make mistakes.

('55', 260, 1, 25, 494554) And there can be no question that I must have served them better in the measure in which I have succeeded in my effort to observe it.

('55', 261, 1, 2, 494816) 308. LETTER TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH
('55', 261, 2, 3, 494848) YERAVDA MANDIR, April 19, 1932
('55', 261, 3, 4, 494879) SUMANGAL PRAKASH, I have your letter.
('55', 261, 3, 5, 494917) It would have been better if efforts had not been made to have Chandrakanta given ‘A’ class.
('55', 261, 3, 6, 495010) But what is done is done.
('55', 261, 3, 7, 495036) Now she must give up the facilities of ‘A’ class or make the very least use of them.
('55', 261, 3, 8, 495121) I do remember that when I was in England I had a letter from you but I never had any time there to spare and I hardly wrote to anyone in this country.
('55', 261, 3, 9, 495272) Even if you wrote about Kanaiyalal’s death, I have completely forgotten about it.
('55', 261, 3, 10, 495354) What had been the matter with him?
('55', 261, 3, 11, 495389) I also remember about the scheme for the publishing house.
('55', 261, 3, 12, 495448) I do not recollect that I was able to go through it.
('55', 261, 3, 13, 495501) I take it that it is unnecessary now to say anything about it.
('55', 261, 3, 14, 495564) I had not been given the book about Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi.
('55', 261, 3, 15, 495626) You must, if necessary, follow a strict regimen and put your health in order.
('55', 261, 3, 16, 495704) It is now more than two months since I gave up milk.
('55', 261, 3, 17, 495757) I give up milk whenever a pretext presents itself and that is what happened this time.
('55', 261, 3, 18, 495844) This has not done me any harm and so long as no harm comes from it I shall continue to eschew milk.
('55', 261, 3, 19, 495944) In place of milk I take four tolas of roasted almonds ground to a paste.
('55', 261, 3, 20, 496017) In addition to this I take baked bread, dates, lemon and one vegetable a day such as white gourd, brinjal, etc.
('55', 261, 3, 21, 496129) I take sour lemon with soda bi carb.
('55', 261, 3, 22, 496166) In the early morning I have honey in hot water with a little soda.
('55', 261, 3, 23, 496233) That is my diet.
('55', 261, 3, 24, 496250) You are not to copy this.
('55', 261, 3, 25, 496276) You must have chiefly milk, curd and fresh fruit.
('55', 261, 3, 26, 496326) If you still feel hungry you may take greens and chapati or bread, but this is not to be a substitute for milk and fresh fruit.
('55', 261, 3, 27, 496454) It is difficult, if not impossible, to say how long my body will endure.
('55', 261, 3, 28, 496527) Whatever I may say will only be guessing.
('55', 261, 3, 29, 496569) I can not claim that my life has been one of self control from the beginning.
('55', 261, 3, 30, 496647) I have indulged myself in some form or other and so I cannot take from the body as much work as I should like.
('55', 261, 3, 31, 496758) Most of the others, too, are poorin health and, therefore, either do not see my physical weakness or ignore it.
('55', 261, 3, 32, 496870) Be that as it may.
('55', 261, 3, 33, 496889) All that I wish is that the few years that are left to me should be spent in some work or other of service.
('55', 261, 3, 34, 496997) It will
('55', 262, 0, 1, 497005) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 263
('55', 262, 1, 2, 497051) be enough if I am not condemned to live the life of an invalid.
('55', 262, 1, 3, 497115) The full span of a man’s life is a hundred years.
('55', 262, 1, 4, 497165) For the reasons explained above I do not consider myself fit to reach that age.
('55', 262, 1, 5, 497245) It is good to have the teeth scraped by a machine.
('55', 262, 1, 6, 497296) Pyorrhoea must be got rid of.
