('55', 262, 4, 10, 497443) 309. LETTER TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH
('55', 262, 5, 11, 497475) YERAVDA MANDIR, April 19, 1932
('55', 262, 6, 12, 497506) BHAI SUMANGAL PRAKASH,
('55', 262, 7, 13, 497529) I have your letter.
('55', 262, 7, 14, 497549) Kanta must not be coerced into giving up the facilities she enjoys.
('55', 262, 7, 15, 497617) So long as she does not herself want to give up the privileges, she should not be made to do so.
('55', 262, 7, 16, 497714) To cite my example is right and not right.
('55', 262, 7, 17, 497757) It is right because so long as I am engaged in public work people are bound to take me as a model, which will only create misunderstandings, because what I expect others to practise I cannot for various reasons practise myself.
('55', 262, 7, 18, 497985) So there is a flaw in my leadership.
('55', 262, 7, 19, 498022) Citing my example might not be right because my position is very different from that of others.
('55', 262, 7, 20, 498118) One reason is my physical weakness.
('55', 262, 7, 21, 498154) Another reason is my title of Mahatma.
('55', 262, 7, 22, 498193) A third reason is my special situation.
('55', 262, 7, 23, 498233) In whatever class I may be I have to have special food, because my body and my vow demand it.
('55', 262, 7, 24, 498327) This applies to some extent to all prisoners.
('55', 262, 7, 25, 498373) It is a different matter that every prisoner cannot have this facility as easily as I can.
('55', 262, 7, 26, 498464) I am permitted interviews once every week instead of once every three months.
('55', 262, 7, 27, 498542) As for letters there is almost no restriction.
('55', 262, 7, 28, 498589) I have decided in my mind that I have no intimate friend.
('55', 262, 7, 29, 498647) I meet relatives, not because they are relatives but because my meeting them serves some moral purpose.
('55', 262, 7, 30, 498751) My writing letters also has the same end in view.
('55', 262, 7, 31, 498801) Whether deep down it gives me some kind of pleasure I do not know.
('55', 262, 7, 32, 498868) Thereseems little likelihood because withdrawal of permission to write letters or to see visitors would not upset me.
('55', 262, 7, 33, 498986) In 1930 I refused to avail myself of the facility of interviews because the Government would not
('55', 263, 0, 1, 499083) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 263, 1, 2, 499125) accept my condition.
('55', 263, 1, 3, 499146) In 1922 I had stopped writing letters.
('55', 263, 1, 4, 499185) Lately I have been kept apart from others.
('55', 263, 1, 5, 499228) That also is a reason.
('55', 263, 1, 6, 499251) One should not make comparisons with me on this account, but if this is not obvious I would not like to persuade anyone by arguments.
('55', 263, 1, 7, 499385) There is no doubt a slight difference between one who has got ‘A’ class after some efforts from outside the jail and one who has been given ‘A’ class by the jail authorities themselves.
('55', 263, 1, 8, 499571) But it is no use stressing this difference.
('55', 263, 1, 9, 499615) The ideal should certainly be that there should be no classification, and where as a result of classification people have been given better classes they should give up the privileges of those classes.
('55', 263, 1, 10, 499816) Very few are today acting up to this idea.
('55', 263, 1, 11, 499859) Therefore one does not want to bring the least pressure to bear on a delicate girl such as Kanta.
('55', 263, 1, 12, 499957) She is a thoughtful girl and on her own practises such self control as she can.
('55', 263, 1, 13, 500037) Kanaiyalal’s untimely demise is distressing.
('55', 263, 1, 14, 500082) But instead of losing courage you must be doubly careful.
('55', 263, 1, 15, 500140) The prayer I made on behalf of Manilal was impelled not by wisdom but by a father’s love for his son.
('55', 263, 1, 16, 500242) Only one prayer is proper and that is “May God do as He wills.” Of course one may ask what meaning this prayer has.
('55', 263, 1, 17, 500358) The answer is that prayer should not be given a gross meaning.
('55', 263, 1, 18, 500421) It means that to free ourselves of attachments we become aware of the God dwelling in our hearts and conceiving Him as separate from us, we pray that we may not be taken where we are impelled by the mind but that we may be taken where God who is our Master takes us.
('55', 263, 1, 19, 500688) Whether our good lies in our dying or in our living we do not know.
('55', 263, 1, 20, 500756) Therefore we should not rejoice in life or tremble at the thought of death.
('55', 263, 1, 21, 500832) We should treat the two as the same and remain untouched.
('55', 263, 1, 22, 500890) This is the ideal and it may take a long time to attain to it.
('55', 263, 1, 23, 500953) Indeed very few can attain to it.
('55', 263, 1, 24, 500987) But this need not discourage us from pursuing it.
('55', 263, 1, 25, 501037) And the more difficulties we face in the pursuit the greater should be our efforts to overcome them.
('55', 263, 1, 26, 501138) If we think over the matter deeply we can conquer the palate.
('55', 263, 1, 27, 501200) We must not accept defeat.
('55', 263, 1, 28, 501227) Man’s full span of life is considered to be a hundred years.
('55', 263, 1, 29, 501288) It can be more but however long it may be, time is an unending stream in which a human lifetime is not even a millionth part of a drop.
('55', 263, 1, 30, 501424) What can therefore attachment for it or calculation about it avail?
('55', 263, 1, 31, 501492) And any calculations we may make can never be definite.
('55', 263, 1, 32, 501548) We can only guess and say at the most how long a human life can be.
('55', 263, 1, 33, 501616) For the rest even the healthiest children meet with untimely
('55', 264, 0, 1, 501677) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 265
('55', 264, 1, 2, 501723) deaths.
('55', 264, 1, 3, 501731) We cannot even say that a man given to lustful pleasures will not enjoy a long life.
('55', 264, 1, 4, 501816) The most we can say is that a man who has been free from lust from the very beginning, who leads a simple life, stands a good chance of enjoying a long life span.
('55', 264, 1, 5, 501979) But to seek to conquer pleasures of sense for the sake of a long life is like digging up a mountain for the sake of a mouse.
('55', 264, 1, 6, 502104) We must conquer sensual pleasures for realizing the Self.
('55', 264, 1, 7, 502162) If self control leads to shortening of life rather than to prolonging it we should not care.
('55', 264, 1, 8, 502255) A life free of disease and long in years is the least significant result of self control.
('55', 264, 1, 9, 502345) Being in jail Kanta naturally cannot practise hydrotherapy.
('55', 264, 1, 10, 502405) Therefore the best way for her is to consult the best doctors.
('55', 264, 1, 11, 502468) It is possible that if she restricts herself to a diet of milk, curd and fruit she may have some relief in the matter of her menstrual trouble and her toothache.
('55', 264, 1, 12, 502630) Relief from pyorrhoea may be attained by chewing a datun for half an hour morning and evening and by massaging the gums inside and outside with a finely ground clean mixture of salt and charcoal powder.
('55', 264, 1, 13, 502833) I am not writing separately to Kanta.
('55', 264, 2, 14, 502871) Blessings from BAPU From the Gujarati original: Sumangal Prakash Papers.

('55', 265, 0, 1, 503670) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 265, 1, 2, 503712) 311. LETTER TO NRISIMHAPRASAD K. BHATT
('55', 265, 2, 3, 503751) April 20, 1932
('55', 265, 3, 4, 503766) My fear has come true.
('55', 265, 3, 5, 503789) You have seen a discrepancy between my advice to you and the fact that I myself toured the country to collect money for the service of the poor.
('55', 265, 3, 6, 503934) I was afraid that you would do so.
('55', 265, 3, 7, 503969) I, however, see no such discrepancy.
('55', 265, 3, 8, 504006) I did not feel any inconsistency with my views in this matter even when I started on my tour.
('55', 265, 3, 9, 504100) The difference between our two cases is this.
('55', 265, 3, 10, 504146) Dakshinamurti is your institution, as the Ashram is mine.
('55', 265, 3, 11, 504204) Your duty towards it is not to go out collecting money for it, but to teach and pour your soul into the pupils.
('55', 265, 3, 12, 504316) Similarly, my duty towards the Ashram is not to collect money for it but to observe its vows and help the other inmates to observe them, and to help in carrying on the various activities of the Ashram with greater vigour.
('55', 265, 3, 13, 504538) I must have faith that, if I do this duty, we shall get the money that we need.
('55', 265, 3, 14, 504618) The principle regarding the collection of a fund for the poor should be the opposite of this.
('55', 265, 3, 15, 504712) In that case my chief aim was to raise a fund.
('55', 265, 3, 16, 504759) You cannot go out to collect money for Dakshinamurti, but friends may certainly approach people for help to your institution.
('55', 265, 3, 17, 504885) It is their duty to do so.
('55', 265, 3, 18, 504912) Do you now see the difference between the two cases?
('55', 265, 3, 19, 504965) And this is not a new kind of difference, nor have I thought of it recently.
('55', 265, 3, 20, 505042) I bore this distinction in mind even in South Africa.
('55', 265, 3, 21, 505096) That is, when I realized it, I stopped seeking help for Phoenix, but I begged from door to door for a public institution there.
('55', 265, 3, 22, 505224) I, therefore, still suggest that you should resolve, if not immediately, as soon as may be, that you will not go out to collect money for the institution.
('55', 265, 3, 23, 505379) You should write toall friends who have been helping the institution and whom you know personally, and inform them of your decision, and then let the events take their own course.
('55', 265, 3, 24, 505559) The argument that our people do not yet appreciate institutions like yours and do not realize that it is their duty to give help to them on their own, is only a half truth.
('55', 265, 3, 25, 505732) We who manage such institutions lack faith in our work, and, therefore, the people have not been rightly educated about their duty of providing funds for them.
('55', 265, 3, 26, 505892) This is a vicious circle.
('55', 265, 3, 27, 505918) The people remain ignorant of their duty because we have not tried to educate them about it; and till they learn to give money on their own, we go begging from door to door.
('55', 265, 3, 28, 506092) Things will never change in this way.
('55', 265, 3, 29, 506130) The people will not learn their
('55', 266, 0, 1, 506162) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 267
('55', 266, 1, 2, 506208) duty and we shall not acquire faith in our work.
('55', 266, 1, 3, 506257) And the result will be that all our labour will be wasted.
('55', 266, 1, 4, 506316) Some of us, therefore, should risk everything and follow the way of faith.
('55', 266, 1, 5, 506391) You are in every respect qualified to take such a risk.
('55', 266, 1, 6, 506447) Your institution is relatively an old one and has acquired a reputation for itself.
('55', 266, 1, 7, 506531) Some of your teachers are selfless workers, and the pupils are taught with love.
('55', 266, 1, 8, 506612) We have evidence of this in the fact that you have succeeded in training some pupils by your method and that you have friends who give monetary help regularly.
('55', 266, 1, 9, 506772) Hence, even from the practical point of view, my advice does not seem unsound.
('55', 266, 1, 10, 506851) According to me, absolute faith in one’s work is also the highest practical wisdom.
('55', 266, 2, 11, 506935) Why do you suppose that, if you raise your fees and become self supporting, only the rich will send their children to your institution?
('55', 266, 2, 12, 507071) You must be admitting some children free.
('55', 266, 2, 13, 507113) You should pass on that burden to the rich.
('55', 266, 2, 14, 507157) They will pay, and must pay, that tax if they want their children to be educated in your institution.
('55', 266, 2, 15, 507259) Why do you entertain any doubt about the value to the people of the education which you impart?
('55', 266, 2, 16, 507355) Personally I am firmly of the view, and my view is based on actual observation, that even our best institutions do not grow to their full capacity because their heads spend much of their time in begging money for them.
('55', 266, 2, 17, 507574) The head of a school should devote himself exclusively to the internal development of the institution.
('55', 266, 2, 18, 507677) Instead, I have seen heads wasting their valuable time in collecting funds.
('55', 266, 2, 19, 507753) Personally I feel that in doing so those heads betrayed ignorance of their real duty.
('55', 266, 2, 20, 507839) They did not have faith in teaching as a vocation.
('55', 266, 2, 21, 507890) We see the result.
('55', 266, 2, 22, 507909) You and all the teachers should meet once among yourselves, and then again in the presence of the friends who have been providing you with funds.
('55', 266, 2, 23, 508055) Make your resolution at that meeting.
('55', 266, 2, 24, 508093) The meeting should be called not to seek the advice of those friends but to make your resolution and announce it.
('55', 266, 2, 25, 508207) Faith does not wait for anybody’s advice, and if you wait for advice you will stand to lose.
('55', 266, 3, 26, 508300) I stop here today.
('55', 266, 3, 27, 508319) If you wish to differ from me on this issue again, you may do so.
('55', 266, 3, 28, 508385) If you can spare time to write to me, I certainly have enough time to reply.
('55', 266, 3, 29, 508462) I cannot get so much time when I am outside.
('55', 266, 3, 30, 508507) You should, therefore, take the fullest advantage of my wider knowledge and experience.
('55', 266, 3, 31, 508595) If you fail to do so, you will be the loser.
('55', 266, 3, 32, 508640) I do not hesitate in the least or feel the slightest embarrassment in claiming that I am something of an expert in this matter.
('55', 266, 3, 33, 508768) It is for you
('55', 267, 0, 1, 508782) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 267, 1, 2, 508824) to accept or reject my claim.
('55', 267, 1, 3, 508854) But just as a man who knows a cure for snakebite but doubts or hides his ability would be a great fool, so also, if I know my special ability and still hide it from others I would be as good a fool as he.
('55', 267, 1, 4, 509059) I would not knowingly wish to become one.
('55', 267, 2, 5, 509101) [From Gujarati]

('55', 269, 2, 3, 512400) April 21, 1932
('55', 269, 3, 4, 512415) DEAR SISTER, I got the cotton and the honey yesterday.
('55', 269, 3, 5, 512470) May I thank you?
('55', 269, 3, 6, 512487) The cotton seems to have been carded in a mill.
('55', 269, 3, 7, 512535) You probably know that it can be of no use to me.
('55', 269, 3, 8, 512585) May I remind you of what I said last year?
('55', 269, 3, 9, 512628) I had hoped then that you would stock good, hand ginned cotton, get it carded at your place and give it to people to spin.
('55', 269, 3, 10, 512751) I wanted you to send me some from such stock of cotton, or if you did not have it, to obtain some from a khadi store.
('55', 269, 3, 11, 512869) It seems that the people in the office here could not explain this to you properly.
('55', 269, 3, 12, 512953) Send me such cotton immediately if you can secure it.
('55', 269, 3, 13, 513007) I was asked to give a list of persons other than inmates of the Ashram whom I should like to meet.

('55', 269, 3, 15, 513162) The government has replied that you can come to see me.
('55', 269, 3, 16, 513218) You may, therefore, now come along with a party from the Ashram or by yourself whenever you wish to.

('55', 269, 6, 19, 513421) 314. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('55', 269, 7, 20, 513452) April 21/22, 1932
('55', 269, 8, 21, 513470) NARANDAS, I get your post regularly on Wednesday every week.
('55', 269, 8, 22, 513531) I got it yesterday too.
('55', 269, 8, 23, 513555) The results of the spinning competition were excellent.
('55', 269, 8, 24, 513611) I had certainly guessed that your speed would be very high, but the speeds reached by the others, too, are very good.
('55', 269, 8, 25, 513729) I should be happier if all this makes a difference in the total output.
('55', 269, 8, 26, 513801) The pain in my left elbow is of the same kind as in the right hand thumb, and the doctor has been advising me for some time that I should give up spinning for a few days and give complete rest to the elbow.
('55', 269, 8, 27, 514008) I told you about this in my last letter.
('55', 269, 8, 28, 514049) At the moment, all that I can say is that my experiment is continuing.
('55', 269, 8, 29, 514120) I can draw yarn with the right hand with fairly good ease.
('55', 269, 8, 30, 514179) It is too early yet to say
('55', 270, 0, 1, 514206) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 271
('55', 270, 1, 2, 514252) whether this will cure the pain in the elbow completely.
('55', 270, 1, 3, 514309) However, there is no cause at all for worry.
('55', 270, 1, 4, 514354) I shall give you definite information on Tuesday when I seal the letters in a packet.
('55', 270, 1, 5, 514440) I have started dictating this letter on Thursday.
('55', 270, 1, 6, 514490) I was glad that Mathuradas came and saw me.
('55', 270, 1, 7, 514534) It would be a good thing if Tilakam goes to Calicut, but we should not send him at our own risk unless somebody there offers to take care of him and treat him well.
('55', 270, 1, 8, 514699) As regards Amtul, I am writing to her.
('55', 270, 1, 9, 514738) Read that letter 1. I told you in my previous letter what I wrote in reply to the letter 2 I had from Darjeeling.
('55', 270, 1, 10, 514852) You may come here whenever you wish to.
('55', 270, 1, 11, 514892) You will be able to see those women whom the previous visitors did not see.
('55', 270, 1, 12, 514968) I have been trying to do for Kaka everything I can from here.
('55', 270, 1, 13, 515030) Use Soniramji’s money as you think proper.
('55', 270, 1, 14, 515073) It should certainly be used for supplying free copies of the Gita whenever you think it justified.
('55', 270, 1, 15, 515172) The person who stole things from your room must have known what it contained.
('55', 270, 1, 16, 515250) I cannot resist the temptation of saying that Jamna deserved the lesson.
('55', 270, 1, 17, 515323) Nobody should keep a single pice in his or her room.
('55', 270, 1, 18, 515376) Anything one has should be deposited in the safe of the Ashram and that, too, only when the person has no other alternative.
('55', 270, 1, 19, 515501) Except for books, a few spinning wheels and such other articles necessary for our work, we should have nothing in our rooms.
('55', 270, 1, 20, 515626) Even the clothes should be the minimum we require for our daily use.
('55', 270, 1, 21, 515695) As a rich man feels happier the longer the list of his possessions, we should feel happier the shorter it is.
('55', 270, 1, 22, 515805) Our ideal is to have no possessions worth keeping a record of.
('55', 270, 1, 23, 515868) So long as we continue to possess things, our burglar friends are bound to claim their share.
('55', 270, 1, 24, 515962) Since we do not voluntarily offer it, they seize it by force.
('55', 270, 1, 25, 516024) You will of course read the letter which I am going to write to Kusum.
('55', 270, 1, 26, 516095) It would certainly be good if she learns nursing.
('55', 270, 1, 27, 516145) I also believethat Mrs. Lazarus 3 will treat her well.
('55', 270, 1, 28, 516200) But it seems to me that at present the work is beyond Kusum’s strength.
('55', 270, 1, 29, 516272) If she cannot preserve her own health, how will she be able to help others to preserve theirs?
('55', 270, 1, 30, 516367) Nursing the sick imposes no small strain on one’s strength.
('55', 270, 2, 31, 516427) 1Vide “A Letter”, 22 4 1932 2 From Mahavir Giri; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi” 3 Matron at the Vadilal Sarabhai Hospital, Ahmedabad
('55', 271, 0, 1, 516562) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 271, 1, 2, 516604) Sometimes a nurse has to be on duty the whole of the day and the night.
('55', 271, 1, 3, 516676) And she is on her feet all the time.
('55', 271, 1, 4, 516713) Most of the patients have little endurance.
('55', 271, 1, 5, 516757) They are irritable and demand immediate attention.
('55', 271, 1, 6, 516808) Hence anybody who is sincere in taking up this work must make her body and mind strong.
('55', 271, 1, 7, 516896) Of course this is true only about a woman who wishes to be a devoted nurse.
('55', 271, 1, 8, 516972) A nurse who doesn’t care for her patients and whose heart is not in her work is a disgrace to her profession.
('55', 271, 1, 9, 517082) A nurse’s job, if done sincerely, is more arduous than a doctor’s.
('55', 271, 1, 10, 517149) Good doctors have always given credit to the nurses and claimed none for themselves.
('55', 271, 1, 11, 517234) If Kusum has understood all this and if we can be sure that she can make her body strong enough for the work, I would certainly encourage her in her idea.
('55', 271, 1, 12, 517389) Personally, I have always been of the view that a nurse should remain unmarried.
('55', 271, 1, 13, 517470) The best nurses in the world are found among the followers of the Catholic Church, and that religion also supplies the largest number.
('55', 271, 1, 14, 517605) All of them are required to remain unmarried.
('55', 271, 1, 15, 517651) This is a special merit of the Catholic Church.
('55', 271, 1, 16, 517699) Another noteworthy fact about it is that all teachers, from the primary to the highest level, are unmarried persons.
('55', 271, 1, 17, 517816) We see very few other teachers who can excel them.
('55', 271, 1, 18, 517867) April 22, 1932
('55', 271, 2, 19, 517882) Dhiru had asked me in his letter whether he might send a Magan spinning wheel or himself bring one, and I had replied to him and told him that he could send or bring one.
('55', 271, 2, 20, 518053) How is it that it has not yet come?
('55', 271, 2, 21, 518089) I thought about that spinning wheel especially because of the pain in my elbow.

('55', 271, 2, 23, 518298) If the spinning wheel is ready, send it with anybody who may be coming to see me.

('55', 272, 1, 2, 519076) 315. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('55', 272, 2, 3, 519103) April 22, 1932
('55', 272, 3, 4, 519118) DEAR COL.
('55', 272, 3, 5, 519128) DOYLE, If you, will turn up the file left by Major Martin, you will find I am referring to a matter that has been pending for some time.
('55', 272, 3, 6, 519265) Kaka Kalelkar you know perhaps as well as I do.
('55', 272, 3, 7, 519313) He is at present in the Belgaum Central Prison.
('55', 272, 3, 8, 519361) He was transferred from Visapur to Belgaum.
('55', 272, 3, 9, 519405) I have been trying to get accurate information about his health and that of three other companions, but beyond getting a little vague information after considerable delay I have been able to make no headway.
('55', 272, 3, 10, 519613) In the reply Major Martin sent me just before he left, he said that he was asking for the information that I had sought.
('55', 272, 3, 11, 519734) The information already received by Major Bhandari shows that Kakasaheb is weak.
('55', 272, 3, 12, 519815) Probably he has lost weight and does not get cow’s milk which he used to get here.
('55', 272, 3, 13, 519898) Therefore if there are no political reasons to the contrary, I suggest his transfer to Yeravda, and if he can be put with me I should bring him up, I hope, to the weight he reached here in 1930, i.e., to 116 lb.
('55', 272, 3, 14, 520110) Of the other three prisoners referred to in my letter to Major Martin of 13th April, Narahari Parikh has nose trouble which often causes great pain.
('55', 272, 3, 15, 520259) His wife Mrs. Parikh writes saying that she cannot even get acknowledgment from the Belgaum Prison although she has sent reply paid postcards.
('55', 272, 3, 16, 520402) She has not heard from her husband at all and naturally she is worrying.
('55', 272, 3, 17, 520475) I have myself written to Kakasaheb inquiring not only about him but about the other three also, because they are all inmates of the Ashram, but I have no reply from him or them.
('55', 272, 3, 18, 520653) I would like to have their personal letters if I may.
('55', 272, 3, 19, 520707) I presume that the object of allowing me to hold correspondence with fellow prisoners was to give me the human satisfaction that I need in the way of getting information from them as to their well being.
('55', 272, 3, 20, 520911) I know that you have only just arrived and must be very busy.
('55', 272, 3, 21, 520973) I would not have worried you almost immediately on your arrival, but for the pressing necessity of the cases I have brought to your notice.
('55', 272, 4, 22, 521113) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Government of Bombay, Home Department, I.G.P. File No.

('55', 273, 1, 2, 521311) 316. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('55', 273, 2, 3, 521335) [April 22, 1932] 1
('55', 273, 3, 4, 521354) MIRA, Your expected letter has just arrived.
('55', 273, 3, 5, 521399) Like you I need not delay mine.
('55', 273, 3, 6, 521431) I am delighted that you have Kamaladevi with you and that she joins you at the morning prayer and sings bhajans in the evening.
('55', 273, 4, 7, 521559) Her vigorous skipping reminds me of the time when I used to skip for the same reason as Kamaladevi.
('55', 273, 4, 8, 521659) I had taught the boys also.
('55', 273, 4, 9, 521687) Ramdas was the gracefullest and best.
('55', 273, 4, 10, 521725) It is certainly a fine exercise especially in winter.
('55', 273, 4, 11, 521779) It is good that you are continuing your saltless experiment and that it is agreeing with you.
('55', 273, 4, 12, 521873) We have here a new doctor.
('55', 273, 4, 13, 521900) He is a Parsi Major.
('55', 273, 4, 14, 521921) He loves his work and has the innate dignified courtesy that you see invariably associated with a cultured Parsi.
('55', 273, 4, 15, 522035) He has been giving me electric massage for the right thumb and the left elbow.
('55', 273, 4, 16, 522114) The elbow has been causing pain for some time, but only when I work in particular ways.
('55', 273, 4, 17, 522202) He thinks that it may be necessary to stop spinning for some days.
('55', 273, 4, 18, 522269) Having done double work during the National Week, so far as my output is concerned, it is now about 85 rounds per day.
('55', 273, 4, 19, 522388) For I have anticipated Dr. Mehta by using the left hand for turning the wheel.
('55', 273, 4, 20, 522467) This is my fourth day.
('55', 273, 4, 21, 522490) I have made very good progress.
('55', 273, 4, 22, 522522) The right hand draws much more steadily and the thread is finer and more uniform.
('55', 273, 4, 23, 522604) This additional practice with the left hand again makes me think of the necessity of our trying to use the left hand equally with the right.
('55', 273, 4, 24, 522745) And we should teach the children 3 from now to be ambidexterous.
('55', 273, 4, 25, 522810) I have already written about this to Narandas.
('55', 273, 5, 26, 522857) 1 “Superintendent’s initialling date”—Mirabehn 2 “Kamaladevi was imprisoned as a ‘B’ class prisoner, and placed like other ‘B’ class prisoners, amongst the ‘C’ class prisoners in the Debtors’ Prison.
('55', 273, 5, 27, 523057) She and I began to take too much interest in the well being of the rest of the prisoners with the result that we were both removed to the permanent women’s jail inside the big Arthur Road jail, where we were placed in one of three small barracks, which had a common verandah.
('55', 273, 5, 28, 523333) The other barracks were occupied by female convicts.” —Mirabehn 3 “Ashram children” —Mirabehn

('55', 277, 8, 17, 529100) Regarding conversion, I don’t mean that it is never justified.
('55', 277, 8, 18, 529163) But no one should invite another person to change his or her religion.
('55', 277, 8, 19, 529234) In my view, the belief which underlies such practice, namely, that one’s own religion is true and another’s false is an error.
('55', 277, 8, 20, 529361) When, however, a person has changed his religion under compulsion or in ignorance, there should be no objection to such a person rectifying his error, that is, returning to his original religion; on the contrary, he should be encouraged to do that.
('55', 277, 8, 21, 529610) His action is not conversion.
('55', 277, 8, 22, 529640) If I think that my religion is false, I should give it up.
('55', 277, 8, 23, 529699) And I may, I ought to, accept what seems to me good in any other religion.

('55', 277, 8, 25, 529853) It is also my duty to try to rid it of any evil which I may see in it.

('55', 278, 1, 2, 530050) I regard Mirabehn as a Christian, and now she also regards herself as a Christian.
('55', 278, 1, 3, 530133) I see no inconsistency in her being a Christian and reading the Gita with devotion.

('55', 278, 1, 5, 530298) I really don’t know what we shall do after we get swaraj.
('55', 278, 1, 6, 530356) God will lead me then, as He does today.
('55', 278, 1, 7, 530397) A man who believes in God does not plan what he will do in future.
('55', 278, 1, 8, 530464) He who plans is not a man of faith, or rather his faith is weak.
('55', 278, 1, 9, 530529) There are not three separate paths, knowledge, devotion and action, for the realization of God.
('55', 278, 1, 10, 530625) The three form one single path.
('55', 278, 1, 11, 530657) That one path is divided into three aspects for the sake of convenience [of discussion].
('55', 278, 1, 12, 530746) Water is a compound of hydrogen and oxygen, but it is neither the one nor the other.
('55', 278, 1, 13, 530831) Similarly, knowledge is not a self sufficient path of God realization, nor is devotion.

('55', 278, 1, 18, 531310) If, however, a person cultivates devotion in expectation of such help, his devotion is of no value.

('55', 278, 1, 29, 531933) Even now we are making efforts towards that end.

('55', 279, 1, 2, 532147) 322. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('55', 279, 2, 3, 532180) April 22, 1932
('55', 279, 3, 4, 532195) PARASRAM, Who helped you to write the letter in Gujarati?
('55', 279, 3, 5, 532253) Whoever it was, his handwriting is excellent.
('55', 279, 3, 6, 532299) I assume that the actual language was yours.
('55', 279, 3, 7, 532344) one may certainly enter into loving rivalry with a fellow disciple of one’s guru or with anybody else.
('55', 279, 3, 8, 532447) That is, we can take everybody who can do something better than we as our ideal and advance.
('55', 279, 3, 9, 532540) There should be no trace of envy in this.
('55', 279, 3, 10, 532582) I have used the adjective ‘loving’ above to suggest this.
('55', 279, 3, 11, 532640) In such rivalry, we should wish in our heart that the person whom we have accepted as our ideal will improve his skill day by day, so that the ideal which we seek to attain will always be rising higher as we progress.
('55', 279, 3, 12, 532858) Such a wish will have a beneficial result for us too, since we shall be continually advancing.
('55', 279, 3, 13, 532953) I am firmly of the view, and it is my experience too, that, if a person has violated a moral principle in any one sphere of his life, his action will certainly have an effect in other spheres.
('55', 279, 3, 14, 533146) In other words, the belief generally held that an immoral man may do no harm in the political sphere is quite wrong.
('55', 279, 3, 15, 533263) And so is the other belief that a person who violates moral principles in his business may be moral in his private life or in his conduct in family affairs.
('55', 279, 3, 16, 533420) Hence, whenever we do an evil we should overcome [the tendency towards] it.
('55', 279, 4, 17, 533496) Blessings from BAPU

('55', 290, 7, 15, 548692) 345. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('55', 290, 8, 16, 548721) April 24, 1932
('55', 290, 9, 17, 548736) DEVDAS, You have proved your opinion of yourself to be wrong.
('55', 290, 9, 18, 548798) For, your letter just received is, though not too short, not very long either.
('55', 290, 9, 19, 548877) But it will do.
('55', 290, 9, 20, 548893) I used to get news of you, though I did not hear from you directly.
('55', 290, 9, 21, 548961) It is good that you have got quiet there.
('55', 290, 9, 22, 549003) It was necessary for you to get used to it.
('55', 290, 9, 23, 549047) Since you are keeping good health, I do not worry on your account.
('55', 290, 9, 24, 549114) I certainly wish that you should master Urdu.
('55', 290, 9, 25, 549160) It is ten minutes to two now.
('55', 290, 9, 26, 549190) Mahadev has come to me after finishing most of his own work, and, since I write very slowly with the left hand, I am now dictating this letter to him.
('55', 290, 9, 27, 549341) My aim in asking you to complete your study of Urdu is that you should read Maulana Shibli’s writings.
('55', 290, 9, 28, 549444) He has written a biography of the Prophet and also anecdotes from the lives of his associates.
('55', 290, 9, 29, 549539) There is much else too, with all of which I believe we should become acquainted.
('55', 290, 9, 30, 549620) If you have sufficient enthusiasm, you should read all that.
('55', 290, 9, 31, 549681) You can send for the
('55', 291, 0, 1, 549702) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 291, 1, 2, 549744) books from Azamgarh, where his office and madrasah are.
('55', 291, 1, 3, 549800) Most probably, you were with me during that tour and saw the place.
('55', 291, 1, 4, 549868) The present incumbent of Maulana Shibli’s religious office is Maulana Suleman Nadvi, since the former, as you must be aware, died some time ago.
('55', 291, 1, 5, 550013) I get quite good letters from Lakshmi.
('55', 291, 1, 6, 550052) That is, she replies to mine as a matter of religious duty.
('55', 291, 1, 7, 550112) Her letters are rather short.
('55', 291, 1, 8, 550142) But she seems helpless.
('55', 291, 1, 9, 550166) She admits that she cannot think of anything to write and so contents herself with a few sentences.
('55', 291, 1, 10, 550266) However, whatever little she writes she writes beautifully, and her Hindi may be said to be quite good.
('55', 291, 1, 11, 550370) She writes a pleasing hand and seems to be a quiet girl.
('55', 291, 1, 12, 550427) But why need I describe her to you ?
('55', 291, 1, 13, 550464) I have given here, though, the impression she has made on me.
('55', 291, 1, 14, 550526) She has been writing, it seems, to the Ashram inmates too.
('55', 291, 1, 15, 550585) We are happy here.
('55', 291, 1, 16, 550604) We do not feel that we are in a jail.
('55', 291, 1, 17, 550642) How can men be styled ‘State prisoners’ unless they enjoy complete freedom about food, sleep and all else?
('55', 291, 1, 18, 550749) As for visitors, Dahyabhai comes every week and he sees both of us together; but Mahadev does not have our status and, therefore, cannot join us at the interview.
('55', 291, 1, 19, 550912) Occasionally someone comes from the Ashram too, andwe two see the visitor.
('55', 291, 1, 20, 550987) Durga and Jivanji came once and saw Mahadev.
('55', 291, 1, 21, 551032) Now we have decided for the present that Durga should not come and unnecessarily spend money.
('55', 291, 1, 22, 551126) However, she is free to change her mind if she wishes, as she has not taken a vow not to come.
('55', 291, 1, 23, 551221) This is our daily routine: All three of us get up at 3.45 a.m.
('55', 291, 1, 24, 551284) After we have prayed together, Mahadev goes back to sleep and we two take honey and water and then have a walk.
('55', 291, 1, 25, 551396) Afterwards I sleep for about a quarter of an hour.
('55', 291, 1, 26, 551447) At 6.30 all the three have our breakfast consisting of bread, tea, etc., my tea of course being crushed almonds mixed in water.
('55', 291, 1, 27, 551575) I like it and have so far not felt the want of milk.
('55', 291, 1, 28, 551628) That is the only joint meal during the day.
('55', 291, 1, 29, 551672) The other two who drink milk have their next meal at about mid day, and I have mine at 4 p.m.
('55', 291, 1, 30, 551766) In between, I eat dates and almonds.
('55', 291, 1, 31, 551803) At 4 p.m.
('55', 291, 1, 32, 551813) I eat some vegetables, bread and almonds.
('55', 291, 1, 33, 551855) Mahadev has been doing a lot of spinning and carding, giving the spare time, if any, to reading.
('55', 291, 1, 34, 551952) At present he has also to go through the proofs of the book being published by the Oxford Press.
('55', 291, 1, 35, 552049) I take about two of his hours for my work.
('55', 291, 1, 36, 552092) Owing to the pain in the hand, since the National Week I have been spinning with the left hand and drawing the thread with the right.
('55', 291, 1, 37, 552226) I have had enough
('55', 292, 0, 1, 552244) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 293
('55', 292, 1, 2, 552290) practice by now and experience no difficulty, though the speed has of course slowed down.
('55', 292, 1, 3, 552380) Formerly I used to spin 375 rounds or more a week, but I cannot maintain a steady speed now.
('55', 292, 1, 4, 552473) I rest satisfied with whatever I can spin in two to three hours.
('55', 292, 1, 5, 552538) The highest number of rounds I have been able to draw so far with the right hand is 182. However, I feel confident that gradually the speed will increase.
('55', 292, 1, 6, 552693) As for my reading, I could get Urdu readers here and am going through them.
('55', 292, 1, 7, 552769) I read Ruskin also and give some time to books on astronomy too, as I have of late fallen in love with watching the stars.
('55', 292, 1, 8, 552892) With all this, I also find time for a nap of 20 or 25 minutes during the day.
('55', 292, 1, 9, 552970) I have started writing the history of the Ashram, having completed the remaining chapters of the Gita 1 some time ago.
('55', 292, 1, 10, 553089) That is the account of time for us two.

('55', 294, 7, 22, 556468) 349. A LETTER
('55', 294, 8, 23, 556482) April 24, 1932
('55', 294, 9, 24, 556497) BHAI, If you have fully understood the value of brahmacharya, I think your father’s pain or anger need not be taken into account.
('55', 294, 9, 25, 556627) If you put his anger in one scale and dharma in the other scale, the former would weigh as light as air.
('55', 294, 9, 26, 556732) But you should first decide whether you regard brahmacharya as dharma.
('55', 294, 9, 27, 556803) If you are firm, your father will soon calm down.
('55', 294, 10, 28, 556853) From Gujarati: C.W. 9057. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('55', 297, 0, 1, 559657) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 297, 1, 2, 559699) 354. NECESSITY OF DRAWING UP A BALANCE SHEET 1
('55', 297, 2, 3, 559746) April 25, 1932
('55', 297, 3, 4, 559761) Many thoughts occur to me as I write the history of the Ashram.
('55', 297, 3, 5, 559825) I become aware of our many short comings.
('55', 297, 3, 6, 559867) These reflections have led me to the conclusion that from time to time we should draw up a balance sheet of our progress.
('55', 297, 3, 7, 559989) A business man draws up a daily, a monthly and a half yearly balance sheet of his business, and a comprehensive balance sheet at the end of every year.
('55', 297, 3, 8, 560141) We are engaged in the business of spiritual seeking and, therefore, we should draw up a balance sheet of our spiritual progress.
('55', 297, 3, 9, 560270) Everybody should draw up such a balance sheet for himself or herself and all of us together for the Ashram as a whole.
('55', 297, 3, 10, 560389) If we do not follow this practice, we would become spiritually bankrupt, as a business man who is negligent in drawing up the balance sheet of his business would find himself financially bankrupt.
('55', 297, 3, 11, 560586) If we do not know whether we are progressing or going backwards in keeping our vows and in our other activities, we would become mechanical in all our work and, in the end, become less efficient even than machines.
('55', 297, 3, 12, 560801) In other words, we would incur loss in our business.
('55', 297, 3, 13, 560854) How is such a balance sheet to be drawn up?
('55', 297, 3, 14, 560898) I will answer this question by writing down a few questions.
('55', 297, 3, 15, 560959) 1. Are we untruthful in our thoughts, speech or actions?
('55', 297, 3, 16, 561016) ‘We’ means every one of us.
('55', 297, 3, 17, 561044) 2. If that is the case, who are the guilty persons and on what occasions were they guilty of untruth?
('55', 297, 3, 18, 561146) What did they do when their guilt was discovered and also what action did the Ashram take?
('55', 297, 3, 19, 561237) 3. During all these years of the existence of the Ashram, have we made any progress in this matter or have we become worse ?
('55', 297, 3, 20, 561362) 4. We should ask these questions in regard to all the vows and whenever we discover short comings, we should try to think out suitable remedies and employ them.
('55', 297, 3, 21, 561523) We can do the same with regard to the various activities in which we are engaged.
('55', 297, 3, 22, 561605) We have to think about them from two different points of view.
('55', 297, 3, 23, 561668) From the economic point of view, the question we
('55', 297, 4, 24, 561717) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 25 4 1932; vide the following item.
('55', 298, 0, 1, 561809) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 299
('55', 298, 1, 2, 561855) should ask is this: ‘Is the activity self supporting?’ It is our faith that if an activity is found economically self supporting, from the moral point of view also it is likely to have been carried on along proper lines.
('55', 298, 1, 3, 562076) If there is either loss or profit, we may be sure that there has been a violation of moral principles somewhere.
('55', 298, 1, 4, 562189) The second point of view is this: ‘Is the activity carried on primarily with a religious motive?’ It is essential that all our activities in the Ashram should be carried on with a religious motive, for everything we do ought to be subordinate to dharma that is, to truth.
('55', 298, 1, 5, 562461) Concerning both these—our vows and the other activities—I cannot help asking the following questions: 1. How is it that in the Ashram itself people deceive one another in small matters?
('55', 298, 1, 6, 562647) 2. When shall we cease to distrust one another?
('55', 298, 1, 7, 562695) What can we do to bring this about?
('55', 298, 1, 8, 562731) 3. How is it that burglars from outside still continue to raid the Ashram?
('55', 298, 1, 9, 562806) 4. Why is it that the inmates have too many personal possessions?
('55', 298, 1, 10, 562872) 5. Why have we not cultivated contacts with the neighbouring villages?
('55', 298, 1, 11, 562943) What is the best way of doing that?
('55', 298, 1, 12, 562979) 6. Why do people continually fall ill in the Ashram?
('55', 298, 1, 13, 563032) 7. What have we done for the labourers who work in the Ashram?
('55', 298, 1, 14, 563095) Why is it that they have not been attracted to come and live in the Ashram?
('55', 298, 1, 15, 563171) Or, rather, why should there be any labourers at all in the Ashram?
('55', 298, 1, 16, 563239) In the Ashram there should be no masters and labourers.
('55', 298, 1, 17, 563295) I can write down many more such questions.
('55', 298, 1, 18, 563338) But these are enough to show what I have in mind.
('55', 298, 1, 19, 563388) I should like all people, young and grown up, to start thinking.
('55', 298, 1, 20, 563453) This was certainly one of my aims in insisting that all inmates should maintain a diary.
('55', 298, 2, 21, 563542) From a microfilm of the Gujarat: M.M.U./II
('55', 299, 0, 1, 563585) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('55', 300, 5, 6, 565659) I wish you will not take to heart what the Bishop has been saying.
('55', 300, 5, 7, 565726) Your church is in your heart.
('55', 300, 5, 8, 565756) Your pulpit is the whole earth.
('55', 300, 5, 9, 565788) The blue sky is the roof of your church.
('55', 300, 5, 10, 565829) And what is this Catholicism?
('55', 300, 5, 11, 565859) It is surely of the heart.
('55', 300, 5, 12, 565886) The formula has its use.
('55', 300, 5, 13, 565911) But it is made by man.
('55', 300, 5, 14, 565934) If I have any right to interpret the message of Jesus as revealed in the Gospels, I have no manner of doubt in my mind that it is in the main denied in the churches, whether Roman or English, High or Low.
('55', 300, 5, 15, 566139) Lazarus has no room in those places.
('55', 300, 5, 16, 566176) This does not mean that the custodians know that the Man of Sorrows has been banished from the buildings called Houses of God.
('55', 300, 5, 17, 566303) In my opinion, this excommuni cation is the surest sign that the truth is in you and with you.
('55', 300, 5, 18, 566398) But my testimony is worth nothing, if when you are alone with your Maker, you do not hear His voice saying, ‘Thou art on the right path.’ That is the unfailing test and no other.

('55', 300, 7, 20, 566616) 357. LETTER TO A BENGALI ASPIRANT FOR BRAHMACHARYA
('55', 300, 8, 21, 566667) April 25, 1932
('55', 300, 9, 22, 566682) I have your letter.
('55', 300, 9, 23, 566702) Brahmacharya is a mental state.
('55', 300, 9, 24, 566734) It is undoubtedly helped by abstentiousness in all respects.
('55', 300, 9, 25, 566795) But diet plays the least part in giving one the necessary mental state.
('55', 300, 9, 26, 566867) Not that wrong diet will not hinder progress.
('55', 300, 9, 27, 566913) What I want to say is that right diet, taken in moderation, is not the only thing in the observance of brahmacharya though it is undoubtedly one of the necessary things.
('55', 300, 10, 28, 567083) 1 From Bapuna Patro 9: Shri Narandas Gandhine, Pt. I 2 This paragraph appears to have been added by Mahadev Desai.
('55', 300, 10, 29, 567198) 3 The letter was in reply to the addressee’s letter in which he had said that a Bishop had called him a traitor to Christ and had prohibited him from preaching in churches.
('55', 301, 0, 1, 567371) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 301, 1, 2, 567413) Indulgence of the palate will be the surest sign of weak mental state which is repugnant to brahmacharya.
('55', 301, 1, 3, 567519) The sovereign remedy for the observance of brahmacharya is realization that the soul is a part of the Divine and that the Divine resides within us.
('55', 301, 1, 4, 567667) A heart grasp of the fact induces mental purity and strength.
('55', 301, 1, 5, 567729) You should therefore read such books as would enable you to grasp the central fact, cultivate such companionship as would constantly make you think of the Divine presence and follow all the directions given about fresh air, hip baths, etc., in my book called Self restraint v.
('55', 301, 1, 6, 568006) Self indulgence.
('55', 301, 1, 7, 568023) And when you are doing all these things regularly and industriously, do not brood over all that happens, but have confidence that success is bound to attend 1 your effort.
('55', 301, 2, 8, 568195) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.
('55', 301, 3, 9, 568227) 358. A LETTER 2
('55', 301, 4, 10, 568243) April 25, 1932
('55', 301, 5, 11, 568258) I have your pathetic letter.
('55', 301, 5, 12, 568287) Seeing that God is to be found within, no research in physical sciences can give one a living faith in the Divine.
('55', 301, 5, 13, 568402) Some have undoubtedly been helped even by physical sciences, but these are to be counted on one’s finger tips.
('55', 301, 5, 14, 568513) My suggestion therefore to you is not to argue about the existence of Divinity, just as you do not argue about your existence, but simply assume like Euclid’s axiom, that God is, if only because innumerable teachers have left their evidence and what is more their lives are an unimpeachable evidence.
('55', 301, 5, 15, 568814) And then, as evidence of your own faithr epeat Ramanama 3 every morning and every evening at least for a quarter of an hour each time and saturate yourself with the Ramayana reading.
('55', 301, 6, 16, 568997) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('55', 302, 9, 19, 570299) 361. LETTER TO K. NATARAJAN 2
('55', 302, 10, 20, 570329) April 26, 1932
('55', 302, 11, 21, 570344) DEAR MR. NATARAJAN, I am sure you must have read the reports of an exhibition given by an Indian yogi of his powers before an audience specially assembled at the Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital.
('55', 302, 11, 22, 570532) The yogi is reported to have eaten a live viper’s head, nails, nitric acid, and the like, and that the Chief Justice and his wife were among the distinguished audience.
('55', 302, 12, 23, 570701) 1 For Doyle’s reply, vide “Letter from E. E. Doyle”, 28 4 1932 2 Editor, Indian Social Reformer
('55', 303, 0, 1, 570797) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 303, 1, 2, 570839) The report states that one lady was so disgusted at the eating of the viper’s head that she abruptly left the hall before the exhibition was finished.
('55', 303, 1, 3, 570990) I do not know how you look at such exhibitions.
('55', 303, 1, 4, 571038) In my opinion they are degrading both for the demonstrator, as also for the public.
('55', 303, 1, 5, 571122) And if the demonstrator died, as he most likely would, if these demonstrations were continued, those who encouraged him by attending them, I should hold guilty of manslaughter.
('55', 303, 1, 6, 571299) I do not think that either science or humanity is served by such revolting exhibitions.
('55', 303, 1, 7, 571387) The text books on Hatha yoga clearly lay down that the Hathayogisare expected not to exhibit their yogic powers or make use of them for purposes of gain.
('55', 303, 1, 8, 571541) If you agree with me, will you not initiate an agitation in the daily Press for preventing such cruel exhibitions?
('55', 303, 1, 9, 571656) One man, I suppose you know, recently died in Rangoon precisely giving demonstrations such as the one reported in Bombay.
('55', 303, 2, 10, 571778) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('55', 306, 9, 13, 577305) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, After all if a letter had to be written about getting the specialists here, Sardar Vallabhbhai thought that he should write the letter himself.
('55', 306, 9, 14, 577470) Hence the enclosed from him.
('55', 306, 9, 15, 577499) You will see in that letter absence of any mention of 12 lb.
('55', 306, 9, 16, 577560) loss of weight.
('55', 306, 9, 17, 577576) Of course I wholly disagree with you and the other doctors that these local troubles have nothing to do with the digestive apparatus.
('55', 306, 9, 18, 577710) As a layman I strongly hold the conviction that the nose trouble has much to do with the loss of weight.
('55', 306, 9, 19, 577815) In Sardar Vallabhbhai’s case in spite of his strong will, I know that the constant and irritating attention that the trouble invites disturbs him as it would anybody.
('55', 306, 9, 20, 577982) If nothing else, the disturbance itself would be a sufficient cause to put a person off his food.
('55', 306, 9, 21, 578080) I know that in my case I should simply stop taking food if I had such trouble.

('55', 309, 5, 6, 582675) 372. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('55', 309, 6, 7, 582703) April 28, 1932
('55', 309, 7, 8, 582718) The question you have put me about the meaning of pinda and brahmanda is a big one.
('55', 309, 7, 9, 582802) But I will explain the idea in brief.
('55', 309, 7, 10, 582840) For our purpose, we may understand the word pinda to mean our body, and the word brahmanda to mean the earth.
('55', 309, 7, 11, 582950) Now, the statement [as in the pinda, so in the brahmanda] means that everything that is in the body is there in the earth, too, and likewise there is nothing in the earth which is not in our body.
('55', 309, 7, 12, 583147) The latter is composed of the same substance as the earth.
('55', 309, 7, 13, 583206) There are five elements of the earth, and the body is made of the same five elements.
('55', 309, 7, 14, 583292) Innumerable creatures exist on the earth and also in the body.
('55', 309, 7, 15, 583355) As one body perishes and another is born, so the substance of the earth also is continually undergoing transformations.
('55', 309, 7, 16, 583475) We can amplify this analogy still further.
('55', 309, 7, 17, 583518) But we can deduce from what I have said, that if we know the real nature of our body, we shall know the real nature of the earth as well and shall not have to go far afield in seareh of knowledge.
('55', 309, 7, 18, 583715) Our body is the nearest thing to us, and if we understand it we shall have attained our object.
('55', 309, 7, 19, 583811) If we try to know about the earth, our knowledge will always be incomplete.
('55', 309, 7, 20, 583887) That is why wise men have told us that there is nothing in the brahmanda which is not to be found in the pinda.
('55', 309, 7, 21, 583999) Therefore, if we know the self, that knowledge will include all other knowledge.
('55', 309, 7, 22, 584080) But we may also enjoy the knowledge of other things which we gain while we strive for knowledge of the self, since we shall be enjoying it asincidental to our pursuit of knowledge of the self .
('55', 309, 7, 23, 584274) 2. I think that Narasinhbhai has not thought deeply enough in interpreting the Gita.
('55', 309, 7, 24, 584359) We should not confuse the Krishna of the Gita with the Krishna of
('55', 309, 8, 25, 584425) 1 This is not available.
('55', 309, 8, 26, 584450) Vide, however, “Fragment of Letter to Harilal Gandhi”,27 4 1932 2 Omission as in the source
('55', 310, 0, 1, 584542) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 311
('55', 310, 1, 2, 584588) history.
('55', 310, 1, 3, 584597) The problem before Krishna was not that of violence or non violence.
('55', 310, 1, 4, 584666) Arjuna shrank not from violence but from having to kill his relations.
('55', 310, 1, 5, 584737) Krishna, therefore, explained to him that in doing one’s duty one ought not to treat one’s relations differently from others.
('55', 310, 1, 6, 584863) In the age when the Gita was composed, the men who influenced its thought did not raise the question whether the violence committed in war was right or not.
('55', 310, 1, 7, 585020) That question seems to have been raised only in modern times.
('55', 310, 1, 8, 585082) The principle of non violence was accepted even then by all Hindus; but opinions differed then, as they do now, as regards what involved violence and what did not.
('55', 310, 1, 9, 585246) Our descendants may see violence in many things in which we do not see it today.
('55', 310, 1, 10, 585327) For instance, we do destroy life when we consume milk or cook cereals.
('55', 310, 1, 11, 585398) It is conceivable that future generations may wish to refrain from such violence and stop drinking milk and cooking cereals.
('55', 310, 1, 12, 585523) Today we commit this violence and still claim without any hesitation that we observe non violence.
('55', 310, 1, 13, 585622) In exactly the same manner, war was regarded such a normal thing in the age of the Gita that people did not feel that they violated the principle of non violence by engaging in it.
('55', 310, 1, 14, 585803) The illustration of the war in the Gita, therefore, seems to me perfectly innocent.
('55', 310, 1, 15, 585887) If, however, we reflect over the teaching of the Gita as a whole and examine the characteristics of the sthitaprajna, of the man who has merged in the Brahman, of the bhakta or of the yogi, we can come to only one conclusion, namely, that the Shri Krishna who taught the path of the Gita was literally an avatar of ahimsa and his exhortation to Arjuna to fight does not in the least detract from the purity of his ahimsa.
('55', 310, 1, 16, 586309) On the contrary, if he had advised Arjuna to follow any other course, I am sure that the perfection of his knowledge would have been called in question and he would never have come to be worshipped as the most perfect avatar of God.
('55', 310, 1, 17, 586542) You should read what I have written in this connection in Anasaktiyoga 1. [From Gujarati]
('55', 310, 2, 18, 586632) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.
('55', 310, 3, 19, 586665) 1 Vide “Anasaktiyoga”
('55', 311, 0, 1, 586687) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 311, 1, 2, 586729) 373. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('55', 311, 2, 3, 586762) April 29, 1932
('55', 311, 3, 4, 586777) PARASRAM 1. It does not befit us to ask the questions you have asked about Maulana Shaukat Ali.
('55', 311, 3, 5, 586873) We should not pay attention to the short comings of other people or sit in judgment over anybody.
('55', 311, 3, 6, 586971) We should exhaust all our energies in examining ourselves.
('55', 311, 3, 7, 587030) As long as we can detect even a single weakness in ourselves and, despite it, inwardly wish that our relatives, acquaintances and friends should not cut off relations with us, we are not entitled to see short comings inothers or criticize them.
('55', 311, 3, 8, 587275) If we unintentionally see such short comings in anybody, we may, if it lies in our power and if it is proper for us to do so, ask the person concerned about them, but nobody else.
('55', 311, 3, 9, 587455) There is no gain in asking other people.
('55', 311, 3, 10, 587496) However, since you wished to ask me, you did quite well in doing so.
('55', 311, 3, 11, 587565) For otherwise I would not have had an opportunity to lecture to you in this way.
('55', 311, 3, 12, 587646) And now I reply to your question.
('55', 311, 3, 13, 587680) From a distance and on the basis of the known facts only, we should not approve of the Maulana’s activities.
('55', 311, 3, 14, 587789) However, I cannot arrive at any definite opinion without hearing in detail about his activities from his own mouth.
('55', 311, 3, 15, 587905) According to me, it is not correct to say that the followers of the Prophet ought to, or may, do all things done by him.
('55', 311, 3, 16, 588026) All people are not entitled to do everything that the great men may have done.
('55', 311, 3, 17, 588105) We have seen that such imitation leads to undesirable results.
('55', 311, 3, 18, 588168) However, we find that Hindus, Muslims and followers of other faiths do not only not follow this golden rule always, but even act as if they were entitled to do certain things because the Prophets or avatars had done them.
('55', 311, 3, 19, 588390) Seeing that this is the general attitude, I am not surprised that the Maulana has cited the Prophet’s example.
('55', 311, 3, 20, 588501) 2. What we do about Bhishma and others we may also apply to social workers of the present day.
('55', 311, 3, 21, 588596) I feel that the present practice of (offering) jalanjali needs reform.
('55', 311, 3, 22, 588667) Everyone who has written to me on the subject had nothing but praise about the Ramayana class which you have been conducting.
('55', 311, 3, 23, 588793) Go on in the same interesting way.
('55', 311, 3, 24, 588828) It would be in my view a great achievement if all at the Ashram come to love speaking in Hindi and
('55', 312, 0, 1, 588927) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 313
('55', 312, 1, 2, 588973) become interested in the Ramayana.
('55', 312, 1, 3, 589008) I am, therefore, very much pleased that you have thrown yourself heart and soul into this work.
('55', 312, 3, 4, 589104) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 7495. AIso C.W. 4972. Courtesy: Parasram Mehrotra

('55', 314, 1, 2, 590864) 378. FRAGMENT OF A DRAFT LETTER TO LORD SANKEY
('55', 314, 2, 3, 590911) May 1, 1932
('55', 314, 3, 4, 590923) You have given judgment against me on evidence of which I have been kept in ignorance and your judgment has been given at a time when I have been rendered incapable of defending myself.
('55', 314, 4, 5, 591109) The Diary of Mahadev Desai, Vol. I, p.
('55', 314, 5, 6, 591148) 379. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA
('55', 314, 6, 7, 591183) May 1, 1932
('55', 314, 7, 8, 591195) CHI BHAGWANJI, It is good that you wrote to me.
('55', 314, 7, 9, 591243) I am going to write about the subject 2; so I do not expatiate on it here.
('55', 314, 7, 10, 591318) You drew the attention of a responsible person to what you felt was a slip.
('55', 314, 7, 11, 591394) Now you have only to watch what he would do.
('55', 314, 7, 12, 591439) As for you, you have done your duty.
('55', 314, 9, 13, 591476) From a copy of the Gujarati: C.W. 346. Courtesy: Bhagwanji P. Pandya
('55', 314, 10, 14, 591545) 1 Mahadev Desai explains: “Bapu was deeply pained to read Sankey’s article in Newsletter.
('55', 314, 10, 15, 591635) He said it was a vicious piece of writing and he felt he should write to its author.
('55', 314, 10, 16, 591720) The Sardar who was listening to the dictation remarked: ‘Instead of writing such a longish letter, why don’t you simply tell him that he is a liar?’ Bapu laughed and replied, ‘In fact I have said something stronger still.
('55', 314, 10, 17, 591942) I say his conduct is ungentlemanly.
('55', 314, 10, 18, 591978) I go further and say that he has betrayed a friend or colleague.
('55', 314, 10, 19, 592043) This is something that would cut an Englishman to the quick, but I have written what I felt.
('55', 314, 10, 20, 592136) People like Shafi and the Aga Khan who met him every now and then must have told him all these lies.
('55', 314, 10, 21, 592237) And he not only believed them to be true, but never asked me about them and throws the blame on me now when I am in prison....’ The keenness of Bapu’s feeling is evident from this sentence in the first draft of the letter....
('55', 314, 10, 22, 592463) Part of the sentence was later replaced with the following: ‘You have given it after rendering me incapable of defending myself.’ .
('55', 314, 10, 23, 592595) It is not true again that my claim is exaggerated.
('55', 314, 10, 24, 592646) Why should our claim to independence be considered exaggerated?
('55', 314, 10, 25, 592710) It may be so considered if I propose to reduce England to slavery.

('55', 319, 6, 9, 599065) 389. LESSON OF THE NATIONAL WEEK 1
('55', 319, 7, 10, 599100) May 2, 1932
('55', 319, 8, 11, 599112) I received a letter from Shri Bhagwanji regarding the self purification week celebrated in April last.
('55', 319, 8, 12, 599215) In that letter he draws my attention to the waste of cotton which occurs and he also suspects that some persons knowingly gave a higher figure for the yarn spun by them.
('55', 319, 8, 13, 599385) He states that the waste was of two kinds: one, the quantity of broken threads was more than permissible, and, two, since the spinning was done with excessive speed the count of the yarn spun was very low.
('55', 319, 9, 14, 599591) If anybody knowingly gave a wrong figure for the yarn spun by him or her, I would regard it as a serious matter.
('55', 319, 9, 15, 599704) Such conduct would be a blot on the good name of the Ashram.
('55', 319, 9, 16, 599765) The spinning done by a person who gives a wrong figure will not be accepted by God as yajna.
('55', 319, 9, 17, 599858) The figure entered in our records has no value.
('55', 319, 9, 18, 599906) The real value of the spinning done remains what it is.
('55', 319, 9, 19, 599962) It cannot be increased or diminished by entering a higher or lower figure in our record.
('55', 319, 9, 20, 600051) Besides, the cash value of the yarn is no more than a few annas; its real value lies in the sincerity of the motive with which the spinning is done.
('55', 319, 9, 21, 600200) That value can never be estimated by us.
('55', 319, 9, 22, 600241) It is recorded only in the divine book, for who but God can understand man’s motives.
('55', 319, 10, 23, 600327) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 28 4/2 5 1932; vide the following item.
('55', 319, 10, 24, 600423) 2 For Gandhiji’ reply to Bhagwanji P. Pandya, vide “Letter to Bhagwanji P. Pandya”, 1 5 1932
('55', 320, 0, 1, 600516) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 321
('55', 320, 1, 2, 600562) However, we have one test.
('55', 320, 1, 3, 600589) If such yajna does not yield the expected result in time, we may conclude that there is some impurity in us.
('55', 320, 1, 4, 600698) Let everybody examine his work from this point of view and, if anybody has been guilty of untruth, let him or her humbly confess it and so purify himself or herself.
('55', 320, 1, 5, 600864) We cannot, in the Ashram, keep a secret watch over anybody; most of the work is carried on the basis of trust in one another.
('55', 320, 1, 6, 600990) The Ashram cannot be run on any other basis.
('55', 320, 1, 7, 601035) Everybody, therefore, should know his duty and do it.
('55', 320, 1, 8, 601089) Let the inmates also think if they have been guilty of anything else besides giving wrong figures for yarn.
('55', 320, 1, 9, 601197) Were they slack in doing the spinning?
('55', 320, 1, 10, 601236) Did they do it as a task forced on them?
('55', 320, 1, 11, 601277) Did they give to it less than the appointed time?
('55', 320, 1, 12, 601327) Did they throw away the broken threads?
('55', 320, 1, 13, 601367) This is the condition for a true yajna: the person doing it should give his whole hearted attention to the work, and do it with all his skill and intelligence.
('55', 320, 1, 14, 601527) Let nobody believe that he or she may behave anyhow throughout the year and still be able to observe the rules explained above during the National Week.
('55', 320, 1, 15, 601680) It should be remembered that one’s whole life in the Ashram has to be a continuous yajna.
('55', 320, 1, 16, 601770) Among all its activities, spinning is the supreme yajna.
('55', 320, 1, 17, 601827) The only difference between the National Week and the rest of the year is that we give more time to spinning during that Week.
('55', 320, 1, 18, 601954) I suggest that the following rules should be observed in future: 1. If the yarn is of less than 20 counts, the spinning should not be regarded as yajna.
('55', 320, 1, 19, 602107) 2. If the waste exceeds a fixed limit, the spinning should not be regarded as yajna.
('55', 320, 1, 20, 602192) 3. If the strength of the yarn comes to less than a fixed limit, then also the spinning should not be regarded as yajna.
('55', 320, 1, 21, 602313) In yajna or any other work, the neatness of the product and the sincerity with which the work is done are more important than the number or quantity of what is produced.
('55', 320, 1, 22, 602483) Fifty bullocks who are physically unfit will prove a burden on the owner, whereas one strong bullock will do his work well.
('55', 320, 1, 23, 602607) Fifty knives with blunt edges will not be useful in mincing vegetables, but one knife with a sharp edge will do the work perfectly.
('55', 320, 1, 24, 602739) We should, therefore, learn to give our full attention to every work which we do.
('55', 320, 1, 25, 602821) We should devote the next [National] Week exclusively to this subject.
('55', 320, 1, 26, 602892) I observe that some inmates find spinning a boring work and
('55', 321, 0, 1, 602952) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 321, 1, 2, 602994) prefer something else.
('55', 321, 1, 3, 603017) There is one natural weakness in this attitude.
('55', 321, 1, 4, 603065) A person is bored by the work which he has to do every day and persuades himself that, if he had been doing some other work instead, he would not get bored in that manner.
('55', 321, 1, 5, 603237) However, if that other work becomes his daily work, he would ask for something else still.
('55', 321, 1, 6, 603328) Besides, consciously or unconsciously persons who do spinning think of the low earnings from that work.
('55', 321, 1, 7, 603432) According to the standpoint of Ashram this is a wrong attitude.
('55', 321, 1, 8, 603496) The wage for spinning is the lowest because it is the only work at present which millions can do and which can help them to earn a little money.
('55', 321, 1, 9, 603641) All of us, therefore, do voluntary spinning as yajna in order to popularize the work.
('55', 321, 1, 10, 603727) The idea behind yajna is that we dedicate the work to God and have faith that He will provide us the wherewithal for our maintenance.
('55', 321, 1, 11, 603861) Let everyone understand this significance of yajna and daily do the yajna of spinning with whole hearted devotion and with zest.
('55', 321, 2, 12, 603990) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('55', 323, 1, 2, 607774) but there is no doubt that we ought to pay attention to the fineness of the count and strength of yarn and to reducing waste.
('55', 323, 1, 3, 607900) At the examination, this was the method of evaluation formerly adopted.
('55', 323, 1, 4, 607972) The candidate was awarded marks equal to the figure of the count multiplied by that of the strength.
('55', 323, 1, 5, 608073) I do not know what method is followed now.
('55', 323, 1, 6, 608116) I would introduce the factor of waste in calculating the marks—reduce the marks in proportion to the quantity of waste.
('55', 323, 1, 7, 608236) Mahadev and I have thought out this method.
('55', 323, 1, 8, 608280) Waste up to one tola for every pound [of yarn] may be condoned.
('55', 323, 1, 9, 608344) If the waste exceeds one tola, for every additional tola the marks arrived at by multiplying the figure of the count by that of the strength should be reduced by sixteen.
('55', 323, 1, 10, 608515) That is, the marks should be reduced by one for every 1/16 tola of waste.
('55', 323, 1, 11, 608589) If the waste is as much as ten tolas, the candidate should fail.
('55', 323, 1, 12, 608654) However, you yourself may decide whether waste, of one tola or of more than one tola per pound should be condoned.
('55', 323, 1, 13, 608769) I have given the figures merely as illustrations to explain my idea.
('55', 323, 1, 14, 608838) If I were an examiner, I would even take into account how the candidate sat when spinning, in what condition he maintained his spinning wheel, whether he kept the place where he sat for spinning quite clean and whether he could repair a spinning wheel when it went out of order, and calculate marks for all these.
('55', 323, 1, 15, 609152) This means that the work of the candidates would be constantly observed by somebody.
('55', 323, 1, 16, 609237) This observer would be one of the examiners at the test.
('55', 323, 1, 17, 609294) I would not mind if such a practice had the effect of reducing our output.
('55', 323, 1, 18, 609369) What is essential is that we should be sure in our minds that we were vigilant and were progressing from day to day.
('55', 323, 1, 19, 609486) I have stated in the accompanying note 1 that when the yarn spun is of less than 20 counts, the spinning should not be counted as yajna.
('55', 323, 1, 20, 609623) This does not mean that no credit should be given for the spinning done.
('55', 323, 1, 21, 609696) The candidate would go on spinning every day and be awarded marks for his work, the yarn could be made use of, but such a spinner should not be considered to be performing yajna.
('55', 323, 1, 22, 609875) He would be only a candidate.

('55', 326, 7, 18, 614524) I would not, however, spend time convincing anybody about the reality of rebirth; nor would I enter into too much argument on the subject.
('55', 326, 7, 19, 614663) There are several things scientifically established, our disbelief in which is of no great consequence in our lives.
('55', 326, 7, 20, 614780) It is possible that rebirth may be so defined by somebody that the usual proof offered in support of it will not satisfy him.
('55', 326, 7, 21, 614906) My own definition of it is just this.
('55', 326, 7, 22, 614944) The soul does not cease to exist with the end of the body, but migrates from one existence to another, and that is rebirth.
('55', 326, 7, 23, 615068) That is, I would say that even Christians, Muslims and Zoroastrians who believe in the Day of Judgment believe in rebirth according to my definition of it.
('55', 326, 7, 24, 615224) The acquisition of another body, in my view, follows as a necessary corollary from this belief.

('55', 327, 1, 14, 616532) I have often noticed that what we have said or wish to say had already been said by somebody else in different words.
('55', 327, 1, 15, 616650) Instead of noting a difference or contradiction between the two explanations, I see the identity of meaning.
('55', 327, 1, 16, 616759) What does it matter if the language differs?
('55', 327, 1, 17, 616804) I am aware that there are certain risks in following this method, but they exist only for those persons who twist the meanings of words to see and prove the identity of the meaning of the passages in question.
('55', 327, 1, 18, 617014) I don’t think there is any such risk for a person who sees such identity spontaneously.
('55', 327, 1, 19, 617102) Hence, the question we face is, whether the better course is to form the habit of seeing identity of meaning or to proceed on the assumption that difference in language indicates difference in meaning.
('55', 327, 1, 20, 617304) In my view, it is dangerous to see difference in meaning in verbal difference.
('55', 327, 1, 21, 617383) I very much like to see identity rather than difference of meaning between Ishvar and Allah.

('55', 332, 7, 20, 627470) 402. LETTER TO IBRAHIMJI RAJKOTWALA
('55', 332, 8, 21, 627506) May 5, 1932
('55', 332, 9, 22, 627518) I got your letter.
('55', 332, 9, 23, 627537) If you ask reason for proof of the existence of God, what proof can reason give since God is above all reason?
('55', 332, 9, 24, 627648) For, if you say that nothing is beyond rational explanation, you will certainly run into difficulties.
('55', 332, 9, 25, 627751) If we give the highest place to reason, we shall be faced with serious difficulties.
('55', 332, 9, 26, 627836) Our own atman is beyond reason.
('55', 332, 9, 27, 627868) People have indeed tried to prove its existence with logical arguments,
('55', 332, 10, 28, 627940) 1 Manilal, Sushila and their daughter
('55', 333, 0, 1, 627978) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 333, 1, 2, 628020) as they have tried to prove the existence of God.
('55', 333, 1, 3, 628070) But he who knows God and the atman with his intellect only does not know them at all.
('55', 333, 1, 4, 628156) Reason may be a useful instrument of knowledge at one stage.
('55', 333, 1, 5, 628217) But anybody who stops there will never enjoy the benefits of true spiritual knowledge, in the same way that intellectual knowledge of the benefits of eating food does not by itself help one to enjoy those benefits.
('55', 333, 1, 6, 628432) God or the atman is not an object of knowledge.
('55', 333, 1, 7, 628480) He Himself is the Knower.
('55', 333, 1, 8, 628506) That is why we say that He is above reason.
('55', 333, 1, 9, 628550) There are two stages of knowledge of God.
('55', 333, 1, 10, 628592) The first is faith, and the second and the last is first hand experience to which faith leads.
('55', 333, 1, 11, 628687) All great teachers of the world have testified to their having had such experience, and people whom the world would ordinarily dismiss as fools have also demonstrated their faith.
('55', 333, 1, 12, 628867) If we have faith, like theirs, one day we may have first hand experience too.
('55', 333, 1, 13, 628945) If a person sees somebody with his eyes but, being deaf, cannot hear him and then complains that he had not heard him, he would net be justified.
('55', 333, 1, 14, 629091) Similarly, to say that reason cannot know God betrays ignorance.
('55', 333, 1, 15, 629156) Just as hearing is not the function of the eyes, so also knowing God is not the function of the senses or of reason.
('55', 333, 1, 16, 629273) To know Him a different kind of faculty is required, and this is unshakable faith.

('55', 337, 6, 13, 635415) 409. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('55', 337, 7, 14, 635442) May 7, 1932
('55', 337, 8, 15, 635454) DEAR COLONEL DOYLE, I wish to bring to your notice a matter that has reached the point of exasperation.
('55', 337, 8, 16, 635558) Over two months ago Sardar Vallabhbhai wrote two letters, one to his son at Bombay and one to Mr. G. V. Mavalankar at Ahmedabad, both of which were of a business type.
('55', 337, 8, 17, 635726) They were duly authorized, but never reached the addressees.
('55', 337, 8, 18, 635787) On March 26th Sjt.
('55', 337, 8, 19, 635806) Mahadev Desai wrote his monthly letter to his wife at the Ashram at Sabarmati.
('55', 337, 8, 20, 635885) The letter never reached her.
('55', 337, 8, 21, 635915) On the 28th ultimo I wrote, by permission, a letter addressed to the Ashram and meant for an erring boy of mine.
('55', 337, 8, 22, 636028) It was a most important letter in answer to his.
('55', 337, 8, 23, 636077) The letter was not delivered at the Ashram, though subsequent letters were delivered.
('55', 337, 8, 24, 636163) Almost invariably the Ashrampost reaches the Ashram two or three days after the due day of delivery.
('55', 337, 8, 25, 636264) I infer from this that the letters are delayed, where they are not withheld entirely, by some authority.
('55', 337, 8, 26, 636369) I know that correspondence of civil resisters is under strict censorship.
('55', 337, 8, 27, 636443) I have nothing to say against it.
('55', 337, 8, 28, 636477) But the correspondence sent from a prison, duly franked by prison authorities would, I should
('55', 338, 0, 1, 636571) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 339
('55', 338, 1, 2, 636617) imagine, be free from further censorship and consequent delay or danger of being withheld altogether.
('55', 338, 1, 3, 636719) I do not write letters uselessly and hope I am meticulous about observing the terms under which I am permitted to write these letters.
('55', 338, 1, 4, 636854) If they require a double censorship, it may be well to let us know.
('55', 338, 1, 5, 636922) If they are withheld even after being passed by prison authorities I think it is due to us that we should know at least the fact of detention.
('55', 338, 1, 6, 637065) The letter that I sent to my son was designed to affect the future course of his conduct and it had attached to it an original letter which my son had sent for my inspection and which he desired should be returned to him.
('55', 338, 1, 7, 637287) I have no desire whatsoever to write a single line that I would not like any Government official to see.
('55', 338, 1, 8, 637392) But I do feel hurt when even letters sent by prisoners that are held to be unobjectionable by prison authorities are delayed or intercepted in course of transmission.
('55', 338, 1, 9, 637559) I should, therefore, thank you if you would kindly enquire of proper authorities as to the fate of the letters in question.
('55', 338, 1, 10, 637683) I should be glad if it were discovered that my suspicions were groundless and that there had been no interference with this correspondence, and that the delays had been accidental and that the missing letters had been found and delivered to the addressees.

('55', 338, 6, 16, 638092) PREMA, If we make it a rule to draw up a balance sheet of our spiritual progress from time to time, we shall be able to get rid of unnecessary fears and appear to the world as we really are.

('55', 339, 1, 5, 638912) He always takes too much work upon himself.

('55', 339, 1, 9, 639162) 1 You should keep a watch.

('55', 339, 1, 11, 639285) If any person living in the Ashram becomes so, I would blame our method of running it.
('55', 339, 1, 12, 639372) I know that that method is not perfect.
('55', 339, 1, 13, 639412) But no one living in the Ashram has become mechanical in his or her work, and many who were mechanical have come to be filled with new life.
