('55', 339, 1, 15, 639627) Those who are in charge of the various activities in the Ashram are not experts in their respective fields.
('55', 339, 1, 16, 639735) It is not their fault that they are not.
('55', 339, 1, 17, 639776) But it has always happened that the Ashram has either undertaken some new type of activity or has decided to carry on a traditional activity in a new manner, and, therefore, it has had to train its own experts.
('55', 339, 1, 18, 639987) This has resulted in some unnecessary expenditure of time and moneys and despite that the Ashram has not always done its work so well as to win praise.
('55', 339, 1, 19, 640139) The Ashram, however, exists not to win praise but toserve.
('55', 339, 1, 20, 640198) If it does the work of service so well that it wins praise for it, we may feel happy.
('55', 339, 1, 21, 640284) But, even if it is criticized, we should continue to serve.
('55', 339, 1, 22, 640344) The conclusion to be drawn from this is that, as we become progressively more efficient, we shall be able to do more work and shall feel the burden of work less and less.

('55', 339, 1, 27, 640818) I have now started spinning on the Magan spinning wheel.
('55', 339, 1, 28, 640875) Yesterday I spun 24 rounds and spent much time.
('55', 339, 1, 29, 640923) Today I spun 56 rounds in less time.
('55', 339, 1, 30, 640960) The fatigue, too, was less.
('55', 339, 1, 31, 640988) What is true about an individual and his small task, is also true about an organization and its big undertakings.
('55', 339, 1, 32, 641102) “Yoga is skill in work.’’ 2 Work here means service, yajna.

('55', 347, 4, 7, 652633) 424. CLEANLINESS, TRUTHFULNESS, PURITY, NEATNESS 1
('55', 347, 5, 8, 652684) May 9, 1932
('55', 347, 6, 9, 652696) Now that I have succeeded today in acquiring over the Magan spinning wheel brought by Dhiru enough elementary control to satisfy me, I feel sufficiently free in my mind to pay attention to the appearance of the wheel.
('55', 347, 6, 10, 652914) Vallabhbhai’s sharp eyes detected a spider’s web on it, and he immediately joked about it.
('55', 347, 6, 11, 653005) I discovered now the real source of Manibehn’s great love of neatness.
('55', 347, 6, 12, 653076) The envelopes in which I seal the letters for the Ashram are an illustration of this quality of Vallabhbhai’s.
('55', 347, 6, 13, 653187) Anybody who has not seen these envelopes should do so immediately.
('55', 347, 6, 14, 653254) Along with neatness, they exemplify great economy.
('55', 347, 6, 15, 653305) The letters which I write from here do not require very long envelopes.
('55', 347, 6, 16, 653377) It will, therefore, be observed that two envelopes are made out of the original one.
('55', 347, 6, 17, 653462) The brown paper which comes here in the form of packets, etc., is preserved and then used for making new flaps for the envelopes.
('55', 347, 6, 18, 653592) This was by way of introduction.
('55', 347, 6, 19, 653625) I noted Vallabhbhai’s comment, but at the moment I was impatient to try the spinning wheel.
('55', 347, 6, 20, 653717) The doctor had been advising me not to use the left hand even for turning the wheel.
('55', 347, 6, 21, 653802) Hence I thought that, if I could rotate the wheel with either foot, probably I would not have to drop spinning for a single day.
('55', 347, 6, 22, 653931) In my impatience to acquire control in managing the spinning wheel as soon as possible, I let the web remain where it was.
('55', 347, 6, 23, 654054) But I felt confident today that I would be able to work with my right hand, and so began observing the poor condition of the spinning wheel.
('55', 347, 6, 24, 654195) I saw that there was not only one web, but that there were webs in seven or eight places.
('55', 347, 6, 25, 654285) And the entire spinning wheel was
('55', 347, 7, 26, 654319) 1 This was sent along with ‘‘Letter to Narandas Gandhi’, 4/9 5 1932; vide the following item.

('55', 348, 1, 2, 654459) covered with dust.
('55', 348, 1, 3, 654478) The brass spindle bearers were covered with a sticky layer of grease and dust.
('55', 348, 1, 4, 654557) There was plenty of dust on the wooden boards too.
('55', 348, 1, 5, 654608) This should be deemed unpardonable.
('55', 348, 1, 6, 654644) The spinning wheel is the divine weapon of Daridranarayana.
('55', 348, 1, 7, 654704) It is the chief means of worship.
('55', 348, 1, 8, 654738) By neglecting it and allowing it to be covered with dust, we show lack of reverence for Him.
('55', 348, 1, 9, 654831) Generally, temples, mosques and other places of worship are kept clean.
('55', 348, 1, 10, 654903) But we believe that every spot on the earth is as sacred as a temple.
('55', 348, 1, 11, 654973) There is no place anywhere where God is not present.
('55', 348, 1, 12, 655026) To us, therefore, our bedrooms, dining rooms, libraries, lavatories—all these are sacred as temples and should be kept clean as such.
('55', 348, 1, 13, 655160) All the more so a spinning wheel.
('55', 348, 1, 14, 655194) If we really believe in its power, none of us, from the very young to the old, would ever let a spinning wheel remain unclean.
('55', 348, 2, 15, 655321) I have already referred once to the cat’s love of cleanliness.
('55', 348, 2, 16, 655384) Recently I observed more evidence of it.
('55', 348, 2, 17, 655425) She gave birth to two kittens about a month and a half ago.
('55', 348, 2, 18, 655485) Their ways are wonderful.
('55', 348, 2, 19, 655511) The three are rarely found separated.
('55', 348, 2, 20, 655549) The mother cat lets the kitten suck whenever they indicate their desire.
('55', 348, 2, 21, 655622) The two cling to her and suck at the same time.
('55', 348, 2, 22, 655670) It is a sublime sight.
('55', 348, 2, 23, 655693) The mother has no feeling of false shame about the matter.
('55', 348, 2, 24, 655752) She does not perform all actions in public and anywhere.
('55', 348, 2, 25, 655809) As soon as the kitten could walk and play, she taught them the procedure to be followed for defecation.
('55', 348, 2, 26, 655913) She withdrew to a quiet spot where the earth was soft and dug out a small hollow.
('55', 348, 2, 27, 655995) She put the kitten in position over the hollow, afterwards covered the excreta with earth and made the spot as clean as it was before.
('55', 348, 2, 28, 656130) The kittens now follow that procedure every day.
('55', 348, 2, 29, 656179) They are a brother and a sister.
('55', 348, 2, 30, 656212) Four days ago, one of them was trying to dig a hollow in the earth, but the ground was rather hard.
('55', 348, 2, 31, 656312) The other one went to its help and the two together dug out a hollow of the required size.
('55', 348, 2, 32, 656403) After defecation, they covered up the excreta with earth and left the place.
('55', 348, 2, 33, 656480) Why should we not willingly do what these creatures—even the little ones—do?
('55', 348, 2, 34, 656557) The four words in the title are intended to suggest the same meaning.
('55', 348, 2, 35, 656627) Since we are conscious of ourselves as souls, our cleanliness must be both internal and external.
('55', 348, 2, 36, 656725) The former means truthfulness.
('55', 348, 2, 37, 656756) Truthfulness is the essence of purity, and is also another name for neatness.
('55', 348, 2, 38, 656834) If we are neat and tidy outwardly but have unclean minds, we make a false show or are guilty of pure hypocrisy, or that may be a sign of our lustfulness.
('55', 348, 2, 39, 656988) Thus, for men and women who strive to lead a
('55', 349, 0, 1, 657033) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 349, 1, 2, 657075) life of self control, outward neatness is of value only if it is a sign of inner purity.

('55', 354, 11, 22, 668721) 430. A LETTER
('55', 354, 12, 23, 668735) May 10, 1932
('55', 354, 13, 24, 668748) When deciding what one’s duty is, many questions may arise.
('55', 354, 13, 25, 668808) But when examining the teaching of the Gita, we have only to consider what Arjuna’s question was.
('55', 354, 13, 26, 668906) If a teacher goes beyond the scope of the question put to him, he would be a bad teacher, for the questioner’s attention would be fixed on his question and he would be in no fit state of mind to listen to other things.
('55', 354, 13, 27, 669125) The discussion may even be beyond his capacity and may, therefore, bore him.
('55', 354, 13, 28, 669202) Further,
('55', 355, 0, 1, 669211) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 355, 1, 2, 669253) the reply to his question is likely to get lost in the discussion about irrelevant issues, in the same way that plants of grains in a field sometimes get buried under the weeds which grow round them.
('55', 355, 1, 3, 669453) From this point of view, Krishna’s reply to Arjuna is perfect.
('55', 355, 1, 4, 669516) And when we leave Chapter I and come to Chapter II, we find that it breathes the pure spirit of ahimsa.
('55', 355, 1, 5, 669620) We should not, believing or claiming that Shri Krishna is the most perfect avatar of God, expect that we can get from his words a simple reply to every question that may arise in our minds in the same manner that we can find the meaning of a word by looking up a dictionary.
('55', 355, 1, 6, 669895) Even if we could find such replies, that would do us harm, for in that case nobody would strive for further advance or new discoveries.
('55', 355, 1, 7, 670031) Man’s reason would simply atrophy.
('55', 355, 1, 8, 670066) Thus, the people of every age should strive to solve the problems of that age by their own hard labour and tapascharya.
('55', 355, 1, 9, 670186) We should, therefore, try to solve the problems which arise in the present age in regard to war and other issues with the help of the principles enunciated in a noble work like the Gita.
('55', 355, 1, 10, 670373) But even such help will be negligible.
('55', 355, 1, 11, 670412) We shall get real help only from what we learn through tapascharya.
('55', 355, 1, 12, 670480) Books on Ayurveda describe the properties of innumerable herbs and plants.
('55', 355, 1, 13, 670555) We may read those descriptions for guidance.
('55', 355, 1, 14, 670600) But the knowledge so gained will be useless, may even be burdensome, if the properties attributed to those herbs and plants do not pass the test of actual experience.
('55', 355, 1, 15, 670767) We have to seek solutions to the many difficult problems of life in exactly the same manner.
('55', 355, 1, 16, 670860) If you still wish to ask me any questions on this subject, please do.
('55', 355, 2, 17, 670930) [From Gujarati]
('55', 355, 3, 18, 670946) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 364, 1, 2, 688776) 438. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAM GANDHI 1
('55', 364, 2, 3, 688812) May 12, 1932
('55', 364, 3, 4, 688825) I got your letter.
('55', 364, 3, 5, 688844) It was a beautiful one.
('55', 364, 3, 6, 688868) My statement that Jainism puts emphasis on pure nyaya 2 has been slightly misund erstood by you.
('55', 364, 3, 7, 688965) Pure nyaya may mean right policy or just decision, and ordinarily that is the sense in which we use the word.
('55', 364, 3, 8, 689075) But I did not use it in that sense.
('55', 364, 3, 9, 689111) I wanted to say that Jainism emphasizes logic, but that logic sometimes leads to wrong conclusions the consequences of which are fearful.
('55', 364, 3, 10, 689249) This is not the fault of logic, but we do not always possess all the data necessary for arriving at a correct conclusion.
('55', 364, 3, 11, 689371) Nor is every word understood by the hearer or the reader in the same sense in which it was used by the speaker or the writer.
('55', 364, 3, 12, 689497) Hence the heart, that is bhakti, faith and first hand experience, is given a higher place than logic.
('55', 364, 3, 13, 689599) Logic is a purely intellectual process.
('55', 364, 3, 14, 689639) We should not care in the least if logic, that is intellect, cannot understand what is self evident to the heart.
('55', 364, 3, 15, 689753) On the contrary, sometimes our intellect is convinced of certain ideas which the heart does not accept.
('55', 364, 3, 16, 689857) We should, then, reject them.
('55', 364, 3, 17, 689887) You will be able to think of any number of illustrations which will explain my point.
('55', 364, 3, 18, 689973) In the sense in which I have used the word nyaya above, it can never be an end in itself.
('55', 364, 3, 19, 690063) Both nyaya and the yoga of desireless work are means.
('55', 364, 3, 20, 690117) The former belongs to the sphere of the intellect, the latter is a matter of the heart.
('55', 364, 3, 21, 690205) We cannot cultivate desirelessness with the help of the intellect.
('55', 364, 4, 22, 690272) Now I will deal with the issue which you have raised.
('55', 364, 4, 23, 690326) Compassion and ahimsa are not two different things.
('55', 364, 4, 24, 690378) Compassion is not opposed to ahimsa.
('55', 364, 4, 25, 690415) Anything which is so opposed is not true compassion.
('55', 364, 4, 26, 690468) We can describe compassion as the concrete expression of ahimsa.
('55', 364, 4, 27, 690533) It is a contradiction in terms to describe any man as free from attachment and without compassion.
('55', 364, 4, 28, 690632) A person who is free from attachment should have a compassionate heart as large as the ocean.
('55', 364, 5, 29, 690726) 1 “Who wrote that according to the Jains even compassion is included in attachment (raga), albeit a desirable one, and therefore Bapu’s action in putting an ailing calf out of pain was not worthy of vitaraga (one who is free from attachment)” (The Diary of Mahadev Desai, Vol. I, pp.
('55', 364, 5, 30, 691010) 108 9).
('55', 364, 5, 31, 691018) 2 Vide “Letter to Purushottam Gandhi”, 18 41932
('55', 365, 0, 1, 691066) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 365, 1, 2, 691108) And when such compassion embraces millions, to say that, though sattvik, it is not free from attachment is to betray ignorance of the meaning of the word or else to give it a new meaning.
('55', 365, 1, 3, 691296) Generally, we use the word in the sense in which Tulsidas has used it.
('55', 365, 1, 4, 691367) His meaning is clear in the following doha 1: n;k /keZ dk ewy gS iki@nsg ewy A Here, compassion is used as a synonym for ahimsa.
('55', 365, 1, 5, 691496) Perfect ahimsa is possible only in the atman in its disembodied state.
('55', 365, 1, 6, 691567) But when the atman takes on a body, ahimsa manifests itself in one as the feeling of compassion.
('55', 365, 1, 7, 691664) Considered from this point of view, my mercy killing of the calf 3 was an expression of the purest ahimsa.
('55', 365, 1, 8, 691771) To endure suffering in one’s own person is the very nature of the atman, but it is contrary to its nature to make or let others suffer.
('55', 365, 1, 9, 691907) If the mercy killing of the calf had been prompted by a desire to relieve my own pain [at its suffering], the act was not ahimsa, but to end the calf’s pain was ahimsa.
('55', 365, 1, 10, 692076) Indeed, ahimsa implies inability to endure other creatures suffering pain.
('55', 365, 1, 11, 692151) From such inability arise compassion, heroism and all other virtues associated with ahimsa.
('55', 365, 1, 12, 692243) It is perverse logic to argue that we should be able to look on while others suffer.
('55', 365, 1, 13, 692328) Again, it is not always true that death is more painful for human beings than anything they may suffer in life.
('55', 365, 1, 14, 692440) I think that it is we ourselves that have made death the terror it is.
('55', 365, 1, 15, 692511) The so called savages do not have the same fear of death.
('55', 365, 1, 16, 692569) The martial races also have very little of it.
('55', 365, 1, 17, 692616) And in the West a school of thought is spreading whose followers would prefer to end their lives rather than go on living in extreme pain.
('55', 365, 1, 18, 692755) I think that the assumption of excessive fear of death proceeds from ignorance or dry theorizing.
('55', 365, 1, 19, 692853) Because of that assumption, we, and especially the Jains, have perverted the meaning of ahimsa, with the result that true ahimsa has practically disappeared.
('55', 365, 1, 20, 693011) A woman who jumps into a well in anger may clutch at a rope offered to her, but one who has jumped into it deliberately under the force of some belief, whatever it be, will disdain to avail herself of a rope even if offered to her.
('55', 365, 1, 21, 693243) The practice of harakiri among the Japanese is a well known example of this.
('55', 365, 1, 22, 693320) Whether that practice is the result of right knowledge or ignorance is beside the point.
('55', 365, 1, 23, 693409) Here I am only pointing out that there are countless instances in which men prefer death to life.
('55', 365, 1, 24, 693507) In the West they kill animals whose condition is hopeless and who suffer extreme pain, and behind this
('55', 365, 2, 25, 693610) 1 Couplet 2 “Compassion is the source of dharma and pride is the source of sin (or, the ego is the cause of the body).”
('55', 366, 0, 1, 693730) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 367
('55', 366, 1, 2, 693776) practice lies the belief that they do not experience much fear of death, and that they will prefer death to suffering pain beyond a certain limit.
('55', 366, 1, 3, 693923) This idea may not be true, and it is, therefore, our duty to behave towards animals as if life was as dear to them as it is to human beings.
('55', 366, 2, 4, 694064) If you accept so much, it is not very necessary to consider the matter from a social point of view or from the point of view of our duty towards society.
('55', 366, 2, 5, 694218) Where the people have regard for ahimsa, there is little risk of the example of my killing the calf being misused.
('55', 366, 2, 6, 694333) Where people have no such regard, in any case animals are killed.
('55', 366, 2, 7, 694399) Thus, my action is not likely to increase violence to animals.
('55', 366, 2, 8, 694462) When killing the calf, it was not necessary for me to know all the possible consequences of my action.
('55', 366, 2, 9, 694565) If it was certain that the calf would never die in any other manner, I should of course have paused before killing it.
('55', 366, 2, 10, 694684) In other words, if it were the case that nobody but I could have ended the calf’s life, it would have been necessary for me to think of all the possible consequences of my action.
('55', 366, 2, 11, 694864) But the fact is that all creatures, calves as much as we, live with the possibility of death always hanging over us.
('55', 366, 2, 12, 694981) Therefore, the utmost that could have happened was that the calf would have lived for a few days or months or a year more.
('55', 366, 2, 13, 695104) These considerations are not irrelevant to the case, since my motive was disinterested and my only aim was to end the pain of the calf.
('55', 366, 2, 14, 695240) We may, therefore, say that even if there was any error in my reasoning, no harmful consequence to the calf followed which would never have followed but for my action.
('55', 366, 2, 15, 695408) 1 Ask me again and again till you have understood the point.
('55', 366, 2, 16, 695469) The subject is an important one and the explanation deserves to be carefully grasped.
('55', 366, 2, 17, 695555) It is easy to grasp, and once it is grasped you will be able to deduce many other consequences from it.
('55', 366, 3, 18, 695659) It is undoubtedly true that my approach to the problem attacks certain generally accepted beliefs.
('55', 366, 3, 19, 695758) But I do believe that we, that is Hindus, have become so full of cowardice and inertia that the true essence of ahimsa is forgotten and the thing has come to be identified with superficial concern for the lives of lower creatures.
('55', 366, 3, 20, 695989) In its essence, ahimsa is a powerful emotion of the heart which finds expression in numerous forms of service.
('55', 366, 3, 21, 696100) If it manifests itself in its perfection even
('55', 366, 4, 22, 696146) 1 The rest of the paragraph is from the C.W. copy.

('55', 368, 4, 30, 699888) 441. WONDERFUL SELF SACRIFICE 1
('55', 368, 5, 31, 699920) May 15, 1932
('55', 368, 6, 32, 699933) Sometimes a lesson in even an ordinary school reader teaches us a great moral.
('55', 368, 6, 33, 700012) Recently I have been reading an Urdu reader.
('55', 368, 6, 34, 700057) Some of the lessons in it are very good.
('55', 368, 6, 35, 700098) One of them produced a profound effect on me.
('55', 368, 6, 36, 700144) Thinking that it may have such effect on others too, I
('55', 368, 7, 37, 700199) 1 Presumaply, this was sent along with ‘‘Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 13/15 5 1932; vide the following item.
('55', 369, 0, 1, 700307) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 369, 1, 2, 700349) give here a summary.
('55', 369, 1, 3, 700370) A few years after the death of the Prophet, there was a great battle between the Arabs and the Romans.
('55', 369, 1, 4, 700473) On both sides large numbers of warriors were killed and a great many wounded.
('55', 369, 1, 5, 700551) Every evening the fighting would stop.
('55', 369, 1, 6, 700590) One evening after the fighting had ended an Arab warrior went round the battlefield to find his cousin.
('55', 369, 1, 7, 700694) If he found the cousin dead, he would bury the body, and if he found him alive he would treat his wounds.
('55', 369, 1, 8, 700800) Thinking that the cousin might be thirsting for water, this Arab carried a jug full of water.
('55', 369, 1, 9, 700894) As, with lamp in hand, he made his way through the bodies of warriors Iying wounded and crying in pain, he found his cousin and indeed he was thirsting for water.
('55', 369, 1, 10, 701057) His wounds were bleeding profusely.
('55', 369, 1, 11, 701093) There was little hope of his remaining alive.
('55', 369, 1, 12, 701139) The Arab held out the jug of water before him.
('55', 369, 1, 13, 701186) Just then they heard a wounded warrior crying pitifully for water.
('55', 369, 1, 14, 701253) The cousin felt compassion for that man and asked the Arab to go first to him and give him water.
('55', 369, 1, 15, 701351) The latter immediately went in the direction from which they had heard the cry.
('55', 369, 1, 16, 701431) This wounded man crying for water was a big chieftain.
('55', 369, 1, 17, 701486) As he was about to take the jug of water from the Arab, they heard somebody else crying for water.
('55', 369, 1, 18, 701585) This chieftain, like the Arab’s cousin, was a man of compassion.
('55', 369, 1, 19, 701650) With great difficulty, he uttered a few words and made gestures to the Arab and explained to him that he should first go to that other person and, give him water.
('55', 369, 1, 20, 701813) Feeling miserable, the Arab ran to the place from which the cries had come.
('55', 369, 1, 21, 701889) But the moment he reached there, the wounded warrior breathed his last and closed his eyes.
('55', 369, 1, 22, 701981) The water had arrived too late.
('55', 369, 1, 23, 702013) The Arab quickly returned to where the wounded chieftain was lying.
('55', 369, 1, 24, 702081) He found that the chieftain, too, was dead.
('55', 369, 1, 25, 702125) With a heavy heart and praying to God, the Arab went back to where his cousin lay, and found that his pulse, too, had stopped and he had died.
('55', 369, 1, 26, 702268) Thus, none of the three got water.
('55', 369, 1, 27, 702303) But the first two won immortal fame.
('55', 369, 1, 28, 702340) The pages of history abound in such instances of pure self sacrifice, and, if they are narrated by a master of the pen, we even shed a few tears over them.
('55', 369, 1, 29, 702496) But I have narrated this wonderful story here with the hope that it may inspire in us the spirit of self sacrifice displayed by those two brave warriors and that, when such occasions arise, we will give water first to others before drinking it ourselves, will save others’ lives before saving our own and if, in trying to do so, we meet death, we will meet it with a smile on our face.
('55', 370, 0, 1, 702882) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 371
('55', 370, 1, 2, 702928) I think even more difficult than the sacrifice of water is that of air.
('55', 370, 1, 3, 703000) Without it we cannot live even for a minute.
('55', 370, 1, 4, 703045) That is why the whole world seems to have been filled with air.
('55', 370, 1, 5, 703109) However, it does sometimes happen that men are locked up in a small room as in a cupboard.
('55', 370, 1, 6, 703200) There is only one small hole letting in air, and only those who get this air are likely to survive and the others would die.
('55', 370, 1, 7, 703325) We should pray to God that if ever we found ourselves in such a condition we would voluntarily give up our place near the hole.
('55', 370, 1, 8, 703453) Next to air comes water.
('55', 370, 1, 9, 703478) We occasionally hear of men fighting for a glass of water.
('55', 370, 1, 10, 703537) We should hope that if we find ourselves in such circumstances, we will have the spirit of self sacrifice displayed by those brave Arabs.
('55', 370, 1, 11, 703675) But very few people are tested in this manner.
('55', 370, 1, 12, 703722) There are less severe tests which we face almost every day.
('55', 370, 1, 13, 703782) Let all of us ask ourselves: Whenever we are confronted by such tests, do we always put our co workers and neighbours before ourselves?
('55', 370, 1, 14, 703918) If the answer is in the negative, then it means that we have failed in the test and that we have not learnt even the first lesson in non violence.
('55', 370, 2, 15, 704065) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('55', 370, 3, 16, 704109) 442. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('55', 370, 4, 17, 704140) [May 13/15, 1932] 1
('55', 370, 5, 18, 704160) NARANDAS, I received two packets from you this time.
('55', 370, 5, 19, 704213) I follow your argument that yarn of 16 counts will be cheaper than that of 20 counts.
('55', 370, 5, 20, 704299) But I think we shall find that on the balance yarn of 20 counts is cheaper, for in spinning such yarn we shall have to remain vigilant all the time.
('55', 370, 5, 21, 704448) The spindle, etc., will have to be kept in good condition.
('55', 370, 5, 22, 704507) By “cheap” I do not mean here merely economical.
('55', 370, 5, 23, 704556) I give to the word a spiritual sense.

('55', 370, 5, 25, 704758) If you find that this results in decrease in production for the time being, never mind.
('55', 370, 5, 26, 704846) Probably you remember one thing which I suggested to you once or twice.
('55', 370, 5, 27, 704918) We should reckon the value of all types of work at the same rate.
('55', 370, 5, 28, 704984) In other words, if a person works for one hour, whether he spins or cards or weaves or does carpentry work or writes accounts or works on the

('55', 371, 1, 3, 705274) For the purpose of our record, I had suggested that the value should be one anna per hour of work.
('55', 371, 1, 4, 705373) If all inmates of the Ashram above the age of ten, other than those who may be bedridden, have been working daily for an average of eight hours, I would say that the Ashram was self supporting.
('55', 371, 1, 5, 705567) This may seem just now to entail loss from the economic point of view, but ultimately the account will balance itself even from that point of view.

('55', 372, 1, 6, 708361) Let me return for a while to the question of 20 counts.

('55', 372, 1, 9, 708829) The fact that the latter lasts longer only means this: Both the varieties of yarn which we spin, 16 counts and 20 counts, are weak.
('55', 372, 1, 10, 708961) But the yarn of 16 counts is likely to be less weak comparatively, and such yarn can be spun even from cotton of inferior quality without its quality being affected.

('55', 380, 1, 3, 723390) BABALBHAI, I hope you can now spin yarn of 20 counts.
('55', 380, 1, 4, 723444) The daily reading of the Gita you find uninteresting because probably you do not reflect over what you read.
('55', 380, 1, 5, 723553) If you look upon the Gita as our mother who guides us daily in our life, you will not find its reading uninteresting.
('55', 380, 1, 6, 723671) After the reading every day, you should reflect for a minute over what you have read.
('55', 380, 1, 7, 723757) You will daily learn something new.
('55', 380, 1, 8, 723793) Only a perfect man will have no more to learn from it.
('55', 380, 1, 9, 723848) But the ordinary man who commits some error or other every day will not weary of reading the Gita if he looks upon it as the mother who will save him from his faults.

('55', 382, 8, 19, 727654) May 16, 1932
('55', 382, 9, 20, 727667) BHAISHRI FULCHAND, All of us were glad to receive your letter.
('55', 382, 9, 21, 727730) We need not worry over such incidents.
('55', 382, 9, 22, 727769) 1 After all we are prisoners, and should be content with whatever facilities we are allowed.
('55', 382, 9, 23, 727862) Time was when prisoners were not permitted either to read or write, were not even given sufficient food to eat, were kept in fetters all the twenty four hours and made to sleep on straw.

('55', 383, 0, 1, 728472) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 383, 1, 2, 728514) We were happy to learn that all of you were happy there.
('55', 383, 1, 3, 728571) After all, happiness and unhappiness are states of one’s own mind.
('55', 383, 1, 4, 728638) The fact that you and Mama obey the rules and persuade others also to obey them and to observe cleanliness does great credit to you both.
('55', 383, 1, 5, 728776) I hope that every one of you there makes the best use of his time.
('55', 383, 1, 6, 728843) You are not likely to get such quiet and leisure again in life.
('55', 383, 1, 7, 728907) You may read if you get books, and you can always think and reflect.
('55', 383, 1, 8, 728976) And there is so much work, too, from which you should volunteer to do something or the other.
('55', 383, 1, 9, 729070) There is one serious mistake which all of us commit, and it is that we waste Government’s time or property as if they did not belong to us personally.
('55', 383, 1, 10, 729221) A little reflection will show that the Government’s time and property belong to the people.
('55', 383, 1, 11, 729313) If we waste them because they are at present controlled by the Government, it is the people’s property and time we waste.
('55', 383, 1, 12, 729435) We should, therefore, make the best use of anything which we have occasion to use.
('55', 383, 1, 13, 729518) The goods also which we produce by our work in jail increase the nation’s wealth.
('55', 383, 1, 14, 729600) The fact that the present Government is foreign does not affect this argument.
('55', 383, 1, 15, 729679) But I would be entering the field of politics if I go further than this, and as prisoners we cannot discuss politics.
('55', 383, 1, 16, 729797) I, therefore, stop here on this subject.
('55', 383, 1, 17, 729838) Tell me, when you write next, who else I know are there, or somebody else whose time for exercising his right of writing a letter has come may write to me.
('55', 383, 1, 18, 729994) Is Diwan Master in that jail?
('55', 383, 1, 19, 730024) Is Madhavlal of the Ashram also there?
('55', 383, 1, 20, 730063) The three of us, it may be said, are really enjoying our time.
('55', 383, 1, 21, 730126) There are no restrictions on food except those which are self imposed, nor on the hours of rest and sleep.
('55', 383, 1, 22, 730233) Carding and spinning are going on fairly well.
('55', 383, 1, 23, 730280) And we also read.
('55', 383, 1, 24, 730298) We get a reasonable supply of newspapers too.
('55', 383, 1, 25, 730344) As for books, friends send them regularly.
('55', 383, 1, 26, 730387) We pray at regular hours.
('55', 383, 1, 27, 730413) That is our daily programme.
('55', 383, 1, 28, 730442) Our regards to you all.
('55', 383, 1, 29, 730466) BAPU From Gujarati: C.W. 9445. Courtesy: Chandrakant F. Shah

('55', 386, 7, 10, 733551) NIRMALA,

('55', 390, 2, 3, 739647) May 19, 1932
('55', 390, 3, 4, 739660) PREMA, Though you are likely to visit me next week, I think it best that I should reply to your letter.
('55', 390, 3, 5, 739764) Moreover, an incident which occurred yesterday shows that my receiving visitors should always be treated as uncertain.
('55', 390, 3, 6, 739883) Vali has proved her worth very well indeed.
('55', 390, 3, 7, 739927) I don’t think the Ashram can take credit for that.
('55', 390, 3, 8, 739978) She seems to have joined it with her character already formed.
('55', 390, 3, 9, 740041) Why girls brought up in the Ashram seem so weak is a problem which I have not been able to solve.
('55', 390, 3, 10, 740139) I have my explanations for that, but I think it useless to discuss them unless I can give reasons in support of them.
('55', 390, 3, 11, 740257) We should try our best to discover the real reasons.
('55', 390, 3, 12, 740310) It should also be borne in mind that, after leaving the Ashram, these girls do not always improve.

('55', 390, 3, 14, 740557) I have discovered no ambiguity in any of my statements.
('55', 390, 3, 15, 740613) If they are ambiguous, they are so unintentionally and because of my imperfect command over language.
('55', 390, 3, 16, 740715) My statements are short, and hence they leave many things unsaid.
('55', 390, 3, 17, 740781) But in this respect they are like propositions in geometry.
('55', 390, 3, 18, 740841) Those girls who wish to learn English may certainly do so if they have paid attention to Hindi and Sanskrit and acquired a good command over Gujarati.

('55', 390, 3, 20, 741071) We ought to have them, no doubt.
('55', 390, 3, 21, 741104) You do not seem to have understood my interpretation of passive exercises.

('55', 390, 3, 23, 741238) Passive exercises are for people who are ill.
('55', 390, 3, 24, 741284) If I am ill and wish to give exercise to my bowels, and if someone massages the abdomen or raises my legs several times to form a right angle with the rest of the body and lowers them again, and I am not required to raise or lower any limb, then that is passive exercise.
('55', 390, 3, 25, 741556) I don’t think you have understood that this is what the phrase means.

('55', 391, 1, 2, 741713) I had two aims in practising silent prayer.

('55', 395, 6, 10, 751477) 475. A LETTER
('55', 395, 7, 11, 751491) May 20, 1932
('55', 395, 8, 12, 751504) You should not be in the least disappointed at seeing no immediate result whatever of your work.
('55', 395, 8, 13, 751601) We should stick to the work undertaken, in single minded devotion to it, with the faith that service done with pure motives, selflessly and as sacrifice to the Lord never fails to bear fruit.
('55', 395, 8, 14, 751793) We even know that often in the past men gave their whole lives to some good cause and the fruits were enjoyed only by those who came after them.
('55', 395, 8, 15, 751938) It should not be a matter of any wonder if four or five years of work by men like us yield no results in a poor, despairing region like Orissa, where several people may have gone under the pretext of public service and robbed the people.

('55', 399, 1, 4, 759274) In spite of knowing that it is imagination, different persons conceive different images.
('55', 399, 1, 5, 759363) As long as the imagination lasts, theimages are true; the devotees ascribe whatever they want, to those images.
('55', 399, 1, 6, 759475) In fact, Vishnu, Maheshwar, Brahma, Bhagwan, Ishwar, etc.
('55', 399, 1, 7, 759533) are all meaningless names or are wanting in meaning.
('55', 399, 1, 8, 759586) But truth conveys full meaning.
('55', 399, 1, 9, 759618) A person who says that he will die for God would not be able to explain what he meant by that and the listener, too, would hardly grasp the meaning of what is told to him.
('55', 399, 1, 10, 759790) But a person who says that he would die for truth, knows what he had said and the listener would also most probably grasp the meaning of it.
('55', 399, 1, 11, 759931) You ask me, “what does Rama mean?” It is almost meaningless to worship Him after I explain to you the meaning.
('55', 399, 1, 12, 760042) But if you worship Rama with the realization that one whom you wanted to worship was Him, only then will he be a Kamadhenu 1 to you.
('55', 399, 1, 13, 760175) If you recite the name of Rama with that faith, be it a parrot like recitation, you will transcend the material world.
('55', 399, 1, 14, 760294) The difference is that you recite the name of Rama with faith in Him which a parrot certainly does not have.
('55', 399, 1, 15, 760403) A parrot is devoid of faith and will therefore feel tired and give up, or, if he worshipped God in pursuit of self interest.
('55', 399, 1, 16, 760528) he will keep quiet after collecting enough grains for himself.
('55', 399, 1, 17, 760591) From this point of view, you do not need a symbol.
('55', 399, 1, 18, 760642) Tulsidas has given more importance to the name of Rama than to Rama, the man.
('55', 399, 1, 19, 760720) That is to say, he has suggested that the name need not have any meaning.
('55', 399, 1, 20, 760794) A devotee will create the necessary meaning later on according to the nature and quality of his faith in Him.
('55', 399, 1, 21, 760904) That is the beauty of the practice of such worship, otherwise it cannot be proved how even the dullest of men can enjoy spiritual awakening.
('55', 399, 1, 22, 761045) The only condition is that the name of God should not be taken to impress others or to deceive others.
('55', 399, 1, 23, 761148) As I have suggested, if a man worships God with faith in Him and never tires of doing so, for him He becomes a Kalpataru.
('55', 399, 1, 24, 761270) I have no doubt about it.
('55', 399, 1, 25, 761296) Men so inclined can prove this for themselves.
('55', 399, 1, 26, 761343) Initially, their mind, while worshiping God, will wander for days together, in some cases for years; they will become restless, feel sleepy, even more than that, they might have some tragic experience, but even then if they keep on worshipping God, their devotion will pay.
('55', 399, 1, 27, 761617) I have no doubt about it.

('55', 404, 1, 2, 769454) 484. THE CAT — A TEACHER 1
('55', 404, 2, 3, 769481) May 22, 1932
('55', 404, 3, 4, 769494) I have already written about our cat’s love of cleanliness.
('55', 404, 4, 5, 769554) Observing her and her kittens’ ways, I feel that she is an ideal teacher.
('55', 404, 4, 6, 769628) Whatever they have to be taught, she teaches quietly and without any fuss.
('55', 404, 4, 7, 769703) The method is quite easy.
('55', 404, 4, 8, 769729) She demonstrates to them by her own example what she wishes to teach, and the kittens learn the thing very quickly.
('55', 404, 4, 9, 769845) In this manner they learnt to run, climb trees and come down again carefully to eat, to kill a prey and to lick their bodies and clean them.
('55', 404, 4, 10, 769986) In a very short time they have learnt to do all that their mother can do.
('55', 404, 4, 11, 770060) The cat does not leave the kittens alone for long.
('55', 404, 4, 12, 770111) Her love for them is just like that of a woman’s for her children.
('55', 404, 4, 13, 770178) She sleeps with the kittens clinging to her.
('55', 404, 4, 14, 770223) When they indicate a desire to suck, she lies down and lets them do it.
('55', 404, 4, 15, 770295) If she has killed a prey, she brings it to them.
('55', 404, 4, 16, 770344) Vallabhbhai gives them some milk every day.
('55', 404, 4, 17, 770388) All three of them lick it from a saucer.
('55', 404, 4, 18, 770429) Sometimes the mother only looks on without sharing the milk.
('55', 404, 4, 19, 770490) She plays with them as if she were their own age, and even engages in a sort of wrestling with them.
('55', 404, 4, 20, 770591) I have drawn a lesson from all this, namely, that if we wish to educate children properly we should ourselves do what we want to teach them to do.
('55', 404, 4, 21, 770738) Children have great capacity for imitating others.
('55', 404, 4, 22, 770789) They do not easily understand what is explained to them orally.
('55', 404, 4, 23, 770853) If we wish to teach them truthfulness, we ourselves should be scrupulously truthful.
('55', 404, 4, 24, 770938) If we wish to teach them not to keep with them more things than they need, we, too, should not do that.
('55', 404, 4, 25, 771042) And what is true about moral rules is true about bodily labour.
('55', 404, 4, 26, 771106) Looking at the matter in this light, we immediately see that the present day education produces very little result, considering the expenditure of money and time which it involves.
('55', 404, 4, 27, 771287) We also realize that all grown ups are teachers so far as children are concerned.
('55', 404, 4, 28, 771369) It is because people do not pay proper attention to their duty as teachers that education has degenerated.
('55', 404, 5, 29, 771476) 1 This was sent along with ‘‘Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 19/23 5 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 19/23 5 1932 2Vide “Cleanliness, Truthfulness, Purity, Neatness”, 9 5 1932
('55', 405, 0, 1, 771656) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 405, 1, 2, 771698) Creatures like cats have no reason, or say, they do not have reason like man’s.
('55', 405, 1, 3, 771778) We, therefore, should do much more than what they do.
('55', 405, 1, 4, 771832) But before we can do so, as guardians of the moral character of the next generation we should observe moral principles in our own lives.
('55', 405, 1, 5, 771969) We should learn, to the best of our ability, to live as we wish the next generation to live.
('55', 405, 1, 6, 772062) I have written all this with the hope that all men and women inmates of the Ashram who give their services as teachers, and others too, may think along these lines and, wherever necessary, act accordingly.
('55', 405, 2, 7, 772268) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('55', 407, 2, 8, 775275) 490. A LETTER May 22, 1932 CHI., We ourselves are the source of moha 2. There are two powers dwelling within us: the divine and the demoniac, the Pandavas and the Kauravas.
('55', 407, 2, 9, 775448) The demoniac is the source of moha.
('55', 407, 2, 10, 775484) Why should we not fix our minds on the true Mahadeva instead of on His image made of earth?
('55', 407, 2, 11, 775576) Or rise from the inert matter to spirit?
('55', 407, 2, 12, 775617) If we cling to the trunk,we automatically get hold of the branch.
('55', 407, 2, 13, 775683) If, on the contrary, we cling to the branch, the branch will break and we shall fall with it.
('55', 407, 2, 14, 775777) It is no sin to think about people with whom we are related by blood.
('55', 407, 2, 15, 775847) However, we wish to enlarge our definition of blood relations so as to include in it all people.
('55', 407, 2, 16, 775944) If we make a distinction between ‘ours’ and ‘the others’, we suffer in innumerable ways.
('55', 407, 2, 17, 776033) If we imbibe the truth that the two are the same, there will remain the pain of neither separation nor death.
('55', 407, 2, 18, 776143) Do not look upon this as philosophical or difficult knowledge and be scared by it.
('55', 407, 2, 19, 776226) It deserves to be digested.
('55', 407, 2, 20, 776254) Such an attitude of mind means not diminishing of love but its enlargement.
('55', 407, 2, 21, 776330) In truth, we always go on, knowingly or unknowingly, enlarging our idea of ‘ours’.
('55', 407, 2, 22, 776413) If we carefully grasp this supremelyvaluable law, it leads to very important results.
('55', 407, 2, 23, 776499) From all I have written, accept only as much as you can digest and leave the rest.
('55', 407, 2, 24, 776582) The rule that applies to food applies here also I hope that the change of climate will do you good.
('55', 407, 2, 25, 776682) BAPU From Gujarati: C.W. 9117. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('55', 410, 4, 26, 780749) One labourer may be a smoker and still be good in other ways, while another who does not smoke may be a very bad man.

('55', 410, 4, 28, 780922) Hence, while paying attention to the habits of those whom you engage as labourers, pay as much attention as you can to their inner character as well.

('55', 417, 2, 3, 791824) May 24, 1932 Boys and girls should be married only after they have grown up.
('55', 417, 2, 4, 791901) The partners should choose each other with the consent of their parents.
('55', 417, 2, 5, 791974) Hence there is no unnatural restriction in such a method.
('55', 417, 2, 6, 792032) If anybody asks my opinion, I would say that marriage between persons following different faiths was a risky experiment.
('55', 417, 2, 7, 792153) If both husband and wife believe in their respective religions and actively follow them in their lives, difficulties are likely to arise between them.
('55', 417, 2, 8, 792304) Thus I think that the Bhatia girl’s marriage is a risky step, but I do not regard it as irreligious.
('55', 417, 2, 9, 792405) I would not oppose it if their love is pure, if the Bhatia girl can follow her religion and the Muslim youth his and if their ideas about food are the same.
('55', 417, 2, 10, 792562) But I do not advocate marriages between persons of different faiths as I advocate inter caste marriages because I desire the disappearance of sub castes.
('55', 417, 2, 11, 792716) I would not agitate against such marriages either.
('55', 417, 2, 12, 792767) This is an issue on which every man and woman should think and decide for himself or herself.
('55', 417, 2, 13, 792861) There cannot be a uniform law for all.
('55', 417, 2, 14, 792900) [From Gujarati]

('55', 417, 5, 17, 792976) May 25, 1932 When I said that writing about the abuse of occult powers you might have been stronger, 1 I used the adjective precisely in the same sense in which I use it regarding admitted evils.
('55', 417, 5, 18, 793172) I feel that whilst we should spare evil doers, we dare not be sparing in our condemnation of evil.
('55', 417, 5, 19, 793271) Perfect gentleness is not inconsistent with clearest possible denunciation of what one knows to be evil, so long as that knowledge persists; and there would need to be no cause for regret later if our knowledge of the past was found to be a great error of judgment.
('55', 417, 5, 20, 793537) In our endeavour to approach absolute truth we shall always have to be content with relative truth from time to time, the relative at each stage being for us as good as the absolute.
('55', 417, 5, 21, 793720) It can be easily demonstrated

('55', 418, 6, 19, 795665) I too have ideals, however much they may be obscured by my conduct.
('55', 418, 6, 20, 795733) Judge me as you would yourself.’ I avoid all adjectives of judgement as poison and try in all that I say to be completely objective.

('55', 420, 1, 2, 798447) 508. LETTER TO RELATIVES OF DARBARI SADHU
('55', 420, 2, 3, 798489) May 25, 1932
('55', 420, 3, 4, 798502) Please tell Darbari that there was no need for him to give up the kasti 1 and sadra 2, and that it would be proper for him to resume them as soon as he returned home.
('55', 420, 3, 5, 798669) There is no sin in wearing them, nor is it superstitious to do so.
('55', 420, 3, 6, 798736) By wearing them he does no harm to anybody, but by not wearing them he gives pain to other Parsis.
('55', 420, 3, 7, 798835) It does not befit a servant of the people to give pain to anybody needlessly, and moreover such behaviour is a violation of ahimsa.
('55', 420, 3, 8, 798967) It should be enough if one does not attach undue importance to these things.
('55', 420, 3, 9, 799044) One should not idolize them, and he does not do that.
('55', 420, 3, 10, 799098) The two things are only outward signs of one’s being a Parsi, and I do not think it desirable from any point of view to discard them.
('55', 420, 3, 11, 799232) I have asked Dahyabhai to bring for him books containing the teachings of Zoroaster.
('55', 420, 3, 12, 799317) I have read Zoroaster’s sayings.
('55', 420, 3, 13, 799350) I read a translation of the Vendidad 3 many years ago.
('55', 420, 3, 14, 799405) The work is rich in ethical teaching.
('55', 420, 3, 15, 799443) Since Zoroastrianism is a very old faith, it is possible that all its scriptures have not survived and that those which are extant do not contain spiritual knowledge of the same order as the Upanishads and other works do.
('55', 420, 3, 16, 799665) Darbari should read the extant works and reflect over them.
('55', 420, 3, 17, 799725) But even today it is accepted that Zoroaster’s teaching is based on that of the Vedas.
('55', 420, 3, 18, 799812) As far as I remember, the translator of the Vendidad has pointed out a close similarity between Zend and Sanskrit.
('55', 420, 3, 19, 799927) It is, therefore, in no way derogatory to Zoroastrianism or to the self respect of the Parsi community to fill in the deficiencies which may be observed in the Parsi scriptures with the help of the Vedas and the Upanishads.
('55', 420, 3, 20, 800151) In fact, it is our right, even our duty, while adhering to our own religion, to accept from other religions anything which specially appeals to us.
('55', 420, 3, 21, 800299) It is fanaticism to think that we cannot adopt anything from other religions, and Darbari and all of us have grown out of it.
('55', 420, 3, 22, 800425) [From Gujarati]
('55', 420, 4, 23, 800441) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.
('55', 420, 5, 24, 800473) 1 Sacred thread and shirt worn by Parsis 2 Videvdat, a later Avestan writing 3 ibid

('55', 421, 1, 2, 800599) 509. LETTER TO BHUSKUTE 1
('55', 421, 2, 3, 800625) May 25, 1932
('55', 421, 3, 4, 800638) What do you mean by asserting that there is no guiding force in the universe?
('55', 421, 3, 5, 800716) How can we make such an assertion?
('55', 421, 3, 6, 800751) My statement seems to have been somewhat twisted in this context.
('55', 421, 3, 7, 800817) I have only said that Truth is identical with God and you may take it to be the Moving Spirit.
('55', 421, 3, 8, 800912) In this context karta 2 does not have the meaning we usually attribute to it.
('55', 421, 3, 9, 800990) Therefore Truth is karta as well as akarta 3. But this is only an intellectual explanation.
('55', 421, 3, 10, 801082) There is nothing wrong in this matter in believing whatever one’s heart accepts, as no man has perfect knowledge of God nor can he express whatever little knowledge he has.
('55', 421, 3, 11, 801255) It is true that I do not depend upon my intellect to decide upon any action.
('55', 421, 3, 12, 801332) For me the reasoned course of action is held in check subject to the sanction of the inner voice.
('55', 421, 3, 13, 801430) I do not know if others would call it the mysterious power or whatsoever.
('55', 421, 3, 14, 801504) I have never deliberated upon this nor analysed it, I have felt no need of doing so either.
('55', 421, 3, 15, 801596) I have faith, and knowledge, too, that a Power exists beyond reasoning.
('55', 421, 3, 16, 801668) This suffices for me.
('55', 421, 3, 17, 801690) I am unable to clarify this any further as I know nothing more in the matter.
('55', 421, 3, 18, 801768) [From Hindi]
('55', 421, 4, 19, 801781) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 423, 3, 4, 804516) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter.
('55', 423, 3, 5, 804555) The letter I addressed to Gwalior was somewhat lengthy.
('55', 423, 3, 6, 804611) I recollect this much but nothing of the contents.
('55', 423, 3, 7, 804662) We must consider the views of the workers regarding working in three shifts and also the extent of the material and moral benefit to them from it.
('55', 423, 3, 8, 804809) If they gain materially but lose morally, it will not be acceptable to me.

('55', 426, 6, 16, 811861) As regards his Urdu studies, Bapu wrote to Devdas Gandhi: There are lessons on history in each reader.
('55', 426, 6, 17, 811964) Some of them deal with the Prophet and his times, while others are concerned with Muslim rulers in India.
('55', 426, 6, 18, 812070) The standpoint from which these are written should be understood by everyone.
('55', 426, 6, 19, 812148) I have an increasing realization of the importance of Urdu studies.
('55', 426, 6, 20, 812216) By learning to write a language in its own script we can write letters in it.
('55', 426, 6, 21, 812294) Moreover we thus also acquire greater mastery over the language, and are better able to decipher as well as understand letters received by us.
('55', 426, 6, 22, 812437) I believe we should learn how to write Urdu letters to Muslim co workers.
('55', 426, 6, 23, 812511) If we are compelled to write to them in English, Hindi can never take its legitimate place as the national language.
('55', 426, 6, 24, 812628) That is why I think that ability to write in Urdu is an essential part of our mental equipment.

('55', 434, 5, 27, 825335) 529. LESSON OF DEATH 1
('55', 434, 6, 28, 825358) May 30, 1932 So far as I remember, the following deaths have occurred in the Ashram till now: Fakiri, Vrajlal, Maganlal, Gita, Meghji, Vasant, Imam Saheb and Gangadevi.
('55', 434, 6, 29, 825527) (It would be desirable to record the dates on which these persons died).
('55', 434, 7, 30, 825600) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 26/30 5 1932; vide the following item.
('55', 435, 0, 1, 825695) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 435, 1, 2, 825737) Fakiri’s death cannot be described as one befitting an inmate of the Ashram.
('55', 435, 1, 3, 825814) The Ashram had been recently established when he died and he had not imbibed its moral and spiritual influence.
('55', 435, 1, 4, 825926) He was no doubt a brave boy.
('55', 435, 1, 5, 825955) I have made the foregoing remark as he died a victim of gluttony.
('55', 435, 1, 6, 826021) His death was a test for me.
('55', 435, 1, 7, 826050) I remember that I sat up, alone, by his side for the whole night on the last day of his life.
('55', 435, 1, 8, 826144) In the morning, I had to catch a train for Gurukul.
('55', 435, 1, 9, 826196) I watched the bier being borne away and then, hardening my heart to stone, took the road to the station.
('55', 435, 1, 10, 826301) Fakiri’s father had entrusted him and his three brothers to me, knowing that I would make no distinction between them and others.
('55', 435, 1, 11, 826431) When Fakiri had gone, I lost the other three brothers too.
('55', 435, 1, 12, 826490) Vrajlal had joined the Ashram when he was well advanced in years and met his death while doing an act of service, thus winning immortal fame for himself and bringing glory to the Ashram.
('55', 435, 1, 13, 826677) He had descended into a well to bring up a child’s pot and, while climbing up, because of fatigue lost his grip of the rope and fell and died.
('55', 435, 1, 14, 826820) Gita passed away peacefully, hearing verses from the Gita.
('55', 435, 1, 15, 826879) Meghji was an undisciplined child, but he preserved wonderful peace during his illness.
('55', 435, 1, 16, 826967) In most cases children suffer a great deal when seriously ill and are difficult patients to nurse.
('55', 435, 1, 17, 827066) But Meghji was an almost ideal patient.
('55', 435, 1, 18, 827106) Vasant did not have to be nursed for a long time.
('55', 435, 1, 19, 827156) A fatal attack of smallpox carried him away in a day or two.
('55', 435, 1, 20, 827217) His death was a painful test for Panditji and Lakshmibehn, and they stood it well.
('55', 435, 1, 21, 827300) What shall I say about Maganlal?
('55', 435, 1, 22, 827333) We are describing here the deaths which occurred in the Ashram.
('55', 435, 1, 23, 827397) Hence Maganlal’s name has no place in the list.
('55', 435, 1, 24, 827445) But how can I leave it out?
('55', 435, 1, 25, 827473) He had come into the world to serve the Ashram.
('55', 435, 1, 26, 827521) As gold is tested in fire, Maganlal was tested in the fire of service, and passed away after proving his perfect worth.
('55', 435, 1, 27, 827641) Everything that we see in the Ashram bears witness to Maganlal’s devoted service.
('55', 435, 1, 28, 827723) Imam Saheb’s was the only Muslim family in the Ashram and all the members were perfectly loyal to its ideals.
('55', 435, 1, 29, 827833) His death has created an unbreakable bond between us and Muslims.
('55', 435, 1, 30, 827899) Imam Saheb regarded himself as a representative of Muslims and had joined the Ashram as one.
('55', 435, 1, 31, 827992) (I remember here Amina’s two children.
('55', 435, 1, 32, 828031) But they were only infants and there is little to say about them.
('55', 435, 1, 33, 828097) Their deaths certainly teach us the necessity of self control.)
('55', 436, 0, 1, 828161) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 437
('55', 436, 1, 2, 828207) Gangadevi’s face is still vivid before my eyes, and I seem to hear her voice too.
('55', 436, 1, 3, 828289) I still take pleasure in recalling memories of her.
('55', 436, 1, 4, 828341) Her life teaches all of us, and particularly women, many lessons.
('55', 436, 1, 5, 828407) Though practically illiterate, she possessed spiritual wisdom.
('55', 436, 1, 6, 828470) She was the only person who, of her own accord, refused to go for change of air though she could have gone.
('55', 436, 1, 7, 828578) She looked after every child entrusted to her care as if it was her own.
('55', 436, 1, 8, 828651) I do not remember any occasion when she had quarrelled with somebody or got angry.
('55', 436, 1, 9, 828734) She was not attached to life.
('55', 436, 1, 10, 828764) She did not fear death— she met it with a smile on her face.
('55', 436, 1, 11, 828825) She knew the art of dying, for there is an art of dying as there is of living.
('55', 436, 1, 12, 828904) I have recalled all these deaths lest we forget what we are.
('55', 436, 1, 13, 828965) Our earth is like a particle of sand in this vast universe.
('55', 436, 1, 14, 829025) On that particle of dust we are, so far as our bodies are concerned, mere specks.
('55', 436, 1, 15, 829107) We cannot count the number of ants in an ant hill, and cannot even see with our naked eyes creatures smaller than the ant.
('55', 436, 1, 16, 829230) In relation to the Cosmic Form of the Lord, we are smaller than even the invisible creatures on our earth.
('55', 436, 1, 17, 829337) That is why there is perfect truth in the description of this body as kshanabhangur 1. Why should we be attached to it?
('55', 436, 1, 18, 829457) Why should we cause pain to a single ceature for its sake?
('55', 436, 1, 19, 829516) Why should we move heaven and earth to preserve something which is more brittle even than glass?
('55', 436, 1, 20, 829613) Death means nothing but the soul leaving that body.
('55', 436, 1, 21, 829665) Why should we fear it, then?
('55', 436, 1, 22, 829694) Why all this desperate struggle to delay its coming?
('55', 436, 1, 23, 829747) Let us all, grown up and young, ponder over this constantly and give up the fear of death, and, while the body lasts, spend it in the service of others.
('55', 436, 1, 24, 829900) We recite daily the last 19 verses of Chapter II of the Gita in order that we may get the strength to live in this manner.
('55', 436, 1, 25, 830023) We shall find in them what we seek only if they fill our very hearts.
('55', 436, 1, 26, 830093) After I had finished the foregoing, Mahadev reminds me of the deaths of Fatima, Kaki 2 and Valji’s mother.
('55', 436, 1, 27, 830200) But I leave the discourse as it is, since their inclusion would not affect the lesson which I have drawn.
('55', 436, 1, 28, 830306) Even so, I may say that what I was told about these deaths fills my mind with holy thoughts.

('55', 440, 2, 20, 839699) The doctors are convinced that this pain has no connection with my diet.
('55', 440, 2, 21, 839772) People who play tennis also get such pain sometimes, and the doctors believe that, because of my regular spinning for many years, I have strained the elbow much more than tennis players do.
('55', 440, 2, 22, 839962) Hence they think that it requires complete rest for some time.
('55', 440, 4, 23, 840025) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I. Also C.W. 8829. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('55', 440, 5, 24, 840111) 1Vide “Cable to J. F. Horrabin”, 3 1 1932
('55', 441, 0, 1, 840153) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 441, 1, 2, 840195) 531. LETTER TO GULCHEN LUMSDEN 1
('55', 441, 2, 3, 840228) May 30, 1932
('55', 441, 3, 4, 840241) DEAR SISTER, I thank you for your letter.
('55', 441, 3, 5, 840283) I well remember the visit of Sir Henry Lawrence to this prison in 1922 or 23, and he is right in his impression that I then passed my time principally between reading The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire and spinning at the wheel.
('55', 441, 3, 6, 840518) It is also true that he found me quite happy.
('55', 441, 3, 7, 840564) But there was no “lovely orchard” then, nor is there now.
('55', 441, 3, 8, 840622) There were then, as there are now, some tall trees about.
('55', 441, 3, 9, 840680) The rooms are bare and barred cells of an ordinary Indian prison.
('55', 441, 3, 10, 840746) As cells they are well lighted and well ventilated.
('55', 441, 3, 11, 840798) So long therefore as the surroundings are concerned, there is no question of my memory betraying me, for at the time of writing I am exactly in the same surroundings as when Sir Henry saw me.
('55', 441, 3, 12, 840990) If therefore his description of them gave you the impression of a fairy tale, it was surely erroneous.
('55', 441, 3, 13, 841093) Happiness after all is a mental state, and for myself, being used, now for more than a generation, to a hard life, I have learnt to detach my happiness from my surroundings.
('55', 441, 4, 14, 841267) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('55', 441, 5, 15, 841297) From a photostat: C.W. 9527. Courtesy: Mrs. Hugh Lumsden, Canada

('55', 442, 4, 9, 842526) 533. A LETTER 1
('55', 442, 5, 10, 842542) May 30, 1932 In my opinion unity will come not by mechanical means but by change of heart and attitude on the part of the leaders of public opinion.
('55', 442, 5, 11, 842691) I do not conceive religion as one of the many activities of mankind.
('55', 442, 5, 12, 842760) The same activity may be either governed by the spirit of religion or irreligion.
('55', 442, 5, 13, 842842) There is no such thing for me therefore as leaving politics for religion.
('55', 442, 5, 14, 842916) For me, every, the tiniest, activity is governed by what I consider to be my religion.
('55', 442, 6, 15, 843003) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('55', 443, 4, 4, 843696) 535. LETTER TO RAMESHWARDAS PODDAR
('55', 443, 5, 5, 843731) May 30, 1932
('55', 443, 6, 6, 843744) BHAI RAMESHWARDAS, I got your letter.
('55', 443, 6, 7, 843782) I hope that you got my last letter which I wrote before you wrote yours and which I sent to you through the Ashram.
('55', 443, 6, 8, 843898) Stick to the vow of spinning.
('55', 443, 6, 9, 843928) Do not take any new vow until your mind has become firm.
('55', 443, 6, 10, 843985) However, adhere with the utmost firmness to the vows which you have taken and maintained so far.
('55', 443, 6, 11, 844082) Even a small vow becomes a rudder to the ship of one’s life, if one sticks to it in the face of all difficulties.
('55', 443, 6, 12, 844196) It will be all right if you can win over your mother and sister in law with loving persuasion, otherwise you should patiently tolerate their opposition.
('55', 443, 6, 13, 844349) They should not be forced against their wishes.
('55', 443, 6, 14, 844397) It will be good if you send the boy to the Gurukul at Kangri.
('55', 443, 6, 15, 844459) There he will learn Hindi, Sanskrit and English and almost everything else that they teach at a high school.
('55', 443, 6, 16, 844568) If he is unwilling to go to the Gurukul, he may go to Santiniketan.
('55', 443, 6, 17, 844636) In that case he should learn Bengali.
('55', 443, 6, 18, 844674) If even that does not suit him, he may join the Kashi Vishvavidyalaya.
('55', 443, 6, 19, 844745) He will not be able to study at home.
('55', 443, 6, 20, 844783) Since you have withdrawn him from the high school there, it would not be proper to send him back to it.
('55', 443, 6, 21, 844887) Nor would it be right to interrupt his studies.
('55', 443, 6, 22, 844935) It would, therefore, be desirable to send him to one of the three places mentioned above.
('55', 443, 7, 23, 845025) Blessings from
('55', 443, 9, 24, 845040) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 181

('55', 444, 0, 1, 845196) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 445
('55', 444, 1, 2, 845242) 536. A LETTER 1
('55', 444, 2, 3, 845258) May 30, 1932 I believe, and doctors also hold the same view, that no woman can be absolutely and simply raped.
('55', 444, 2, 4, 845369) Not being prepared to die, a woman yields to the wrongdoer.
('55', 444, 2, 5, 845429) But a woman who has overcome all fear of death would die before submitting to the outrage.
('55', 444, 2, 6, 845520) It is easy to say this, but difficult to act in this manner.
('55', 444, 2, 7, 845581) Hence when a woman yields to the wrongdoer unwillingly, it is but right that we should regard her as having been raped.
('55', 444, 2, 8, 845701) If such a woman becomes pregnant, she should not resort to abortion.
('55', 444, 2, 9, 845770) A woman who has been the victim of a rape does not deserve any censure.
('55', 444, 2, 10, 845842) On the contrary, people should have compassion for her.
('55', 444, 2, 11, 845898) If, however, a woman wishes to conceal the very fact of her having been raped, who is to say what right she has, whether or not she has a right to resort to abortion?
('55', 444, 2, 12, 846065) In her fright she would believe that she had such a right and do as she wished.
('55', 444, 2, 13, 846145) After the outrage, a woman has no right at all to commit suicide, nor need she do it.
('55', 444, 2, 14, 846231) My replies to your letters or to the letters of others, being written from jail, must not be published.
('55', 444, 2, 15, 846335) I write numerous letters from here and it would not at all be proper to publish them.
('55', 444, 2, 16, 846421) The Government may even tolerate the publication of all these letters, but a satyagrahi ought not to take such freedom.
('55', 444, 2, 17, 846541) This is one of the restrictions which a satyagrahi voluntarily imposes on himself.
('55', 444, 2, 18, 846624) The world is not impatient to know my views and act according to them.
('55', 444, 2, 19, 846695) Even if it is, it should exercise patience at present.
('55', 444, 2, 20, 846750) Nor do I myself attach so much value to my views.
('55', 444, 2, 21, 846800) And, moreover, I cannot say about any view which I may express now that I will not change it in future.
('55', 444, 2, 22, 846904) I may not mind expressing my personal views to a person like you.
('55', 444, 2, 23, 846970) I would assume that you would bear in mind my temperament and my short comings and take them for what they are worth.
('55', 444, 2, 24, 847088) And now about the questions you put.
('55', 444, 2, 25, 847125) Some of them are such as should not be asked at all.
('55', 444, 2, 26, 847178) A seeker may ask a person in whom he has faith for solutions to a very few of his immediate difficulties.
('55', 444, 2, 27, 847284) He should never raise hypothetical issues.
('55', 444, 2, 28, 847327) He may certainly ask if he has any doubt about a step which he intends to take.
('55', 444, 2, 29, 847407) If he asks a question
('55', 444, 3, 30, 847429) 1The Diary of Mahadev Desai Vol. I, gives only the initial letter ‘‘S” of the addressee’s name.
('55', 445, 0, 1, 847525) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 445, 1, 2, 847567) about something which has really happened, he should give all details of the incident.
('55', 445, 1, 3, 847654) He should not frame a general question on the basis of the incident, for in doing so he might ignore some relevant detail of that incident.
('55', 445, 1, 4, 847794) It would be risky, in that case, to apply to that particular incident the reply given to a general question.
('55', 445, 2, 5, 847903) [From Gujarati]
('55', 445, 3, 6, 847919) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 467, 6, 17, 889929) 538. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('55', 467, 7, 18, 889953) June 1, 1932
('55', 467, 8, 19, 889966) MIRA, 1
('55', 467, 9, 20, 889974) Your letter arrived today.
('55', 467, 9, 21, 890001) I have now decided to stop the interviews from next week if the decision is delayed 2. They will be resumed if the decision is favourable.
('55', 467, 10, 22, 890140) The left elbow has proved worse than the right hand.
('55', 467, 10, 23, 890193) All work with the left elbow has stopped and presently it will be packed in splints.
('55', 467, 10, 24, 890278) Doctors are sure that it is nothing but the strain caused by the uninterrupted working of the wheel from day to day.
('55', 467, 10, 25, 890395) I am thankful that I have now acquired full control over the Magan wheel.
('55', 467, 10, 26, 890469) Spinning, therefore, continues and will continue merrily, unless the right elbow strikes from sympathy.
('55', 467, 11, 27, 890573) 1 Superscription in this and other letters to Mirabehn is in Devanagari.
('55', 467, 11, 28, 890646) 2 Gandhiji had requested the Government to reconsider their decision not to permit Mirabehn to see him in Yeravda Jail as otherwise he might not avail himself of the permission to receive other visitors; vide “Letter to E. E. Doyle”, 19 5 1932; also “Letter to E. E. Doyle”, 9 6 1932.
('55', 468, 0, 1, 890931) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 469
('55', 468, 1, 2, 890977) You will be glad to learn that today I weighed 106 1/2 lb.
('55', 468, 1, 3, 891036) This is a good record.
('55', 468, 1, 4, 891059) So you see that there is not the slightest cause for worry even on account of the elbow.
('55', 468, 1, 5, 891148) Your saltless experiment is producing interesting results.
('55', 468, 1, 6, 891207) I should, however, wait before ascribing all the good results to the absence of salt.
('55', 468, 1, 7, 891293) I wrote to Verrier 1 last week care of Khambhatta.
('55', 468, 1, 8, 891344) I hope he got my letter.
('55', 468, 1, 9, 891369) Yes, it is a good idea, his going to England for recuperation.
('55', 468, 1, 10, 891432) The sooner he goes the better.
('55', 468, 1, 11, 891463) It was very wrong of Shamrao to have had that fever.
('55', 468, 1, 12, 891516) Have you seen him?
('55', 468, 1, 13, 891535) I am sorry about Damodardas.
('55', 468, 1, 14, 891564) The enclosed is for him..
('55', 468, 1, 15, 891590) It is a superstition to think that saltless is tasteless.
('55', 468, 1, 16, 891648) Salt kills flavour.
('55', 468, 1, 17, 891668) I have known pepole not touch things with salt in them.
('55', 468, 1, 18, 891724) Taste is a matter of habit.
('55', 468, 1, 19, 891752) I suppose you do take butter and bread.
('55', 468, 1, 20, 891792) These do contain salt.
('55', 468, 1, 21, 891815) Your experiment is one of reducing the quantity of free salt.
('55', 468, 1, 22, 891877) The effect produced on you, therefore, is due to reduction, not entire absence of salt in your food.
('55', 468, 1, 23, 891978) But that does not matter.
('55', 468, 1, 24, 892004) Nor needyou worry that you are taking some salt somehow.
('55', 468, 1, 25, 892061) Let well alone.
('55', 468, 1, 26, 892077) Do you ever see Manilal?
('55', 468, 1, 27, 892102) Or is he still not there at all?
('55', 468, 1, 28, 892135) Love from us all.
('55', 468, 2, 29, 892153) BAPU [PS.] Verrier suggested that we should sing a Christian 2 hymn every Friday at evening prayer.
('55', 468, 2, 30, 892253) So Mahadev began “Lead, Kindly Light” in Gujarati 3. And this we shall continue every Friday.
('55', 468, 2, 31, 892347) Please tell Verrier this if he has not yet got my letter.

('55', 469, 0, 1, 892593) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 469, 1, 2, 892635) 539. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('55', 469, 2, 3, 892668) YERAVDA MANDIR 1, June 1, 1932
('55', 469, 3, 4, 892699) PARASRAM, 2
('55', 469, 4, 5, 892711) I was glad to hear that Nirmala’s enthusiasm for Hindi was increasing.
('55', 469, 4, 6, 892782) By all means teach Hindi poems.
('55', 469, 4, 7, 892814) I do not know whether the lines on the palms (of our hands) have any significance, but there is no profit in trying to know what the future holds whether through these or through astrology or by any other means; on the contrary, it is definitely harmful.
('55', 469, 4, 8, 893069) And, one who is a lover of the Gita, i.e., who leaves the results of one’s work to God, should never desire to know the future.
('55', 469, 4, 9, 893197) I have not received the booklet, but will go through it when I get it.
('55', 469, 4, 10, 893268) Destruction of small creatures as a result of essential activities is unavoidable.
('55', 469, 4, 11, 893351) As far as possible, we should be careful about those which we can see with our naked eyes; more than this, we cannot do.
('55', 469, 4, 12, 893472) Tiny insects like ants are not crushed under our feet when we walk.
('55', 469, 4, 13, 893540) They are protected by their very smallness.
('55', 469, 4, 14, 893584) But larger insects may be so crushed.
('55', 469, 4, 15, 893622) Hence it has been regarded as our duty to look at the ground in front of us while walking.
('55', 469, 4, 16, 893713) All these precautions are signs of our kind heartedness, but non violence is something more far reaching and wonderful.
('55', 469, 4, 17, 893833) It should be apparent in all our work, in our relationship with one another and in all our dealings with our fellowmen.
('55', 469, 4, 18, 893953) We should remain unconcerned when we see a peacock devouring a snake.
('55', 469, 4, 19, 894023) The latter is food for the former and we cannot interfere with it.
('55', 469, 4, 20, 894090) Tulsidas’s quatrain 3 about women which you have quoted is not only not applicable to all women but it is not even a criticism of women.
('55', 469, 4, 21, 894227) It criticizes man’s sensuality.
('55', 469, 4, 22, 894259) Tulsidasji’s point in it is that man, being lustful, thinks only of women, and he has written these lines to show what man becomes like when he is seized by lust.
('55', 469, 6, 23, 894422) From a photostat of the Gujarati:G.N. 7500. Also C.W. 4977. Courtesy: Parasram Mehrotra
('55', 469, 7, 24, 894510) 1 Literally, Yeravda temple, that is, Yeravda Central Prison, where Gandhiji was imprisoned from January 4, 1932 to May 8, 1933. This place line is not reproduced in subsequent letters.
('55', 469, 7, 25, 894696) 2 A khadi worker and a Hindi teacher; also a member of Gandhiji’s secretariat for some time.
('55', 469, 7, 26, 894789) 3 Intellect, valour, virtue and truth are all like fish, while woman is like a bait, say the wise.”

('55', 471, 2, 3, 896234) June 2, 1932
('55', 471, 3, 4, 896247) DEAR SISTER, I was glad to read your letter.
('55', 471, 3, 5, 896292) Bhai Nariman had not given me your message.

('55', 480, 2, 15, 913789) My opinion in this matter is as follows: A person suffering from an incurable disease has the right to commit suicide if he cannot perform any service whatsover and lives only as a result of the ministrations of others.
('55', 480, 2, 16, 914009) Fasting unto death is infinitely superior to drowning oneself.
('55', 480, 2, 17, 914072) A person’s strength of character is tested in fasting moreover it leaves scope for changing one’s mind, which is both proper and necessary.
('55', 480, 2, 18, 914212) But as long as he can perform the least bit of service, he is not justified in putting an end to his life.
('55', 480, 2, 19, 914319) Although physical activity is an important and necessary feature of yajna a physically disabled person can certainly perform mental yajna which is not totally unfruitful.
('55', 480, 2, 20, 914490) A man by his pure thoughts alone can render service.
('55', 480, 2, 21, 914543) He can also be engaged in giving useful advice and such like.
('55', 480, 2, 22, 914605) The thoughts of a man possessing a pure heart are an activity by themselves and can produce far reaching results.
('55', 480, 2, 23, 914719) [From Hindi]
('55', 480, 3, 24, 914732) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. 1, pp.

('55', 481, 1, 2, 915269) grave doubts about the claims made by Mr. Cooper for the invention.
('55', 481, 1, 3, 915337) At Sabarmati we have tried almost all improved ploughs manufactured in India and I think even others, but the claims made for each variety have not proved true in the long run.
('55', 481, 1, 4, 915514) An experienced man has said that the indigenous plough is specially designed for the Indian soil.
('55', 481, 1, 5, 915612) It conserves the soil, because it ploughs deep enough for the farmer’s crops but never deep enough to do damage.
('55', 481, 1, 6, 915725) Of course I do not claim to understand agriculture.
('55', 481, 1, 7, 915777) I am simply giving you the testimony of those who have had considerable experience in these matters.
('55', 481, 1, 8, 915878) What we have to remember is that all improved implements have to meet the peculiar conditions of India.
('55', 481, 1, 9, 915982) There is nothing wrong in an engine plough in itself and it may be a great advantage to a man who owns thousands of acres of land, and has a cracked caky soil, which will not yield under the indigenous plough.
('55', 481, 1, 10, 916192) What, however, we want is an implement that would suit owners of small holdings from one acre to three acres.
('55', 481, 1, 11, 916302) I do not believe in the doctrine of the greatest good of the greatest number.
('55', 481, 1, 12, 916380) It means in its nakedness that in order to achieve the supposed good of 51 per cent the interest of 49 per cent may be, or rather, should be sacrificed.
('55', 481, 1, 13, 916533) It is a heartless doctrine and has done harm to humanity.
('55', 481, 1, 14, 916591) The only real, dignified, human doctrine is the greatest good of all, and this can only be achieved by uttermost self sacrifice.
