('55', 482, 1, 2, 917177) 555. CONCERNING “TITIKSHA” AND “YAJNA” 1
('55', 482, 2, 3, 917218) June 6, 1932 A friend 2 suffering from leprosy writes as follows: I am daily growing stronger in my faith that the best medicines for a person suffering from a disease like mine are asanas, pranayama and such other ordinary exercises and eating food earned through yajna.
('55', 482, 2, 4, 917490) I spend my time in reading the Gita, singing bhajans, meditation and spinning more than 500 rounds of yarn daily.
('55', 482, 2, 5, 917604) Our religion enjoins titiksha which means bearing all pains and miseries without opposing them even in thought, without worrying and without complaining.
('55', 482, 2, 6, 917758) I am trying to cultivate such endurance, and I am discovering from experience that it is difficult to acquire such strength unless one works regularly for yajna.
('55', 482, 2, 7, 917920) A person afflicted like me cannot do other forms of yajna, but, thanks be to God, I can do yajna by sweeping public roads, removing night soil and spinning, and I find my happiness in doing these things and try to bear my misfortune.
('55', 482, 2, 8, 918154) However, I often ask myself what my condition would be when the body became so weak that I could do no useful work.
('55', 482, 2, 9, 918270) The Shastras emphatically declare that a life without yajna is as good as death, that it is a burden and an affliction to the world.
('55', 482, 2, 10, 918403) You have said this repeatedly in your speeches and writings and my experience, too, tells the same thing.
('55', 482, 2, 11, 918509) If that is so, the question arises: “What is the duty of a person who is so seriously ill with a disease that he can do no useful work at all and must live on the service of others?” I even read in a Shastra that a person who suffered from such an incurable disease should give up his life by drowning himself or by some similar means.
('55', 482, 2, 12, 918845) This is only a summary in my own language of a beautiful letter.
('55', 482, 2, 13, 918910) I wish to draw a lesson for ourselves from this letter, namely, that all of us should cultivate this friend’s capacity for endurance and, even when ill with a disease, should go on doing useful work as long as the body permits.
('55', 482, 2, 14, 919138) That one must cultivate endurance and must do yajna—these are age old ideals.
('55', 482, 2, 15, 919216) We hear about them constantly in the Ashram.
('55', 482, 2, 16, 919261) When, however, we read such things described by a person
('55', 482, 3, 17, 919318) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 2 6 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 2 6 1932 2 D.V. Parachure Shastri; vide “ Letter to D.V. Parachure Shastri”, 3 6 1932
('55', 483, 0, 1, 919504) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 483, 1, 2, 919546) who is relating his own experience, they seem something new and fresh and the description has great power in it.
('55', 483, 1, 3, 919659) We do not expect a person suffering from leprosy to be able to write in this manner or to feel thus.
('55', 483, 1, 4, 919760) In most cases such persons, if they write about themselves, tell us how they suffer and complain about their misfortune.
('55', 483, 1, 5, 919881) Here we find something different altogether, and hence I have summarized the letter for the inmates of the Ashram.
('55', 483, 1, 6, 919996) The question which is raised in it also deserves attention.
('55', 483, 1, 7, 920056) We understand by yajna physical work voluntarily done for the service of others.
('55', 483, 1, 8, 920137) But this need not be taken to mean that a person who is physically too weak to do such work performs no yajna.
('55', 483, 1, 9, 920248) Such a person can serve with his mental capacities in many ways, and his work would most certainly be yajna.
('55', 483, 1, 10, 920357) But we can conceive of a case in which the person does not have the necessary degree of purity or sufficient mental strength for such yajna, and yet he is extremely eager to do it, has lost the desire to live, dislikes having to be served by others and is convinced that his disease is incurable.
('55', 483, 1, 11, 920654) I think that, in such circumstances a person who has the necessary strength of mind may certainly give up his life, one may even say that it is his duty to do so.
('55', 483, 1, 12, 920817) But to tell anybody that it is his duty to give up his life will probably shock him.
('55', 483, 1, 13, 920902) It is not right for a healthy person to tell another who is suffering from a disease that it is his duty to give up his life.
('55', 483, 1, 14, 921028) Such a remark may even upset that person.
('55', 483, 1, 15, 921070) But I think that is not likely to happen in this case, and so I have cautiously stated what seemed right to me.
('55', 483, 1, 16, 921182) It is certainly desirable that we should cease to fear death and give up the intense clinging to life which impels us to try to save it by trying every possible remedy and at the cost of infinite trouble to people around us.
('55', 483, 1, 17, 921407) My attitude in what I have written is that, if a thoughtful person afflicted with an incurable disease regards it his duty to give up his life, we need not think that what he does is absolutely wrong.

('55', 487, 3, 11, 928772) 559. A LETTER
('55', 487, 4, 12, 928786) June 8, 1932 Whatever your financial condition, bear this in mind: (1) One who earns money has the right to lose it.
('55', 487, 4, 13, 928903) (2) There is no shame in losing money, but it is shameful, even sinful, to hide the fact of one’s loss.
('55', 487, 4, 14, 929007) (3) One should never live beyond one’s means.
('55', 487, 4, 15, 929053) Though one may be living in a bungalow today, one should be prepared to live in a hut tomorrow.
('55', 487, 4, 16, 929149) (4) We need not feel ashamed if we do not have enough money to pay our creditors.
('55', 487, 4, 17, 929231) (5) Anybody who hands over to his creditors everything without keeping back a single pie for himself has fully repaid his debt.
('55', 487, 4, 18, 929359) (6) Wisdom lies first in not starting a business with borrowed money, but in case one has already done it, the next wise thing is to give away what one has and free oneself from one’s debts.
('55', 487, 4, 19, 929550) You may go to the Ashram whenever you wish to.

('55', 488, 3, 4, 929731) DEAR COL.

('55', 488, 3, 6, 929844) I appreciate the frank reasons given for the decision.
('55', 488, 3, 7, 929899) I do not know what the Government would call being “actively engaged in the furtherance of the civil disobedience movement”.
('55', 488, 3, 8, 930024) It is likely too that the Government are misinformed.
('55', 488, 3, 9, 930078) Obviously Mirabai has had no chance of refuting the information given to them.
('55', 488, 3, 10, 930157) I can only reiterate my statement that like several other companions of mine she has been intentionally, and for the movement itself, kept out of its civil resistance part.
('55', 488, 3, 11, 930330) But if Mirabai at any time was, or is now, actively engaged in the furtherance of the civil disobedience movement, my wife and my two sons were taking an active part in it.
('55', 488, 3, 12, 930503) Yet if they were not in prison, being members of my family, they would, I presume, be allowed to see me.
('55', 488, 3, 13, 930608) As I have made it clear to the Government in previous communications, I have long ceased to make any distinction between family members and others.
('55', 488, 3, 14, 930756) My co workers are as much members of my family as the members so called.
('55', 488, 3, 15, 930829) Unless therefore the Government see their way to revise their decision, I must deny myself the pleasure of having weekly visitors.
('55', 488, 3, 16, 930960) I enforced the self denying ordinance on Saturday last.
('55', 488, 3, 17, 931016) Indeed under the ruling given by the Government in Mirabai’s case it would be a serious thing for me to take the responsibility of deciding in the case of Ashram inmates who should and who should not see me.

('55', 490, 4, 8, 933219) If you feel that because of such self restraint the pain is gradually decreasing, you may conclude nothing else is necessary.
('55', 490, 4, 9, 933345) If the pain does not decrease gradually even though you take care not to use that limb, there is no option but to take complete rest.
('55', 490, 5, 10, 933479) There can be no one rule for all as to the time required for a meal.
('55', 490, 5, 11, 933548) If somebody’s meal consists only of milk, it would take him only five to seven minutes to sip it.
('55', 490, 5, 12, 933646) If somebody else’s meal consists only of one pomegranate and he has no teeth but has to eat the seeds instead of extracting the juice and drinking it, he may even take an hour to do so.
('55', 490, 5, 13, 933832) Hence the following should be the rule: A meal should take up as much time as is required for chewing it properly, taking into consideration the type and quantity of the food.
('55', 490, 5, 14, 934008) Ordinarily, twenty to thirty minutes should be regarded enough for those who have good teeth and who eat rotlis 1, dal, rice and vegetables.
('55', 490, 5, 15, 934149) I have no faith in the common belief about sleeping with the head in a certain direction.
('55', 490, 5, 16, 934239) I have never followed that rule.
('55', 490, 6, 17, 934272) It is my belief that the peepul tree is considered sacred because it is very big, covers a large area with shade and can be grown almost everywhere.

('55', 491, 4, 4, 934935) 564. A LETTER
('55', 491, 5, 5, 934949) June 9, 1932 As you say, you are continually assailed by impure thoughts and feel miserable because of that.
('55', 491, 5, 6, 935058) This is what is called self made hell.
('55', 491, 5, 7, 935097) This contains the replies to both your questions.
('55', 491, 5, 8, 935147) It makes clear why I said what I did and also why such a state of mind is described as hell.
('55', 491, 5, 9, 935240) If you understand the nature of this hell, it will also be easy for you to understand how you can come out of it.
('55', 491, 5, 10, 935354) You should not brood over the fact that you get impure thoughts.
('55', 491, 5, 11, 935419) Instead, you should go on as if they never troubled you.
('55', 491, 5, 12, 935476) If a person who stumbles while walking does not stop to find out the cause of his stumbling, no harm will follow.
('55', 491, 5, 13, 935590) If, on the contrary, such a person sits down on the road and goes on thinking why he stumbled, he will make no progress in his journey.
('55', 491, 5, 14, 935726) But he will forget that he had stumbled if he does not think much about the fact and continues his journey.
('55', 491, 5, 15, 935834) Since he is advancing, he gradually gathers strength and consequently stumblesless.
('55', 491, 6, 16, 935918) [From Gujarati]

('55', 491, 8, 18, 935966) 565. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('55', 491, 9, 19, 935998) June 10, 1932 Most of the manual work in the Ashram is done by the inmates themselves.
('55', 491, 9, 20, 936085) There are a few hired labourers, but only those men who follow the Ashram rules fairly well have remained to work in that capacity and the inmates of the Ashram work with them.
('55', 491, 9, 21, 936262) Gradually they are acquiring mastery over all types of work.
('55', 491, 9, 22, 936323) Children also contribute their share Newcomers are first required to learn prayers, bhajans, etc.
('55', 491, 9, 23, 936421) It is only after they have learnt these that those among them who wish to learn English may do so.
('55', 492, 0, 1, 936520) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 493
('55', 492, 1, 2, 936566) All the inmates spin for yajna in company for one hour.
('55', 492, 1, 3, 936622) Yarn of less than twenty counts cannot be included as part of one’s contribution through the spinning yajna.
('55', 492, 1, 4, 936731) The yarn spun on a day has to be handed over to the depot on the same day.
('55', 492, 1, 5, 936806) I have now suggested that, if all the people agree, no one should be permitted to buy the yarn spun by himself or herself for his or her own use.
('55', 492, 1, 6, 936952) 1 I have always believed that our yajna remains incomplete because of this freedom to buy one’s own yarn.
('55', 492, 1, 7, 937058) Beginning last week, it has been decided to maintain an account of everybody’s labour at the rate of one anna per hour of work irrespective of the nature of work, though it has not been decided to make actual payments at this rate.
('55', 492, 1, 8, 937290) Just now my suggestion to Narandas was merely that, if he agreed, he should immediately start keeping the records.
('55', 492, 1, 9, 937405) These records will be in addition to the general records which are being kept now, and for the present we will merely note the results.
('55', 492, 1, 10, 937541) They will give us much useful information and may also help us to realize the ideal of equality of work.
('55', 492, 1, 11, 937646) In other words, all types of social service, whether spinning or weaving or cleaning lavatories, should be valued at the rate of one anna per hour of work.
('55', 492, 1, 12, 937802) You probably remember that we have discussed this subject in the past at great length.
('55', 492, 1, 13, 937889) Recently I have been writing to Narandas on a variety of subjects and among them I brought up this one again for discussion.
('55', 492, 1, 14, 938014) It seems to me that Narandas’s capacity for responding to such idea has increased considerably these days.
('55', 492, 1, 15, 938121) He, therefore, welcomed my suggestion.
('55', 492, 1, 16, 938160) These records do not require much time to maintain and, if the present experiment reaches the stage of implementation, the keeping of accounts would be so easy that even a person of ordinary education in Gujarati would be able to do the work.
('55', 492, 1, 17, 938403) Success in maintaining accounts of this nature depends on the honesty of the people.
('55', 492, 1, 18, 938488) If a person has not really worked for the number of hours which he enters against his name or supplies to the account keeper, or if he has done the work carelessly, it is plain that the account will not be correct.
('55', 492, 1, 19, 938703) That is, it will be like good and bad coins getting mixed up.

('55', 493, 1, 2, 939114) All of us should make the right use, according to our lights, of this priceless opportunity which we have got.
('55', 493, 1, 3, 939225) The best use we can make of it is to cultivate the power of reflection.
('55', 493, 1, 4, 939297) Our minds are oftenvacant and at such times the only thing we like to do is either to read or to talk.
('55', 493, 1, 5, 939400) Some of us do think, but they only build castles in the air.
('55', 493, 1, 6, 939461) Really speaking, just as reading is an art so is thinking.
('55', 493, 1, 7, 939520) All our thoughts should occur to us at the right time.
('55', 493, 1, 8, 939575) Just we do not read useless books, so also we should not let our minds run after idle thoughts.
('55', 493, 1, 9, 939671) The power which is produced and conserved by such control over one’s thoughts can not be measured.
('55', 493, 1, 10, 939770) I have felt during each term of imprisonment that it was the best time for learning to think in this manner.
('55', 493, 1, 11, 939879) I, therefore, advise all of you to master the art of deep reflection.
('55', 493, 1, 12, 939949) If you do so, you will not find it necessary to consult me frequently.

('55', 493, 1, 14, 940061) I do not wish to forbid anyone to consult me.
('55', 493, 1, 15, 940107) I only wish to cure people of excessive dependence on me.
('55', 493, 1, 16, 940165) In case of necessity, however, my advice will always be available.
('55', 493, 1, 17, 940232) It is your right and also your duty to take whatever advantage you can of my experience and the results of my reflection concerning matters of which I have had more experience and over which I have reflected more deeply than others.

('55', 508, 1, 5, 970382) On the other hand, a desire which has been accepted by the heart cannot but inspire sincere effort to fulfil it, though it is quite possible that owing to various cirmustances or weakness of the body our desire may not be fulfilled during this life.
('55', 508, 1, 6, 970632) We have experience of this every day.
('55', 508, 1, 7, 970670) But the desire will cling to the soul when it leaves the body, and in the next life the difficulties which stood in the way of itsfulfilment during this life will diminish and the desire will be fulfilled or will at least become stronger.
('55', 508, 1, 8, 970909) Thus a person who aspires after spiritual life is ever advancing.
('55', 508, 1, 9, 970975) It may be that Jnaneshwar Maharaj meditated on Nivrittinath 1
('55', 508, 2, 10, 971037) while the latter was alive, but I am strongly of the view that we should not follow his example.
('55', 508, 2, 11, 971134) If we meditate on a person, he must have attained perfection.
('55', 508, 2, 12, 971196) It is altogether improper, and also unnecessary to ascribe perfection to a living human being.
('55', 508, 2, 13, 971291) It is possible, however, that Jnaneshwar Maharaj did not meditate on the real Nivrittinath, but meditated on the perfect Nivrittinath of his imagination.
('55', 508, 2, 14, 971445) But why should we need at all concern ourselves with this problem?
('55', 508, 2, 15, 971512) when the question is about the propriety of meditating on a living human being, we need not bring in the question of meditating on our mental image of that person and any reply on the propriety of that is likely to confuse the reason of the other person.
('55', 508, 2, 16, 971767) The names which are given Chapter I are, according to me, more the names of certain qualities than of real persons.
('55', 508, 2, 17, 971883) While describing the divine and the demoniac forces in our nature, the poet has personified them.
('55', 508, 2, 18, 971981) In saying this, I do not deny the possibility of an actual battle between Kauravas and Pandavas having taken place near Hastinapur.
('55', 508, 2, 19, 972113) My belief is that the poet took a well knwon event of that age as an example and used it as material for his immortal work.
('55', 508, 2, 20, 972237) I may be mistaken in this belief and all those names may be the names of real persons.
('55', 508, 2, 21, 972324) If so, it was not improper for the poet to give those names at the commencement of his historical narrative, and, since the first chapter is necessary for introducing the subject, it is necessary to recite it as part of ceremonial recitation of the Gita.
('55', 508, 2, 22, 972579) If we spin with slivers made by somebody else, our spinning yajna is certainly imperfect.
('55', 508, 2, 23, 972669) A person like me may not be able to make his own slivers at present owing to physical weakness, but those
('55', 508, 3, 24, 972775) 1 Jnaneshwar’s elder brother, a jnanayogi
('55', 509, 0, 1, 972817) 510 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 509, 1, 2, 972859) who can should make their own slivers.
('55', 509, 1, 3, 972898) I consider it necessary for everybody to learn spinning on the takli and gain mastery over it.
('55', 509, 1, 4, 972993) I know that Vinoba regards it as a much easier means for the yajna of spinning.
('55', 509, 1, 5, 973073) I have not come to a final decision about this, nor do I wish to do so without discussing the matter at length with Vinoba.
('55', 509, 1, 6, 973197) I am, therefore, not particular either way.
('55', 509, 1, 7, 973241) You should, however, discuss your suggestion with Narandas.
('55', 509, 1, 8, 973301) I also will do so.
('55', 509, 2, 9, 973320) BAPU [PS.] Write to me about your constipation.

('55', 509, 5, 12, 973477) June 15, 1932
('55', 509, 6, 13, 973491) MANU 1, I got your letter.
('55', 509, 6, 14, 973518) I cannot understand why you did not get the letter that was sent with my letter to Jamnadas 2 .
('55', 509, 6, 15, 973614) Your courage is being tested fairly well.

('55', 510, 0, 1, 974489) VOL. 55 : 10 FEBRUARY, 1932 15 JUNE, 1932 511
('55', 510, 1, 2, 974535) 580. A LETTER
('55', 510, 2, 3, 974549) June 15, 1932 Like you, some others also believe that I live a life of self control and observe brahmacharya, and that, therefore, I was sure to live long.
('55', 510, 2, 4, 974705) This belief about me is not correct, or it is correct only partially in contrast with how other people live.
('55', 510, 2, 5, 974814) I indulged in sexual pleasure nearly up to the age of 30. Nor can I claim that I exercised self control in eating.
('55', 510, 2, 6, 974929) I used to eat all kinds of delicacies for themere pleasure of the palate.
('55', 510, 2, 7, 975003) Then I steadily drifted towards restrain.
('55', 510, 2, 8, 975045) But this does not mean at all that I have overcome the cravings of the senses.
('55', 510, 2, 9, 975124) All I can claim is that I have learnt to hold them under control.
('55', 510, 2, 10, 975190) Thus, self indulgence had already had its effect on my body, but it has been counteracted in the measure that I have acquired self control.
('55', 510, 2, 11, 975330) My contemporaries who do not exercise even that much self control naturally wonder at my self control such as it is and do not observe my weakness.
('55', 510, 3, 12, 975478) The privileges which I enjoy as a prisoner are not because of my being placed in a particular class.
('55', 510, 3, 13, 975579) I am not treated as an ordinary convict.
('55', 510, 3, 14, 975620) Prisoners of my category 2 are entitled to many privileges.
('55', 510, 3, 15, 975680) This, of course, is no defence of what I do.
('55', 510, 3, 16, 975725) Though the Government does give certain privileges to a prisoner like me, it certainly depends on the prisoner himself whether or not to avail himself of those privileges.
('55', 510, 3, 17, 975897) Hence the misunderstanding which you mention is quite natural.
('55', 510, 3, 18, 975960) But I regard it in public interest to continue to avail myself of the privileges even at the risk of incurring such a misunderstanding.
('55', 510, 3, 19, 976096) But it should not be necessary for me to defend this point of view.
('55', 510, 3, 20, 976164) Its correctness should be self evident.
('55', 510, 3, 21, 976204) Even if it is not, I should cling to it so long as I believe it to be earnest.
('55', 510, 3, 22, 976283) This reasoning applies to every captain of a ship.
('55', 510, 3, 23, 976334) A captain cannot always explain the reasons for the cours which he is following.
('55', 510, 3, 24, 976415) But he would not deserve to be a captain if he listens to the advice of others and give up what he believes to be the right course.
('55', 510, 3, 25, 976547) Such captains are known to have wrecked on rocks the ships under their charge.
('55', 510, 3, 26, 976626) Hence persons like you may certainly caution me whenever they have doubt about the propriety of my actions.
('55', 510, 3, 27, 976734) If, however, I do not change my policy even after that, they should have faith that what I am doing is right.
('55', 510, 3, 28, 976844) It does happen
('55', 510, 4, 29, 976859) 1 Here follows Mahadev Desai’s comment introducing the next paragraph but does not indicate if any portion in omitted here.
('55', 510, 4, 30, 976983) 2 State prisoners detained under Regulation 25 of 1829
('55', 511, 0, 1, 977038) 512 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 511, 1, 2, 977080) sometimes that such faith proves to be misplaced.
('55', 511, 1, 3, 977130) But there is no other way of managing public affairs.
('55', 511, 1, 4, 977184) At the moment I am confident that, when I feel that I ought not to avail myself of a particular privilege or of any of them, I shall have the strength to renounce it or them.
('55', 511, 1, 5, 977359) In South Africa I spent fairly long periods of imprisonment as an ordinary prisoner.
('55', 511, 1, 6, 977444) From whom did you hear that story about Krishnadas 1?
('55', 511, 1, 7, 977498) There is no truth in it at all.
('55', 511, 1, 8, 977530) Krishnadas was certainly not sent away.
('55', 511, 1, 9, 977570) For somereasons he himself asked for leave to go.
('55', 511, 1, 10, 977620) But though he has left, our relations have remained the same.
('55', 511, 1, 11, 977682) It is against my nature to take any such step at somebody’s instigation.
('55', 511, 1, 12, 977755) And nobody instigated me to take such a step in regard to Krishnadas.
('55', 511, 1, 13, 977825) All the same I wish to know the source of this story.
('55', 511, 1, 14, 977879) If you think you can tell me, please let me know.
('55', 511, 1, 15, 977929) [From Gujarati]
('55', 511, 2, 16, 977945) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 512, 2, 3, 978069) APPENDIX I
('55', 512, 3, 4, 978080) LETTER FROM SIR SAMUEL HOARE 1
('55', 512, 4, 5, 978111) April 13, 1932
('55', 512, 5, 6, 978126) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('55', 512, 6, 7, 978143) I write this in answer to your letter of 11th March and I say at once I realize fully the strength of your feeling upon the question of separate electorates for the “Depressed” Classes.
('55', 512, 6, 8, 978329) I can only say that we intend to give any decision that may be necessary solely and only upon the merits of the case.
('55', 512, 6, 9, 978447) As you are aware, Lord Lothian’s Committee has not yet completed its tour and it must be some weeks before we can receive any conclusions at which it may have arrived.
('55', 512, 6, 10, 978615) When we receive the report we shall have to give most careful consideration to its recommendations and we shall not give a decision until we have taken into account in addition to the view expressed by the Committee the views that you and those who think with you have so forcibly expressed.
('55', 512, 6, 11, 978907) I feel sure if you were in our position you would be taking exactly the same action we intend to take.
('55', 512, 6, 12, 979010) You would await the Committee’s report, you would then give it your fullest consideration and before arriving at a final decision you would take into account the views that have been expressed on both sides of the controversy.
('55', 512, 6, 13, 979237) More than this I cannot say.
('55', 512, 6, 14, 979266) Indeed I do not imagine you would expect me to say more.
('55', 512, 6, 15, 979323) As to the Ordinances, I can only repeat what I have already said both publicly and privately.
('55', 512, 6, 16, 979417) I am convinced that it was essential to impose them in the face of the deliberate attack upon the very foundations of orderly government.
('55', 512, 6, 17, 979555) I am also convinced that both the Government of India and the local Governments are not abusing their extensive powers and are doing everything possible to prevent excessive or vindictive action.
('55', 512, 6, 18, 979751) We shall not keep the Emergency measures in force any longer than we are obliged to for the purpose of maintaining the essentials of law and order and protecting our officials and other classes of the community against terrorist outrages.
('55', 512, 6, 19, 979990) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI, ESQUIRE
('55', 512, 7, 20, 980029) The Bombay Chronicle, 13 9 1932

('55', 514, 11, 15, 982252) EXTRACTS FROM MIRABEHN’S LETTER 1
('55', 514, 12, 16, 982286) April 8, 1932
('55', 514, 13, 17, 982300) Received a letter from Mirabehn with 24 pages, every line of it instinct with spotless devotion.
('55', 514, 13, 18, 982397) She would not be happy unless she lived with and rendered personal service to Bapu.
('55', 514, 13, 19, 982481) But Bapu wants her to get rid of this desire, as otherwise she would feel herself stranded when Bapu was no more with us.
('55', 514, 13, 20, 982603) This controversy has been on ever since Mirabehn came to India.
('55', 514, 13, 21, 982667) In today’s letter she has poured out her wonderfully transparent heart: Bapu, I am never without that thought in my mind, as to how best to serve you.
('55', 514, 13, 22, 982818) I think and pray and reason with myself, and it always ends the same way in my heart of hearts.
('55', 514, 13, 23, 982914) When you are taken from us, as in jail, an instinct impels me to work with all my strength at outward service of your cause.
('55', 514, 13, 24, 983039) I feel no doubt and no difficulty.
('55', 514, 13, 25, 983074) When you are with us, an equally strong instinct impels me to retire into silent
('55', 514, 14, 26, 983155) 1Vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 8 4 1932
('55', 515, 0, 1, 983192) 516 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('55', 515, 1, 2, 983234) personal service—trying to do anything else, I feel lost and futile.
('55', 515, 1, 3, 983303) The capacity for the former depends on the fulfilment of the latter.
('55', 515, 1, 4, 983372) The one is the counterpart of the other, and something continually tells me that it was for fulfilment in that way that I was led to you.
('55', 515, 1, 5, 983510) The instinct is so strong that I cannot get round it or through it or over it.
('55', 515, 1, 6, 983589) It is difficult to ask you to have faith in it as the full proof of its correctness can only leave it at that.
('55', 515, 1, 7, 983700) This much I know full well that during this struggle my strength, capacity and inner peace and happiness are much greater than last time, because I had been able to serve according to my instinct (except for one short spell of anguish since your previous release).
('55', 515, 1, 8, 983965) The fact that I was on the point of a breakdown when I came here had nothing to do with this question.
('55', 515, 1, 9, 984068) It was sheer over work, because when I saw that I was shortly going to be arrested, I simply spent my strength recklessly, knowing an enforced rest was coming.
('55', 515, 1, 10, 984228) And there was more than enough work around me to be reckless over.
('55', 515, 1, 11, 984295) Who knows if it is all delusion!
('55', 515, 1, 12, 984328) But a woman has to go by instinct.
('55', 515, 1, 13, 984363) It is stronger with her than any amount of reason, and her full strength can only be harnessed and brought into service if her nature is able to express itself.
('55', 515, 1, 14, 984524) I have no thought, no care, no longing in all the world except for you— (you the cause—you the ideal.) To serve that cause in this life and to reach that ideal in after life, Godwho has brought me from utter darkness to the light of your path will surely not answer my prayers by leaving me now to follow a wrong instinct.
('55', 515, 1, 15, 984847) I have not written all this for the sake of argument, but simply to share with you the result of my ceaseless strivings to (understand) since I have been in jail.
('55', 515, 2, 16, 985010) The Diary of Mahadev Desai, Vol. I, pp.

('55', 518, 1, 2, 988061) APPENDIX VII
('55', 518, 2, 3, 988074) RABINDRANATH TAGORE’S APPEAL 1
('55', 518, 3, 4, 988105) VISWABHARATI,
('55', 518, 4, 5, 988119) SANTINIKETAN,
('55', 518, 5, 6, 988133) BENGAL,
('55', 518, 6, 7, 988141) March 22, 1932
('55', 518, 7, 8, 988156) From the depths of the present atmosphere of suffering the cry has come for the inauguration of a new age of faith and reconciliation, for a fellowship of understanding between races and nations alienated by cruel politics and diplomacy.
('55', 518, 7, 9, 988394) We in India are ready for a fundamental change in our affairs which will bring harmony and understanding into our relationships with those who have inevitably been brought near to us.
('55', 518, 7, 10, 988578) We are waiting for a gesture of goodwill from both sides, spontaneous and generous in its faith in humanity, which will create a future of moral federation, of constructive works of public good, of the inner harmony of peace between the peoples of India and England.
('55', 518, 7, 11, 988845) The visit of our friends from England has confirmed the immediate possibility of such an intimate fellowship and truth in our mutual relationship, and I feel called upon to appeal to all who have the welfare of humanity at heart to come forward at this critical hour and courageously take upon themselves the task of fulfilling the moral responsibility, which is before us, of building upon the bare foundation of faith or acceptance of truth in a spirit of generous mutual forgiveness.
('55', 518, 7, 12, 989332) The memory of the past, however painful it may have been for us all, should never obscure the vision of the perfect, of the future which it is for us jointly to create.
('55', 518, 7, 13, 989501) Indeed, our experience of the futility of suspicion and hostility must inspire us with a profounder belief in the truth of the simple fellowship of hearts, in the mighty power of creative understanding between individuals as well as nations inspired by a common urge of love.
('55', 518, 8, 14, 989777) Advance, 23 6 1932
('55', 518, 9, 15, 989796) 1Vide”Letter to Percy W. Bartlett”, 4 5 1932. The message was given to the Society of Friends Deputation at Santiniketan in March.
('55', 518, 9, 16, 989927) Dr. Tagore asked them to take it personally to Gandhiji but permission was refused by the Government of India.
